city.name: Paris
city.about:
Paris, the cosmopolitan capital of France, has the reputation of being the most beautiful and romantic of all cities, brimming with historic associations and remaining vastly influential in the realms of culture, art, fashion, food and design.

Dubbed the City of Light (la ville lumière) and the City of Love (la ville de l'amour), Paris is home to some of the world's finest and most luxurious fashion designers and cosmetics, such as Chanel, Christian Dior, Yves Saint-Laurent, Guerlain, Lancôme, L'Oréal, and Clarins. A large part of the city, including the banks of the River Seine, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. 

The city has the second highest number of Michelin-starred restaurants in the world (after Tokyo, which is much larger) and contains numerous iconic landmarks such as the Eiffel Tower, the Arc de Triomphe, Notre-Dame de Paris, the Louvre, the Moulin Rouge and the Basilique du Sacré-Cœur, making it one of the most popular international tourist destinations in the world, with around 14 million visitors annually

points_of_interest.name: La Belle Villoise
points_of_interest.description: An underground, and thus hipper, alternative to La Maroquinerie next door.

points_of_interest.name: Flèche d'Or
points_of_interest.description: An old train station which has been transformed into a hip, popular night club.

points_of_interest.name: Gambetta
points_of_interest.description: All things Jamaican: reggae, dub, jazz, etc.

points_of_interest.name: Goguette
points_of_interest.description: A mainly Latino-American club.

points_of_interest.name: Bateau Phare
points_of_interest.description: Batofar This little red lighthouse boat hosts dance and chill electronic music and other multimedia cultured events and has been one of the coolest spots around for some time. It was closed in or around 2018 but reopened in 2024 under a new name, "le Bateau Phare," that sounds just like the old one, "le Batofar." The dance floor is in the hold, a restaurant is above it, and the lounge on the upper deck. There is also a restaurant on the quai called "La Terrasse" that is open from May to October.

points_of_interest.name: Apogé
points_of_interest.description: Apogé is a dynamic, all-in-one stop for French wine. Part bar, part merchant, part oenology school, its passionate, friendly founders are happy to share their expert advice. Not only are over 100 wines available by the glass, but every bottle for sale can be tasted before purchase. A beautiful terrace and frequent tastings with producers.

points_of_interest.name: La Dame de Canton
points_of_interest.description: La Guinguette Pirate Known for years as the ''Guinguette Pirate'', this Chinese junk has been rechristened with her maiden name. The restaurant and bookings are still the same, with equal parts world music, ''chanson français'' and concerts for kids.

points_of_interest.name: Paname Brewing Company Tap House
points_of_interest.description: PBC Tap house with 16 beers on tap and restaurant. Great views across along the Ourcq. Pizzas, burgers and salads available.

points_of_interest.name: James Joyce Pub
points_of_interest.description: Also serves standard Irish pub food. They screen Irish and English football and soccer.

points_of_interest.name: Andy Wahloo
points_of_interest.description: Andy Wahloo apparently means "I don't have anything" in Arabic. The Moroccan artist who owns this place certainly means it as a play on words having done the decor as a Moorish take on Andy Warhol.

points_of_interest.name: Les Arts et Métiers
points_of_interest.description: An updated but otherwise standard ''Brasserie'', the draw here is the crowd: young trendy locals love the place.

points_of_interest.name: Chez Justine
points_of_interest.description: Close to the centre of the Oberkampf nightlife zone, "Justine's place" functions as a restaurant & bar with trendy versions French offerings (which get mixed reviews) during the early evening, but it's 22ː00-02ː00 which really makes the place. Most of the room is filled with big wooden plank tables which are just the thing for a lively conversation with friends, while the bar is comfy too, and attracts quite a crowd by the late evening. The decor is classic, understated, and classy.

points_of_interest.name: L'Attirail
points_of_interest.description: Cool bar/club with concerts ranging from ''Jazz Manouche'' to contemporary swing.

points_of_interest.name: I Golosi
points_of_interest.description: On a quiet side street, a good Italian wine bar and shop where you can buy the wines you will have tasted.

points_of_interest.name: Grenier
points_of_interest.description: An excellent, but tiny dive bar with live bands upstairs in the hall some nights, but usually downstairs in the front window. This is a great place to hear Django Reinhardt-style jazz guitar playing (''Jazz Manouche'').

points_of_interest.name: Baxo
points_of_interest.description: A lounge bar restaurant with a ''bobo'' environment and rich dishes. A new romantic lounge bar with a very nice patio.

points_of_interest.name: Nouveau Casino et Café Charbon
points_of_interest.description: The New Casino keeps rocking until dawn both in the bar downstairs and the medium-size dance hall upstairs, making it ''the'' favourite among young Parisians, especially after the other places in the neighbourhood have closed. The dance/concert hall features cutting-edge indie rock groups and cutting-edge electronica. The prices do reflect the hipness however.

points_of_interest.name: Le Verre Volé
points_of_interest.description: A part wine bar-part wine shop, an excellent address for nice, simple food & wines. You can take home a bottle you've sampled during meal if you wish!

points_of_interest.name: Café Noir
points_of_interest.description: A particularly fine example of a Paris café.

points_of_interest.name: Le Perchoir
points_of_interest.description: Rooftop bar on the 6th and 7th floors of an old industrial building with a view of Paris from the four corners of the terrace. Expect a wait to enter on Friday or Saturday evenings. Once on the roof, there are unfinished wood, plants and colored cushions. Winter-mode, inside are bar and informal restaurant. See and be seen. The ''Snack Shack'' serves typical bar food. A wide selection of cocktails are available. DJ Sets.
points_of_interest.address: 12 Rue Crespin Du Gast, 75011 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Les Enfants Rouge
points_of_interest.description: This one is makes for another tough call between the ''Eat'' and ''Drink'' sections. It's a completely traditional French bistro with a popular bar in the evenings.

points_of_interest.name: Au fût et à mesure
points_of_interest.description: A beer-bar coming with a new concept: one beer-pump on every table. Each table have its own distinct beer in the pump, so you have to meet people to taste other beers.

points_of_interest.name: The Frog at Bercy Village
points_of_interest.description: Popular English brew-pub with a French twist. Open terrace at each end. Check the beer menu for current selection of beers brewed on the premises. Interesting range of snacks and more filling dishes.

points_of_interest.name: Le Cafe des Lettres
points_of_interest.description: The charming cobblestoned courtyard makes this an ideal place to sit down and linger over a glass of wine. Excellent cocktail list.

points_of_interest.name: Entre Potes
points_of_interest.description: A good place to relax "among friends" as the name would suggest, thus making it a fairly representative Parisian bar, with notable cocktails.

points_of_interest.name: Léonard
points_of_interest.description: If you like trendy décor this is your joint. Free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: The Frog & Rosbif
points_of_interest.description: As you probably know the English use the word "frog" as an ethnic slur for the French. You may not know that the word "rosbif" is a French ethnic slur for the English. Well, it seems that there are mostly no hard feelings over a pint, or so the presence of this chain of 6 English pubs in the French capital would tend to suggest.

points_of_interest.name: Les Marcheurs de Planete
points_of_interest.description: French wine bar with good prices and atmosphere and a friendly staff.

points_of_interest.name: Harry's New York Bar
points_of_interest.description: Legend has it that Harry's New York Bar was the birthplace of the Bloody Mary invented by Fernand "Pete" Petiot, an American bartender, and was another Hemingway hangout.

points_of_interest.name: Moonshiner
points_of_interest.description: Cool ''speakeasy'' bar with a secret entrance. Cross the small dining room of the pizzeria Da Vito and open the walk-in refrigerator door. You will enter into the bowels of an ancient American-style boiler room and bar. The interior welcomes brave visitors to a dim, classy and jazzy world. There you will find friendly steampunk bartenders making innovative cocktails. Try a cigar in the large Art Deco smokehouse... but ''shhhhh'', don't tell anyone.

points_of_interest.name: The Quiet Man
points_of_interest.description: This Irish pub has sessions and Irish music almost (but not quite) nightly. The atmosphere is tops for the genre.

points_of_interest.name: Café de Flore
points_of_interest.description: This café is famous as the favored coffee and smoking venue for the Surrealists during the 1920s and '30s, the Existentialists in the 1940s and '50s, and still attracts an artistic and literary crowd. Also does breakfasts and light meals.

points_of_interest.name: Les Petits Crus
points_of_interest.description: Les Petits Crus is a wine bar specializing in a marriage between wine and cheese. Matched combinations can be chosen among reasonably priced wine and cheese by ''theme'' in 4 or 6 test tubes of quality wine of your choosing, accompanied with matching cheese, bread, salad and cold cuts if desired. All wine is organic.

points_of_interest.name: Les Deux Magots
points_of_interest.description: Another famous literary café, right next door to its great rival Café de Flore. Sartre and Hemingway were regular patrons here and the café confirms its literary connections with an annual, somewhat prestigious book prize.

points_of_interest.name: La Fée Verte
points_of_interest.description: La Fée Verte is an '''absinthe bar''' (and café) as it was known more than 100 years ago. Although no longer produced to be hallucinogenic, absinthe is an enjoyable alcoholic drink you prepare at your table. In the traditional French way, place a sugar cube on top of a specially designed slotted spoon over a small glass of absinthe. Next a large absinthe fountain with a crystal bowl of ice water and several small spouts is shared. Each person opens a valve to their spout and slowly drips the ice water onto the sugar cube until the cube is dissolved and the drink is diluted to their liking.

points_of_interest.name: Bluebird
points_of_interest.description: A real gin bar but they serve many other drinks, specialty cocktails included. Bar food is available but do not come for the food. This place is about cocktails.

points_of_interest.name: The Bombardier
points_of_interest.description: Great pub in a prime location right in front of beautiful St-Etienne-du-Mont church and the Panthéon. One of the few pubs in Paris where you can get cask ales, and they also make cocktails. Food served at lunchtime (good pub food, e.g., bangers & mash, English breakfasts, fish & chips, etc.). Also a great place to watch sporting events like Premier League matches and the Six-Nations tournament as the pub draws a mixed crowd of French and English regulars with expats and tourists thrown into the mix.

points_of_interest.name: The Fifth Bar
points_of_interest.description: Named for the arrondissement, or maybe a measure of whiskey, this little hole-in-the-wall caters to a mixed anglophone expatriate crowd, with a mix of local students and (in tourist season) backpackers. Tuesdays and Thursdays are student nights with happy-hour prices all night with a student ID. Depending on season, American sports often play on the television, as do English Premier league and Spanish Primera matches.

points_of_interest.name: The Auld Alliance Scottish Pub
points_of_interest.description: Friendly staff and customers help create a welcoming atmosphere at the original Scottish pub in Paris. Excellent food is served every day including a hearty brunch. The pub is selling quality British crisps, even smokey bacon flavour. A wide selection of whisky is on offer. Sporting events are shown on eight large television screens. Regular darts and pool competitions take place and Monday night is quiz night.

points_of_interest.name: Café des Phares
points_of_interest.description: Since 1992 this otherwise very attractive but fairly standard Parisian café has been host to a lively discussion of contemporary philosophy and attendant issues every Sunday night. There's a political discussion too, on the first Thursday of each month.

points_of_interest.name: Café de l'Homme
points_of_interest.description: Get a fantastic view of the Eiffel Tower from this restaurant-tearoom opposite the Champ de Mars. Just next to the Musee de l'Homme, there certainly are worse spots to grab a drink or two. Bad service towards tourists according to online reviews.

points_of_interest.name: Le Vieux Chêne
points_of_interest.description: Just down the way from the fifth on the left is another hole-in-the-wall, this one dating from the 18th century. It was named after its sign, a bas relief of an old oak tree (vieux chene), which was around 250 years when it was chiselled off early in 2005 by workmen restoring the facade of the building. The selection of beers, etc., is good and the crowd is mostly students. Expect to pay around €4 for a pint. There is a minuscule dance floor in the atmospheric and sweaty cellar below. On Tuesday nights, there is live music and the musicians take requests from the crowd, playing classic French and American songs.

points_of_interest.name: Au Progres
points_of_interest.description: Small bar in an old place.

points_of_interest.name: Buddha Bar
points_of_interest.description: Famous in electronic lounge music circles for having commissioned a series of lounge and down tempo records which you can get at most larger record shops in France, as well as abroad. Although you can also get them at the bar it's probably not the best way, since they charge €45 per CD. The drinks are not so over-priced, and definitely worth it for the hip, sophisticated, and chill atmosphere.

points_of_interest.name: The Bowler
points_of_interest.description: English pub regularly frequented by British expats.

points_of_interest.name: Le Divan du Monde
points_of_interest.description: A fairly major venue for indi-rock, hip-hop, and other concerts. The prices are usually pretty good and the size of the venue and decor are great.

points_of_interest.name: Caféothèque de Paris
points_of_interest.description: Coffee in Paris is usually found to be lacking, but not in this mini temple to coffee. A gem tucked into a backstreet by the river in le Marais roasts their own beans from around the world and has a small laid-back café area with armchairs. Staff are passionate about great coffee, not just a scaldingly hot coffee! They have some cakes and wine, and speak Spanish and English.

points_of_interest.name: Queen Ann
points_of_interest.description: The "salon de thé" serves soufflés and cakes. The small place has 12 tables. The hot chocolate makes the place highly addictable.

points_of_interest.name: Bar Hemingway
points_of_interest.description: Hemingway tried to drink here once per week even before he made it big. In August 1944 Hemingway made a booze-powered drive into Paris ''ahead'' of the advancing Free French 2nd Tank Division to "liberate the Ritz", and specifically the bar which was shortly thereafter renamed in his honour. Today the bar is considered by many to be one of the best bars in the world, in no small part due to the bar-tending skills of Colin Field, who creates elaborate cocktails as a fine art, and with the rest of the staff is skilled at bringing his guests together in conversation.

points_of_interest.name: Café Oz
points_of_interest.description: Café Oz Châtelet You probably didn't think you were coming to Paris to sample Australian culture, but if after a long day of strolling from one end of the city to another you would just like to let go a bit and meet up with some fellow anglophones then you could do a lot worse than this almost legendarily hard-partying Aussie joint (ask the neighbours). Warning: as with other Aussie places in Paris for some reason, weekend nights here tend to bring out hoards of young single Frenchmen looking to chat up some (any) visiting sheilas. This has been known to lead to, um, confrontations. ~€7 pints.

points_of_interest.name: Juvénile's
points_of_interest.description: The bistro serves many different wines from around the world and tapas. You can buy a bottle to take home if you like it.

points_of_interest.name: Willi's Wine Bar
points_of_interest.description: It's actually a restaurant and is more upscale than Juvéniles, serving good food and good-to-great bottles of wine with a focus on the Rhône Valley, but including many from Burgundy, the Loire, as well as Italians, and "Atlantic crossing" Californians. The dinner menu by chef François Yon Great won the "Bib Gourmet 2009" award, and there are cheeses & desserts (yummy crumble) for after. Reservations recommended.

points_of_interest.name: Celtic Corner Pub
points_of_interest.description: A nice little Irish pub with charming service and fair price. Sports men from the nearby Gymnase "Croix Nivert" like to hang out here for a beer or two.

points_of_interest.name: Crocodile Vert
points_of_interest.description: The small hidden Cuban bar is a bit away from rue de Vaugirard. It is quite popular for the salsa music on the weekends. At later times you'll recognise it by the number of people standing outside.

points_of_interest.name: Le square café
points_of_interest.description: In spring time sun is shining on the outdoor terrace. It is a nice spot for a tea with soft background music.

points_of_interest.name: Le César Palace Paris
points_of_interest.description: Diner and show - Parisian cabaret show and dancing.

points_of_interest.name: Lou Pascalou
points_of_interest.description: Well hidden but worth seeking out, this unassuming restaurant serves happily inexpensive good food.

points_of_interest.name: l'Abadache
points_of_interest.description: A French-English collaboration, the cooking is mostly in the French tradition, but with English cheddar and quite a bit of English inventiveness. Go for the polenta with sun-dried tomatoes.

points_of_interest.name: Le Bistral
points_of_interest.description: Inventive cooking in the Spanish tradition and an intimate atmosphere are what distinguishes this little place from the dozens of bistros in the neighbourhood, but it's probably the genuinely caring, warm, service which will bring you back again and again.

points_of_interest.name: Au Banquier
points_of_interest.description: Decor is minimalist, but the northern African cuisine of this place is delicious.

points_of_interest.name: Bang!
points_of_interest.description: Offers a selection of first class meats from all over the world (From American Angus and French Aubrac to Argentine Angus and Simmental from Bavaria), along with natural wines. The result is a friendly, warm space to meet friends, enjoy delicious food and converse against a soothing musical background of jazz and pop.

points_of_interest.name: Bistrot des Dames
points_of_interest.description: The romantic bistro offers simple seasonal plates and has a charming garden in summer time.

points_of_interest.name: Chez Gladines
points_of_interest.description: Big Basque salads and a lot of ambiance in this moderately low-budget restaurant. This place is almost always crowded on Saturday nights.

points_of_interest.name: Aux Comptoirs des Indes
points_of_interest.description: Indian restaurant.
points_of_interest.address: 50 rue de la Fontaine Au Roi

points_of_interest.name: Le Cambodge
points_of_interest.description: A small and charming restaurant with delicious Cambodian offerings. Order your selections by writing on the note card provided. Artistically inclined diners can see their orders memorialized as artwork on the walls.

points_of_interest.name: La Can Tinh
points_of_interest.description: Vietnamese restaurant.

points_of_interest.name: Avé Maria
points_of_interest.description: Brazilian favela chic. The friendly folks who run this place have been hosting Brasilian dance nights at various venues around town. But don't just come in to check out the posters; stay a while for the fantastic '''vegetarian friendly''' South American and international cuisine at reasonable prices.

points_of_interest.name: Chez Prune
points_of_interest.description: Primarily a drinking establishment, but serves food as well. The cheese plate, which is served with bread and fruit, is particularly good. Often quite crowded with locals. Waitstaff not necessarily proficient in English.

points_of_interest.name: Café de la Musique
points_of_interest.description: Its varied selection of music is what draws the crowds here en masse, at any given night you're likely to hear soulful jazz tunes, or a hip DJ spinning robotic techno. Under chef Alain Podou's watch, the food here is sophisticated, yet light, think lobster-studded risotto and brochettes of shrimp with spinach. Highly recommended.

points_of_interest.name: Jaipur
points_of_interest.description: The brothers who operate this Indian/Mexican restaurant are actually from Sri Lanka, but that doesn't seem to impact their ability to deliver on both of their favourite ethnic cuisines. When asked why Mexican, the youngest of the three (and the usual waiter) explained "because we like it". You will too.

points_of_interest.name: Soya Cantine Bio
points_of_interest.description: A true organic, vegetarian restaurant, and a good one. The tiny bit of preciousness about the place is more than overwhelmed by the laid-back atmosphere and warm welcome. There are daily specials, but the couscous-soy will keep you coming back. Also check out the lunch buffet, but maybe not if you're counting calories because it's hard not to go up for thirds.

points_of_interest.name: Bouillon Chartier
points_of_interest.description: Since 1896. Menu changes regularly. Historic building and interior. Classically dressed servers. Satisfying, cheap food. Traditional, representative French cooking; don't expect innovative, haute cuisine. Usually the line is bigger than the reputation. Continuous service without reservations.

points_of_interest.name: Julien
points_of_interest.description: The original 1890 decor of this Parisian dining classic is a mix of Cuban mahogany and Art Nouveau paintings and fixtures - an atmospheric treat. The cuisine is mostly south-western French: lots of foie gras and the speciality, ''cassoulet d'oie'' (goose in white beans).

points_of_interest.name: Caffe Panem
points_of_interest.description: Pasta and bruschetta featured in this small family-run café that serves good and cheap coffee (90 cents for an espresso cup), croissants and great home made sweets such as tiramisu (standard and with chestnut purée). Evenings feature pasta and toasted bruschetta.

points_of_interest.name: Restaurant La Strasbourgeoise
points_of_interest.description: One of the good "choucroutes" in Paris, with nice décor.

points_of_interest.name: Niv's
points_of_interest.description: A Franco-Italian bistro with high-end Italian dishes.

points_of_interest.name: Sala Thaï
points_of_interest.description: Delicious Thai food.
points_of_interest.address: 13, rue des Frères d'Astier de la Vigerie

points_of_interest.name: Banoi
points_of_interest.description: Tiny Vietnamese restaurant featuring fresh authentic Vietnamese spring rolls, soup and sandwich banh-mi. Mix and match tapas. Vietnamese drinks and beer. They do a huge take-out and delivery business.

points_of_interest.name: Camille
points_of_interest.description: Fantastic fresh French food. It is worth the wait.

points_of_interest.name: Sésame
points_of_interest.description: A cute and comfortable little bistro with numerous vegetarian options, including an awesome vegi lasagne. The stove is warm and the staff are full of smiles.

points_of_interest.name: Le Réfuge
points_of_interest.description: The drinks speciality here is an assortment of flavoured vodkas. The food, served in the spacious seating area in back is traditional, including a huge cheese platter.

points_of_interest.name: Le Temps des Cerises
points_of_interest.description: If you are looking for quality French food and a large choice of good and affordable wine, this is the place to go. This is what we can call a restaurant populaire (as opposed to other posh and expensive places around) with a friendly staff, a very nice atmosphere, no way to reserve a table, just show up and the patron will find a place for you (arrive before 20:00 if you don't want to queue up, especially at weekends), turn off your mobile phone or you will be kicked out! The Boudin à la Normande (blood sausage) is a must and you can also get very decent goose liver and other French specialities such as Salade de Museau.

points_of_interest.name: Clown Bar
points_of_interest.description: The food served in this absolutely beautiful room is classic French. The decor is classic Circus, which makes sense since it's just two doors north of the building which has traditionally housed circuses passing through during the winter.

points_of_interest.name: Chez Janou
points_of_interest.description: Chez Janou has such a pretty location that it's worth an evening visit just for that. But the food and atmosphere are also amazing. Vegetarians be warned, the tortellini is ''not'' the token veggie dish; there isn't one.

points_of_interest.name: La Vigne Saint Laurent
points_of_interest.description: Tiny wine bar, good choice of classic country food (beautiful charcuterie) & good choice of reasonably priced wines.

points_of_interest.name: L'Assiette
points_of_interest.description: Reservation recommended.
points_of_interest.hours: Closed M Tu, 3 weeks in Aug

points_of_interest.name: Terra Rosse
points_of_interest.description: Terre Rosse Pizza Authentic Italian pizzeria, restaurant and deli, The chef's offerings are very authentic and fresh. Top selection of pizza, antipasti, pasti and piatti caldi. Spanish and Italian deli meats are featured. The Italian staff are warm and helpful.

points_of_interest.name: Khrishna Bhavan
points_of_interest.description: Serves excellent Indian vegetarian dishes from the southern state of Tamil Nadu and Sri Lanka. First timers can consider trying the Thali, a combo platter consisting of steamed rice served with 5 different curries.

points_of_interest.name: Blend Hamburger
points_of_interest.description: French meat with home made ketchup.

points_of_interest.name: Café Cannibale
points_of_interest.description: Very chic bar and café with DJ sets weekends; live music Friday and Saturday. Oysters direct from producers, seared octopus, ''chartouterie'', steaks and fish. Wide selection of wine, beer, whiskies and cocktails. Happy Hour 16:00-20:00. Brunch Sundays.

points_of_interest.name: Cour de Rohan
points_of_interest.description: It would be an ordinary tea-room if the Cour de Rohan weren't such a magical little spot.

points_of_interest.name: Saravanaa Bhavan
points_of_interest.description: South Indian vegetarian chain restaurant.

points_of_interest.name: Le Bougainville
points_of_interest.description: This comfy little bar offers home cooking from the Auvergne region, and after-work drinks for the financial set.
points_of_interest.hours: M-Sa 19:00-21:00, but food is only served at lunch from 11:30 to 15:30

points_of_interest.name: Le Bar à Soupes
points_of_interest.description: A large selection of different soups (including some vegetarian options). There are a few new ones each day. All served with your choice of an equally wide selection of breads and cheeses.

points_of_interest.name: Juste
points_of_interest.description: Super fresh, simply served and cheap seafood by a fish monger / restaurateur. Takeout, Outdoor Seating. Arrive at noon to avoid lines. Review the menu on-line before arriving to order quickly at the counter. Raw oysters, bulots (sea snails), ''pinces de tourteau'' (crab claws). 50cl of house wine at a special Friday price. There are plenty of paper napkins and a bucket in the center table hole for shells.

points_of_interest.name: Bodhi Vegan
points_of_interest.description: Cheap and cheerful South-East Asian vegan fare run by a Vietnamese sect. The menu is pretty gigantic so you'll be very spoilt for choice!

points_of_interest.name: Grillé
points_of_interest.description: A fast food restaurant that makes a "healthy" version of kebab (good herbs, better salad). Three cooks, Marie Carcassonne, Hugo Desnoyer, and Frédéric Peneau worked on this creation.

points_of_interest.name: l'Ébauchoir
points_of_interest.description: A typical restaurant of the bo-bo (bourgeois - bohème) population of this district. Good traditional cooking with mid-range prices.

points_of_interest.name: Chez Marianne
points_of_interest.description: At the corner of rue des Hospitalières-Saint Gervais, and the rue Rosiers, Chez Marianne—like the many falafel stands in the ''Pletzle''—serves excellent sandwiches out of a walk up window, but unlike some of the others also has an attractive dining room and a truly lovely terrace where you can enjoy a full range of Jewish/middle-eastern dishes.

points_of_interest.name: Le Café des Anges
points_of_interest.description: Good variety of French café dishes with a few oriental offerings such as Bõ Bun. Quite a diverse menu. Some vegetarian, pasta and fish selections among the beef, pork and chicken dishes. Salads are fresh. Cocktails, beer, wine, whiskies, rums, cognac... the whole kitchen sink.

points_of_interest.name: Tien Hiang
points_of_interest.description: East/South-East Asian vegetarian restaurant. The mock duck (''canard laqué'') is to die for.

points_of_interest.name: Rani Mahal
points_of_interest.description: This Indian restaurant is raved about by vegetarians. It serves meat as well.

points_of_interest.name: Refuge
points_of_interest.description: This charming storefront bistro offers an adventurous take on traditional French cooking, and with a couple of good selections for '''vegetarians''', including a €12 vegetarian ''menu''. The indoor vineyard decor appeals for its artsy clutter; the only indications that the owner and chef is a former rugby star being the newspaper clipping on the wall and the almost hidden world championship medal behind the bar.

points_of_interest.name: Tribeca
points_of_interest.description: A very nice terrasse on the rue Cler (pedestrian area). The food is simple, but good and reasonably cheap.

points_of_interest.name: La Perla
points_of_interest.description: Good Mexican food to be had within a stone's throw of the Ile de St. Louis. They mix a decent margarita too!

points_of_interest.name: Bistro Paul Bert
points_of_interest.description: A ''most classic'' Parisian bistro serving many first-time visitors to Paris and others who return. Appealing dishes are well plated and served, reliable and consistent from starter to dessert. This bistro is not a ''hidden gem'' as its well deserved reputation is widely known by tourists. Nevertheless if reservations are made in advance, seats are available and service remains excellent. The lunch menu is a remarkable value. Wine is diverse and served by the bottle or glass.

points_of_interest.name: Yugaraj
points_of_interest.description: A mostly northern Indian ''carte'' with lots of '''Vegetarian''' options. It seems a popular restaurant so be sure to book in advance if you are going in a large group.

points_of_interest.name: Jah Jah By Le Tricycle
points_of_interest.description: Hipstery vegan restaurant with a slight Caribbean twist.

points_of_interest.name: Café Etienne Marcel
points_of_interest.description: A Costes brothers creation but with lower prices than many of their other restaurants. The Etienne Marcel combines a creative menu with hip interior design and hip musical ambiance. '''Vegetarians:''' The crispy risotto balls (''risotto croustillant'') are amazing, and pretty much impossible to make at home.

points_of_interest.name: 58 Tour Eiffel
points_of_interest.description: The restaurant in the first floor of the Eiffel Tower. One pays of course for the view, not so much for the food.

points_of_interest.name: Flunch
points_of_interest.description: Self-service restaurant, right next to the Pompidou centre. Steaks etc. are cooked fresh when ordered, other food is pre-cooked and there is a microwave in the table area should you need to heat anything up. A chance to try authentic French food at cheap prices. Just one minus - there is a free water and ice dispender next to the microwave, in the table area, AFTER you've paid and probably bought another drink! Price - e.g. one couscous, one steak with mixed vegetables, two pieces of bread, €16.50.

points_of_interest.name: l'Arbuci
points_of_interest.description: A nice bistro with consistently favorable reviews and a jazz club downstairs.

points_of_interest.name: Daily Syrien Veggie
points_of_interest.description: Vegetarian Levantine cuisine.

points_of_interest.name: Le Picotin
points_of_interest.description: An excellent find in a quiet back street. Good value food, with a selection wide enough to offer a good choice whilst allowing the chef to concentrate on perfecting a small number of dishes. Warm, friendly welcome and faultless service.

points_of_interest.name: Gâteaux Thoumieux
points_of_interest.description: Chef patisser Ludovic Chaussard, who had previously worked with Alain Ducasse is designing the cakes.

points_of_interest.name: O Corcovado Marais
points_of_interest.description: This Brazilian restaurant serves authentic food.

points_of_interest.name: Drouant
points_of_interest.description: Anthony Clémot runs this French kitchen.

points_of_interest.name: Creperie Beaubourg
points_of_interest.description: The restaurant serves salty "galette" and sweet "crepes" with cider for a reasonable price. In summertime one can sit nicely outdoor.

points_of_interest.name: Kootchi
points_of_interest.description: Afghan cuisine, small and cosy, food is not too spicy, good value for money.

points_of_interest.name: Le Duc
points_of_interest.hours: Closed Su M, 3 weeks in Aug, 24 Dec-3 Jan

points_of_interest.name: Place du Marché Notre Dame
points_of_interest.description: Place du Marché Notre Dame (the main market square): If you're looking for more of an authentic French experience, the Place du Marché is a wonderful option. It is an outdoor market that offers only the freshest foods one can find. Here you can find vegetables, pizzas, fish, meats, fruits, and cheese. The outdoor market operates on Tuesday, Friday and Sunday mornings and starts winding down around 13:00. Sunday is the busiest day here. There are also sit-down restaurants in the market.
points_of_interest.address: 16 Rue Du Maréchal Foch, 78000 Versailles, France

points_of_interest.name: Le Loir dans la Théière
points_of_interest.description: A highly recommended and quaint little tea shop, well worth a visit especially for brunch, which at €15.50 is a great value for the quantity, quality, and ambience. The cakes are huge, but if one is too late they might already be gone.

points_of_interest.name: Polidor
points_of_interest.description: Since 1845, but don't let that fool you, the carte is quite up-to-date. Vegetarians can assemble a fine pasta-centered meal ''à la carte''.

points_of_interest.name: Le Petit Prince de Paris
points_of_interest.description: A notably Parisian restaurant experience, but with friendly and warm service. Traditional French food (try the duck with feathers) and deliciously complicated sauces. Relaxed and uncrowded, but reserve in the morning for a weekend night. Reasonable wine selection.

points_of_interest.name: Pain Vin Fromages
points_of_interest.description: It's all about cheese, with a selection of Swiss dishes, and others.

points_of_interest.name: Nawab
points_of_interest.description: This Indian and Pakistani restaurant is usually packed especially for lunch so be sure to call ahead and reserve a table. One of the reasons is that if you ask them to spice it up "like in Pakistan" they actually will.

points_of_interest.name: Ze Kitchen Gallery
points_of_interest.description: A generally well-regarded fusion restaurant with another Guy Savoy trained chef. You should reserve if at all possible.

points_of_interest.name: Le Colimaçon
points_of_interest.description: Cozy, charming space. Attentive service. French cuisine with daily specials.

points_of_interest.name: Les Bouquinistes
points_of_interest.description: A favorite among the many art dealers in the neighborhood, and a respected platform for up-and-coming chef Magdala de Beaulieu-Caussimon. Owned by Guy Savoy.

points_of_interest.name: Bibimpap
points_of_interest.description: Korean restaurant.

points_of_interest.name: L'Ambroisie
points_of_interest.description: In the aristocratic décors of the 18th century the chef Bernard Pacaud and his son prepare modern and refined food. The "tarte au chocolat" is surreal.

points_of_interest.name: Brasserie Bofinger
points_of_interest.description: A beautiful, historical ''décor'' in the ''Art Nouveau'' style (see the ceiling upstairs); good Alsatian cuisine : ''choucroute'', kuglopf, etc, plus good classic ''cuisine de brasserie''.

points_of_interest.name: Dans les Landes
points_of_interest.description: A tapas bar with food from southeast France is the new place of the rugby champion and chef Julien Duboué.

points_of_interest.name: Le Georges
points_of_interest.description: On the top floor of the Centre Georges Pompidou, the restaurant Georges offers a panoramic view of Paris. Serves modern French food with classic desserts like "blancs en neige".

points_of_interest.name: Carette
points_of_interest.description: This Pâtisserie and Salon de thé also has great food. The salads are amazing, and there is delicious cakes for dessert.

points_of_interest.name: Amorino
points_of_interest.description: The oldest of the many boutiques operated by this ''gelato'' (Italian ice cream) maker.

points_of_interest.name: Glacier Berthillon
points_of_interest.description: The most renowned French sorbet has his little tea shop since 1954. The wait in the queue is definitely worth it, also with some luck the queue isn't that big. On the corner, the queue for takeaway is usually bigger but, of course, faster. Taking the ice to the Seine is, of course. a possible option.

points_of_interest.name: Chez Francis
points_of_interest.description: View of the Eiffel Tower.

points_of_interest.name: La Petaudiere
points_of_interest.description: Piano bar. Tasty food, nice ambience, and excellent good piano music (prepare some coins for the pianist).

points_of_interest.name: Pozetto
points_of_interest.description: Little shop that's both a café and sells Italian ice cream. The ice cream flavours vary according to the season.

points_of_interest.name: Diep
points_of_interest.description: Thai, Chinese, and Indonesian. Vegetarian friendly.

points_of_interest.name: Le Refuge des Fondues
points_of_interest.description: Fondue restaurant for young people: menu for €17, including wine served in a baby bottle, appetizers, the fondue itself (cheese or meat), and dessert.

points_of_interest.name: Kokohana
points_of_interest.description: Teppanyaki Two chefs battle against each other in a spectacular performance of chopping, slicing, sauteing everything from scallops to foie gras. The food is average, but the presentation is well worth it.

points_of_interest.name: Café Zinc-Zen
points_of_interest.description: Small café with 2 seating areas - seats in the windows and a darker back room. Elegant but not expensive, great lunches/dinners, and superb ''crème brûlée'' for a night cap with coffee.

points_of_interest.name: Villa Spicy
points_of_interest.description: Warm and peaceful close to the Champs-Élysées serving an organic detox menu.

points_of_interest.name: Choux d'enfer
points_of_interest.description: Street food + haute pâtisserie française = sweet food in a designer "kiosk".
points_of_interest.address: Intersection rue Jean Rey and quai Branly

points_of_interest.name: Markotte
points_of_interest.description: Organic sandwiches, salads and soups

points_of_interest.name: L'Astrance
points_of_interest.description: 3 Michelin stars. Considered one of the best restaurants of Paris. Do not go there, if you are hungry and want to get full.

points_of_interest.name: Hokkaido
points_of_interest.description: Japanese cuisine

points_of_interest.name: Hanawa
points_of_interest.description: Great sushi in a nice atmosphere, extensive menu.

points_of_interest.name: Café Beaugrenelle
points_of_interest.description: Brasserie on lively Place Charles Michels

points_of_interest.name: Ladurée
points_of_interest.description: Famous for their macaroon cookies, which come in over 15 different flavours. Expensive, but an experience. There is a tea room, a bar, and a restaurant. You can also order baked goods to go, in fancy boxes and bags.

points_of_interest.name: Le Café du Commerce
points_of_interest.description: Authentic French food and ambience. (Be sure to go to number 51 rue du Commerce, as there is another place nearby with a similar name.)

points_of_interest.name: La Plage Parisienne
points_of_interest.description: Along the River, rather pleasant. They also offer cocktails at their bar.

points_of_interest.name: Lou pasta
points_of_interest.description: Italian cuisine

points_of_interest.name: Le Volant
points_of_interest.description: The Basque restaurant excels in meat. If you are lucky the soup of the day is the "soupe au marron". There is a possibility to get a 3-course evening menu including entrée, plat and dessert. The home-made "mousse au chocolat" is really big. Also the bistro is generous on the sides: Usually one gets "purée", rice and polenta. Inside the restaurant, the former tricot of the famous French football player Zinedine Zidane is on display. As the small place fills rapidly, reservation is recommended.

points_of_interest.name: Au Roi du café
points_of_interest.description: Belle-Epoque decor, true bisto spirit

points_of_interest.name: Lemoni Café
points_of_interest.description: Lémoni Hérold Small plates, also for take-away.

points_of_interest.name: Bermuda Onion
points_of_interest.description: Eat or drink. View of the river even better in the evening.
points_of_interest.address: Centre commercial Beaugrenelle, Ilôt Verseau - 3rd floor, 7 rue Linois, 75015

points_of_interest.name: Chez Denise
points_of_interest.description: La Tour de Montlhéry Small, owner-operated bistro with traditional French country food in a nearly rustic setting. As such it's not exactly veggie-friendly.

points_of_interest.name: Eclectic
points_of_interest.description: Brasserie fashion. Decor Tom Dixon

points_of_interest.name: À la Cloche des Halles
points_of_interest.description: A la cloche des Halles The bell no longer rings, but the brasserie-restaurant still has the flair from the old little bars from the good old times named "troquets".

points_of_interest.name: Le Baribal
points_of_interest.description: 40-year-old neighborhood bistro run by Louisette and her partner George. Traditional simple fare.

points_of_interest.name: La Robe et le Palais
points_of_interest.description: Small restaurant serving mostly tasty Basque food. Fantastic choice of wines.

points_of_interest.name: Frame Brasserie
points_of_interest.description: Californian-style restaurant : a new take on the traditional Parisian brasserie.

points_of_interest.name: Café Marly
points_of_interest.description: Part of the ''Grand Louvre'' redevelopment. Café Marly was opened in 1994 and is on the balcony on the northern terrace of the Cour Napoléon. Patrons can enjoy direct views of the Louvre Pyramid while sitting back in comfortable chairs, watching tourists stroll by.
points_of_interest.address: 93, rue de Rivoli / cour Napoléon du Louvre

points_of_interest.name: Macéo
points_of_interest.description: What was once just a great wine bar with decent food has become a must-visit restaurant with the addition of star chef Thierry Bourbonnais. Second-empire atmosphere with fantastic food.

points_of_interest.name: Afaria
points_of_interest.description: This Basque restaurant mainly serves meat or some fancy tapas on the bar.

points_of_interest.name: Mystery Cuisine
points_of_interest.description: The restaurant serves fusion cuisine inspired by French Vietnamese meals in an atmosphere perfect for couples.

points_of_interest.name: Le Beurre Noisette
points_of_interest.description: The restaurant of Thierry Bianqui offers interesting food all year long. Remember to reserve in advance for this cosy place. The menu are written on chalk boards and they can arrange custom demands for vegetarians. The desserts are recommended.

points_of_interest.name: Le Ciel de Paris
points_of_interest.description: 360° view.

points_of_interest.name: Restaurant Benkay
points_of_interest.description: Japanese cuisine. Great views.
points_of_interest.address: Hotel Novotel Front de Seine Grenelle, 61 quai de Grenelle

points_of_interest.name: le Quinzième
points_of_interest.description: The restaurant, lies alongside Parc André Citroën. By 2005, wide audiences were following Cyril Lignac on TV as he opened his own restaurant, Le Quinzième, on the popular French series “Oui Chef!” Here he brilliantly demonstrated his know-how and good taste, producing refined and slightly off-beat cooking, always made with his trademark top quality ingredients.

points_of_interest.name: Palais des Glaces
points_of_interest.description: Grand palace with two theatres, the Palais des Glaces (Palace of Mirrors) features two shows, often two comics, simultaneously, and sometimes shows for children.

points_of_interest.name: Promenade Canal St. Martin
points_of_interest.description: Enjoy a leisurely stroll along the water's edge while viewing amazing sunsets over the canal. Linger over a coffee and tuck into a pastry while feeling that you are experiencing the true Paris.

points_of_interest.name: Le Palais des Congrès de Paris
points_of_interest.description: A convention centre.
points_of_interest.address: 8 Place De La Porte Maillot, 75017 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Buttes-Chaumont
points_of_interest.description: Popular city escape for nature lovers and walkers who can spend hours wandering around this lush green paradise. Biggest, most hilly, and least touristy park in Paris, here you still find a real Parisian atmosphere, far from the crowds at the city's centre (it still is crowded in summer during weekends as many Parisians come to sunbathe on the grass). Climb on top of the hill and overlook the north of Paris with the Montmartre hill right in front of you. The park has an almost enchanted feel, with its waterfall (water is pumped from the nearby canal Saint Martin), stream, lake and its steep cliff, topped with a "temple" which can only be reached via a suspension bridge. A true oasis indeed

points_of_interest.name: Bataclan
points_of_interest.description: Ba-ta-clan Attend a concert or have a drink at this popular café-concert music hall inaugurated in 1865 featuring brightly painted Chinese architecture. Always attracting a young crowd, the Bataclan has regained the splendor it once enjoyed and now books many emerging hip and rock acts. The is café on the ground floor is outstanding, perhaps even better than in the old days. A memorial honoring those 90 persons killed in a terrorist attack on 13 Nov 2015 is across the street in a small park.

points_of_interest.name: les Grands Boulevards
points_of_interest.description: Boulevards of Paris Go shopping at the ''grands magasins'' (department stores).

points_of_interest.name: Théâtre national de l'Opéra-Comique
points_of_interest.description: National Opéra Comic Theatre The théâtre national de l'Opéra-Comique (National Opéra Comic Theatre) is an opera company and opera house.

points_of_interest.name: Olympia
points_of_interest.description: Olympia Hall A music hall, which houses concerts for an older crowd. Be sure to tip the usher €2 or so.

points_of_interest.name: Cafe Philo in English
points_of_interest.description: Cafe Philo in English meets on the first Wednesday of each month upstairs at the famous Café de Flore. Everyone is invited. You don't have to be knowledgeable about philosophy. Meetings begin with a two round voting process to determine a topic. The topic is discussed for two hours.

points_of_interest.name: Le parcours des années 30
points_of_interest.description: Self-guided walking tour of Boulogne-Billancourt's 1930s architectural heritage starting from Porte de Saint-Cloud and ending at Jean Jaurès metro stations.
points_of_interest.address: 16 Place De La Porte De Saint-Cloud, 75016 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Théâtre Édouard VII
points_of_interest.description: French theatre, for those with command of the language.

points_of_interest.name: La Seine Musicale
points_of_interest.description: Classical music venue on the Ile Seguin.

points_of_interest.name: Lido de Paris
points_of_interest.description: Le Lido The most famous cabaret celebrates spectacle revues. Children ages 4 and older are welcome. Casual elegant dress code. Coat and tie appreciated. Shorts, Bermuda shorts, athletic clothing and tennis shoes are not allowed.

points_of_interest.name: Le Moulin Rouge
points_of_interest.description: With two shows a night, this turn-of-the-20th century burlesque palace offers a big production choreographed dance show interspersed with comedians, jugglers, and magicians. The show is more than bilingual, actually playing up the U.S. 4th infantry's involvement in the ''libération'' for the sake of the large number of Americans in the audience. If you want to spend more you can have dinner there. Is the ''Moulin Rouge'' a tourist trap? Well... it was meant to be one in the first place, so the experience is genuine.

points_of_interest.name: Comédie Francaise
points_of_interest.description: Théâtre-Français, La maison de Molière The theatre is one of the rare state theatres in France. The company's primary venue is the Salle Richelieu. It was enlarged and modified in the 1800s, then rebuilt in 1900 after a severe fire. The played repertoires sum to around 3,000 works.

points_of_interest.name: Ô Chateau, Paris Wine Tasting
points_of_interest.description: Discover French wines with a native French sommelier. Informative, relaxing, and fun. In English in a beautiful Parisian loft.

points_of_interest.name: Aquaboulevard
points_of_interest.description: Biggest swimming pool and recreational center inside Paris.

points_of_interest.name: Môm'artre
points_of_interest.description: An arts centre intended primarily for kids (''Môme'' means kid) the Môm'artre features workshops for kids and adults, hosted by neighborhood artists.

points_of_interest.name: Ballon de Paris
points_of_interest.description: Paris Balloon or Ballon Generali Get a unique bird's eye view of Paris on board an air-balloon, from an altitude of 150 m.

points_of_interest.name: Bois de Boulogne
points_of_interest.description:
Bois de Boulogne is a sprawling urban oasis located on the western edge of Paris' 16th arrondissement, near the suburb of Boulogne-Billancourt. Spanning an impressive 8.45 square kilometers, it is one of the largest parks in the city, offering a peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle of metropolitan life. For visitors looking to explore its vast grounds, the park provides ample opportunities for walking, picnicking, and enjoying outdoor activities like cycling and horseback riding. Its serene lakes and lush greenery make it a popular spot for both locals and travelers seeking relaxation.

In addition to its natural beauty, Bois de Boulogne is home to several cultural attractions, including the Jardin des Serres d'Auteuil, a stunning botanical garden with beautiful greenhouses. The park also hosts various events and activities throughout the year, making it a vibrant destination for all kinds of interests.

While the park is a tranquil retreat during the day, it transforms at night into a different kind of destination, attracting a diverse crowd. This duality makes Bois de Boulogne a fascinating and multifaceted place, reflecting the dynamic spirit of Paris itself.

points_of_interest.name: Swim at Piscine Molitor
points_of_interest.description: Piscines Auteuil-Molitor A stunning classical swimming pool complex. The pool is known for its Art Deco designs and the popular introduction of the bikini by Louis Réard on 5 July 1946. The character ''Pi Patel'' in the novel/movie ''Life of Pi'' was named after this pool. Nowadays it houses a 5-star hotel as well. Access for non-hotel guests is very pricey — you must book a spa package for €230.

points_of_interest.name: Maison de la culture du Japon
points_of_interest.description: The location hosts several expositions, a library and a concert hall.

points_of_interest.name: French Open
points_of_interest.description: The second of each year's four Grand Slam tennis tournaments is held over two weeks in late May and early June at Stade Roland Garros in the Bois de Boulogne. The venue is open for tours year-round whenever tournaments are not scheduled, and the French Tennis Federation operates its national museum of the sport, the Tenniseum [http://www.fft.fr/site-tenniseum/en/] {{dead link|August 2018|December 2020}}, at the site.

points_of_interest.name: Tapovan Paris
points_of_interest.description: This Ayurvedic centre offers treatment and professional training in various Ayurvedic healing arts: hatha & nada yoga, reiki, Ayurvedic massage, reflexology, oil treatments (e.g. Shirodhara).

points_of_interest.name: Paris Saint-Germain
points_of_interest.description: PSG play soccer in the top-tier Ligue 1. They often win it and qualify for European tournaments. Parc des Princes stadium (capacity 48,000) is south side of Bois de Boulogne. The club name derives from St-Germain-en-Laye 20 km west, not the city centre district of Saint-Germain-des-Prés.
points_of_interest.address: Parc des Princes, 24 Rue du Commandant Guilbaud

points_of_interest.name: Tour Montparnasse, Top deck
points_of_interest.description: Panoramic view of Paris from the 56th floor.

points_of_interest.name: Stade Français
points_of_interest.description: Rugby club in the Top 14, and a perennial title contender. Stade's traditional home ground of Stade Jean-Bouin, across the street from Parc des Princes, reopened in 2013 after a major renovation. Ticket information is available [https://billetterie.stade.fr/uk online in English].

points_of_interest.name: Stade de France
points_of_interest.description: France's national stadium has a capacity of 81,338, and hosts concerts and various events. Some football club teams sometimes play here when their home stadium is unavailable.

points_of_interest.name: Maison Européene de la Photographie
points_of_interest.description: La MEP Important center for contemporary photography with a large exposition area having three or four major expositions per year dedicated to contemporary photography. Housed in an updated ''hôtel particulier'' built in 1706. There is a large library, auditorium and café. Their archive houses over twenty thousand works of art. Admission is free every Wednesday from 17:00 to 20:00.

points_of_interest.name: Avenue des Champs-Elysées
points_of_interest.description:
The Avenue des Champs-Élysées is an avenue in the 8th arrondissement of Paris, France, 1.9 kilometres long and 70 metres wide, running between the Place de la Concorde in the east and the Place Charles de Gaulle in the west, where the Arc de Triomphe is located. It is known for its theatres, cafés, and luxury shops; as the finish of the Tour de France cycling race; and for its annual Bastille Day military parade.

The name is French for the Elysian Fields, the place for dead heroes in Greek mythology. It has been described as the "most beautiful avenue in the whole world".

points_of_interest.name: La Bibliothèque Nationale de France
points_of_interest.description:
The Bibliothèque nationale de France is the national library of France, located in Paris on two main sites, Richelieu and François-Mitterrand. It is the national repository of all that is published in France. Some of its extensive collections, including books and manuscripts but also precious objects and artworks, are on display at the BnF Museum on the Richelieu site.

The National Library of France is a public establishment under the supervision of the Ministry of Culture. Its mission is to constitute collections, especially the copies of works published in France that must, by law, be deposited there, conserve them, and make them available to the public. It produces a reference catalogue, cooperates with other national and international establishments, as well as participates in research programs.

points_of_interest.name: Eiffel Tower
points_of_interest.description:
The Eiffel Tower is a wrought-iron lattice tower on the Champ de Mars in Paris, France. It is named after the engineer Gustave Eiffel, whose company designed and built the tower from 1887 to 1889.

Locally nicknamed "La dame de fer" , it was constructed as the centerpiece of the 1889 World's Fair, and to crown the centennial anniversary of the French Revolution. Although initially criticised by some of France's leading artists and intellectuals for its design, it has since become a global cultural icon of France and one of the most recognisable structures in the world. The tower received 5,889,000 visitors in 2022. The Eiffel Tower is the most visited monument with an entrance fee in the world: 6.91 million people ascended it in 2015. It was designated a monument historique in 1964, and was named part of a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1991.

The tower is 330 metres tall, about the same height as an 81-storey building, and the tallest structure in Paris. Its base is square, measuring 125 metres on each side. During its construction, the Eiffel Tower surpassed the Washington Monument to become the tallest human-made structure in the world, a title it held for 41 years until the Chrysler Building in New York City was finished in 1930. It was the first structure in the world to surpass both the 200-metre and 300-metre mark in height. Due to the addition of a broadcasting aerial at the top of the tower in 1957, it is now taller than the Chrysler Building by 5.2 metres . Excluding transmitters, the Eiffel Tower is the second tallest free-standing structure in France after the Millau Viaduct.

The tower has three levels for visitors, with restaurants on the first and second levels. The top level's upper platform is 276 m above the ground—the highest observation deck accessible to the public in the European Union. Tickets can be purchased to ascend by stairs or lift to the first and second levels. The climb from ground level to the first level is over 300 steps, as is the climb from the first level to the second, making the entire ascent a 600-step climb. Although there is a staircase to the top level, it is usually accessible only by lift. On this top, third level is a private apartment built for Gustave Eiffel's personal use. He decorated it with furniture by Jean Lachaise and invited friends such as Thomas Edison.

points_of_interest.name: Château de Versailles
points_of_interest.description:
Nestled in the heart of France, the Château de Versailles stands as a testament to the country's rich history and architectural brilliance. This iconic estate is a must-visit destination for anyone drawn to grandeur, art, and the elegance of a bygone era. As you approach the château, its imposing facade, adorned with intricate stone carvings and gilded details, sets the tone for an unforgettable experience.

Step inside, and you're transported into a world of opulence. The Hall of Mirrors, with its dazzling array of mirrors and crystal chandeliers, is a sight to behold. Each room is a masterpiece, showcasing exquisite furnishings and artworks that reflect the lavish lifestyle of French monarchy. The Royal Chapel, with its soaring vaulted ceiling, is another highlight, offering a glimpse into the spiritual life of the royal family.

The true magic of Versailles, however, lies in its expansive gardens. Stroll through the meticulously manicured lawns, where perfectly aligned trees and vibrant flowerbeds create a symphony of color and texture. The Orangery, with its citrus trees, and the Grand Canal, where you can enjoy a leisurely boat ride, are just a few of the many treasures waiting to be discovered. Don’t miss the stunning fountains, which come alive with choreographed water displays, especially during the summer months.

Beyond the main palace, the estate boasts charming additions like the Trianon palaces and the Hamlet, offering a more intimate glimpse into the private lives of the royals. These lesser-known areas are perfect for those seeking a peaceful retreat from the crowds.

Throughout the year, Versailles hosts various cultural events and seasonal activities, from classical music concerts to ice skating in the winter. Whether you're exploring the palace, wandering the gardens, or simply soaking in the atmosphere, every moment at Château de Versailles is a step back in time. Plan to spend a full day here to fully appreciate the depth of history, art, and natural beauty that this incredible attraction has to offer.
points_of_interest.address: 1 Rue Robert De Cotte, 78000 Versailles, France
points_of_interest.hours: Nov-Mar: Tu-Su 09:00-1730, Apr-Oct: Tu-Su 09:00-18:30; closed Jan 1, May 1 and Dec 25

points_of_interest.name: Père-Lachaise Cemetery
points_of_interest.description:
Père-Lachaise Cemetery is one of the most visited and iconic cemeteries in the world, offering a fascinating glimpse into history, art, and culture. Located in Paris, this vast and picturesque site is renowned for its elaborate tombstones and monuments, which line winding pathways and avenues. Visitors can explore thousands of graves, each telling a unique story of the lives they commemorate.

What truly sets Père-Lachaise apart is its association with some of the most influential figures in history and the arts. The cemetery is the final resting place of luminaries such as Frédéric Chopin, the brilliant composer and pianist; Oscar Wilde, the celebrated author and wit; and Jim Morrison, the charismatic lead singer of The Doors. Other notable residents include French writer Honoré de Balzac, singer Edith Piaf, and playwright Molière. The cemetery also honors the likes of artists Eugène Delacroix and Georges Bizet, as well as writers Marcel Proust and Colette. These graves are not only tributes to their legacies but also draw visitors from around the globe.

A visit to Père-Lachaise Cemetery is as much about the living as it is about the deceased. The grounds are a peaceful retreat from the bustling city, with their ornate sculptures, shaded walkways, and historic charm. For those interested in history, art, or simply experiencing a unique side of Paris, Père-Lachaise Cemetery is a must-see destination. Be sure to bring a map, as the cemetery’s sprawling layout can make it easy to get lost in its beauty and significance.

points_of_interest.name: Albert Kahn Museum
points_of_interest.description: Musée Albert-Kahn The former estate of the Edwardian philanthropist Albert Kahn, consisting of a beautiful botanical garden and a museum of early 20th-century colour film/photography documenting various world cultures and remote tribes. While the museum is closed for renovation until Autumn 2021, the gardens remain open and entry is free on the first weekend of each month.

points_of_interest.name: Le Marais
points_of_interest.description: The Marais (Le Marais French: [lə maʁɛ] ; "the marsh") is a historic district in Paris, France. It spreads across parts of the 3rd and 4th arrondissements on the Rive Droite, or Right Bank, of the Seine. Having once been an aristocratic district, it is home to many buildings of historic and architectural importance. It lost its status as a fashionable district in the late 18th century, with only minor nobles calling the area home. After the French Revolution, the district fell into disrepair and was abandoned by nobility. After a long period of decay, the district has undergone transformation in recent years and is now once again amongst the more fashionable areas of Paris, known for its art galleries, upscale restaurants and museums.
points_of_interest.address: 20a Rue Des Francs Bourgeois, 75003 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Cirque d'Hiver
points_of_interest.description: Cirque d'Hiver, a historic venue in Paris, has hosted an array of performances since its opening in 1852. Designed by architect Jacques Ignace Hittorff, it was originally known as Cirque Napoléon and later renamed in 1870. This iconic space has been a backdrop for circuses, musical concerts, and even fashion shows, blending tradition with modern entertainment. Its rich history includes the renowned Pasdeloup orchestral concerts, which ran for over two decades. Located near the Filles du Calvaire metro station, Cirque d'Hiver remains a cultural gem, offering a glimpse into Paris' vibrant past while continuing to inspire audiences today.

points_of_interest.name: Notre-Dame de Pentecôte
points_of_interest.description:
Notre-Dame de Pentecôte is a church house of the diocese of Nanterre located in the heart of the business district of La Défense, in the Hauts-de-Seine, in the west suburbs of Paris.

It is not a parish per se, but a "church place", where people passing through can go from their workplace, to share how the Spirit acts in the workplace. It is intended to be a Christian and ecumenical presence in the middle of the Defense site by being primarily concerned with those who work thereA.
points_of_interest.address: 1 Rond-Point De La Défense, 92400 Puteaux, France

points_of_interest.name: Tour Montparnasse
points_of_interest.description: If the queues at the Eiffel Tower are just too much for you and your time is limited, consider a trip up the Montparnasse Tower. This is an office building with an observation and shopping area on the 56th floor, where the elevators stop, and an open viewing area on the roof. Arguably the view is better than from the Eiffel Tower: you are not so high up so things are more visible, and you can see the Eiffel Tower!

points_of_interest.name: Les Archives Nationales
points_of_interest.description: French Archives The Archives Nationales have one of the largest and most important archival collections in the world, a testimony to the very ancient nature of the French state which has been in existence for more than twelve centuries already.

points_of_interest.name: Musée Grévin
points_of_interest.description: The Musée Grévin, a must-visit wax museum, is nestled on the historic Grands Boulevards in Paris. As one of the oldest wax museums in Europe, it captivates visitors with its lifelike figures of famous personalities, blending history and modern culture seamlessly. While it has international outposts, the Paris location remains a timeless attraction, offering a unique and engaging experience for all who step inside.

points_of_interest.name: Sacré Coeur
points_of_interest.description:
Perched on a hill in the heart of Montmartre, the Basilique du Sacré Coeur is one of Paris's most iconic landmarks. This stunning white church, with its towering domes and intricate architecture, offers breathtaking views of the city. Built between 1875 and 1914, Sacré Coeur was constructed as a symbol of hope and reconciliation following the turmoil of the Franco-Prussian War and the Paris Commune. Its design, a mix of Romano-Byzantine styles, is both grand and graceful, making it a must-visit for architecture enthusiasts and history buffs alike.

Visitors can reach the top of the hill via a short but steep walk or by taking the Montmartre funicular, which runs regularly during the day. Once at the summit, the panoramic views of Paris from the dome and the square in front of the church are simply stunning, rivaling those from the Eiffel Tower. The square itself, 200 meters above sea level, is a popular spot to relax and take in the city's skyline.

While exploring the area, be mindful of a few local customs and safety tips. Photography inside the church is not allowed, so be respectful of the rules. Additionally, you may encounter street vendors or individuals approaching you near the lower steps. If you're uncomfortable, a firm but polite refusal is usually sufficient. Should you feel unsafe, don't hesitate to seek assistance from nearby authorities.

Sacré Coeur is more than just a beautiful building; it's a piece of Paris's history and a symbol of peace. Whether you're there to admire its architecture, enjoy the views, or simply soak in the atmosphere, it's an experience you won't want to miss.
points_of_interest.address: 4 Rue Du Cardinal Guibert, 75018 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Musée Delacroix
points_of_interest.description: Abbey of Saint-Germain-des-Prés The oldest church in Paris, founded in the year 542 by King Childebert. The church as it exists today dates mainly from the 11th century, the period in which it became the center of a powerful Benedictine abbey. The Revolution witnessed the suppression of the abbey in 1794, when most of the monastic buildings were put to the torch. Earlier, 318 priests had been hacked to death nearby by a mob on 3 September 1792. The church underwent significant restoration in the 19th century, ensuring the preservation of the building, which by that date represented a fascinating mix of styles: 6th century marble columns placed alongside Gothic vaults and supported by Romanesque arches. Famous burials within the church include René Descartes (philosopher), Nicolas Boileau (poet) and King John Casimir of Poland, who had become (in 1669, before his death) abbot of the church's monastery.

points_of_interest.name: Palais de Chaillot
points_of_interest.description: Great perspective on the Eiffel Tower and Left Bank from ''Place du Trocadéro'' in between the two buildings of the palais. Former location of the Palais du Trocadéro. It accommodates three museums, an aquarium, and the Theatre Nationale du Chaillot.

points_of_interest.name: la Bibliothèque Nationale de France
points_of_interest.description:
The Bibliothèque nationale de France, located in Paris, is a must-visit for book lovers and history enthusiasts. Spanning two sites—Richelieu and François-Mitterrand—it serves as France’s national repository, preserving a vast collection of published works, manuscripts, and cultural treasures. 

The Richelieu site is home to the BnF Museum, showcasing rare artifacts, artworks, and historical manuscripts. As a key cultural institution, the library offers a glimpse into France’s intellectual and artistic heritage, making it a fascinating destination for anyone exploring the city.
points_of_interest.hours: Reading rooms, M-F, 09:00-18:00; Sa, 09:00-17:00; exhibitions, Tu-Sa, 10:00-19:00

points_of_interest.name: Jardin Yitzhak Rabin
points_of_interest.description: Nestled in the centre of the Parc Bercy (below) is a lovely, and truly peaceful, garden with several waterworks and other high-quality landscape-art pieces. If you are one of the many people visiting the 12th on business it would be well worth an hour of your time between meetings and dinner to explore the mound, the fountain, and the bridges, and to watch children play in complete peace, much like the peace to which the garden's namesake dedicated his life.

points_of_interest.name: Arènes de Lutèce
points_of_interest.description: An ancient Roman theater, the only surviving above-ground ruins of the Gallo-Roman era in Paris (ancient Lutetia, French ''Lutèce'') apart from the nearby ''Thermes de Cluny''. The theatre could hold approximately 15,000 spectators and measures some 132 m x 100 m. Built sometime in the 2nd century CE, the location of the actor's dressing room, the platform of the stage, and lapidary remains can still be seen. The remains were rediscovered in 1869, when new streets were being built. An excavation was subsequently ordered in 1883. The theatre has been preserved as a quiet archaeological park removed from the bustle of Parisian streets.
points_of_interest.address: 47, rue Monge et rue de Navarre

points_of_interest.name: Colonne Vendôme
points_of_interest.description: The centrepiece of a magnificent 8-sided square first laid out in 1699 to show off an equestrian statue of the Sun King, Louis XIV. The statue was removed amid revolutionary fervor in 1792 and replaced in 1806 with the ''Colonne de la Grande Armée''. This was modelled on Trajan's column in Rome and decorated with Napoleon's military exploits. The present column is a replica, however, as the original was pulled down during the 1871 Paris Commune. Place Vendôme represents the best of well-heeled Paris, being home to an abundance of exclusive boutiques, jewellers and fashion labels—Cartier, Boucheron, Trussardi, van Cleef & Arpels—several banks, the French Ministry of Justice, and the Hôtel Ritz.

points_of_interest.name: Les Catacombes de Paris
points_of_interest.description:
Les Catacombes de Paris offers a unique and fascinating glimpse into the city's history. This vast network of underground tunnels, originally carved out during the Roman era, now serves as the final resting place for the remains of over six million Parisians. In the late 18th and early 19th centuries, these bones were transferred here from overcrowded cemeteries and charnel houses across the city. The result is a hauntingly beautiful, if somewhat macabre, experience. Visitors can wander through the dimly lit passageways, where skulls and bones are neatly arranged in a somber yet orderly fashion.

The atmosphere of the catacombs is undeniably eerie, though not overwhelmingly so. It’s a place that invites reflection and curiosity, making it a must-visit for those interested in history, architecture, or the unconventional. Be aware that the site has a limited capacity, allowing only 200 visitors at a time. This may result in a wait, especially during peak hours, so planning your visit in advance is a good idea.

Visitors should also note that the exit involves climbing a steep stairwell, which may pose a challenge for the elderly or those with mobility issues. Tickets can be purchased online for a small premium (€29, including an audioguide), allowing you to select a specific date and time and skip the queues. This option is highly recommended for a smoother experience.
points_of_interest.hours: Tu-Su 9:45-20:30; last admission 19:30; closed Mo and public holidays

points_of_interest.name: La Cité de la Mode et du Design
points_of_interest.description: Les Docks Part gallery - part restaurant - part nightclub, La Cite (Les Docks) is a modern building that is instantly recognisable due to being draped on one side with a large neon green shell covering the stairwells and roof the building. Roughly translated in English as The City of Fashion and Design, this is a trendy spot at the weekends and is used for event like [http://www.maison-objet.com/fr/paris-design-week Paris Design Week]. The restaurant in the building is open all year round.

points_of_interest.name: l'Assemblée Nationale
points_of_interest.description: Guided tours conducted all day, ID required. Formerly the Palais Bourbon, this building has housed the National Assembly, the French parliament's lower house, since 1827. Some interesting architecture and the library features the painting ''l'Histoire de la civilization'' by Delacroix. Visitors may be interested in attending assembly debates.

points_of_interest.name: The Chapelle Royale
points_of_interest.description: A Palestine Chapel that contains a royal gallery dedicated to St. Louis. It was finished in 1707 by Robert de Cotte. The intricate detailing of the chapel's ceiling contains paintings by the artists Jouvet, Coypel, and La Fosse. Van Cleve sculpted the front altar out of marble which is decorated in front with gilded bronze.

points_of_interest.name: Immeuble Molitor
points_of_interest.description: Immeuble Molitor, a landmark apartment building designed by Le Corbusier and Pierre Jeanneret, was constructed between 1931 and 1934. Situated at the Paris-Boulogne-Billancourt border, it is one of 17 Le Corbusier works recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. This building holds special significance, as Le Corbusier himself resided here from its completion until his death in 1965. It stands as a testament to his innovative modernist design and offers a unique glimpse into his personal and professional legacy. A must-visit for architecture enthusiasts and history buffs alike.

points_of_interest.name: Place des Vosges
points_of_interest.description: Nestled in the heart of Paris's Marais district, Place des Vosges is the oldest planned square in the city. Originally known as Place Royale, it was a symbol of Parisian elegance and a favored address for the nobility during the 17th and 18th centuries. This charming, enclosed square is surrounded by beautiful architecture and offers a peaceful retreat from the bustling city. Visitors can enjoy its tranquil ambiance, cafes, and cultural attractions, making it a must-visit destination in one of Paris's most historic neighborhoods.

points_of_interest.name: Musée Edith Piaf
points_of_interest.description: The Musée Edith Piaf is a charming cultural destination dedicated to the life and legacy of the iconic French singer Edith Piaf. Located in the heart of Paris, this intimate museum offers a fascinating glimpse into the world of "La Môme Piaf," showcasing her rise from a street performer to a global star. Exhibits feature rare memorabilia, personal artifacts, and interactive displays that highlight her career, struggles, and enduring impact on French music and culture. Visitors can explore her story through photographs, costumes, and recordings, gaining a deeper appreciation for her artistry and the timeless appeal of her music.

points_of_interest.name: Place de la Concorde
points_of_interest.description: The largest square in Paris with fantastic vistas in every direction. It was in this square (then called ''la Place de la Revolution'') that the French King Louis XVI, Marie Antoinette and many others were guillotined during the Terror. The large Egyptian obelisk in the centre of the Place de la Concorde was brought from the Temple of Luxor.

points_of_interest.name: Grande Arche de la Defense
points_of_interest.description:
The Grande Arche de la Defense is a striking modern landmark in Paris, known for its bold, cube-like design that reimagines the traditional concept of an arch. This monumental structure, located in the bustling La Defense district, is a testament to contemporary architecture and serves as a gateway to the city.
