While its design may appear more geometric than a conventional arch, it has become an iconic symbol of Paris's blend of history and innovation.

Visitors should note that the viewing platform at the top of the Grande Arche has experienced periodic closures over the years. After being closed following an elevator incident in 2010, it reopened to the public in May 2017. However, as of October 2023, the platform is once again closed. Travelers planning to visit are encouraged to check for updates on accessibility before heading to the site. Despite the viewing platform's current status, the Grande Arche remains a must-see attraction for its architectural significance and its role as a symbol of Paris's dynamic spirit.

points_of_interest.name: Île aux Cygnes
points_of_interest.description: Île aux Cygnes, a small artificial island in the Seine River, offers a charming haven in Paris. Created in 1827, it features a tree-lined walkway perfect for strolling. Visitors can enjoy a public workout area with a climbing wall and a replica of the Statue of Liberty. The island is easily accessible via the Passy and Bir-Hakeim metro stations, making it a popular spot for both relaxation and recreation.

points_of_interest.name: Musée d'Art et d'Histoire du Judaïsme
points_of_interest.description:
The Musée d'Art et d'Histoire du Judaïsme is the largest French museum of Jewish art and history. It is located in the Hôtel de Saint-Aignan in the Marais district in Paris.

The museum conveys the rich history and culture of Jews in Europe and North Africa from the Middle Ages to the 20th century. Its fine collection of religious objects, archives, manuscripts, and works of art promotes the contributions of Jews to France and to the world, especially in the arts. The museum's collections include works of art from Marc Chagall and Amedeo Modigliani. Its exhibitions have included works by artists such as Soutine, Frenel, Mane-Katz and others.

The museum has a bookshop selling books on Jewish art and history and Judaica, a media library with an online catalogue accessible to the public, and an auditorium which offers conferences, lectures, concerts, performances, and seminars. It also provides guided weekly visits in English during the tourist season for individuals as well as students and teachers, and workshops for children, families, and adults.

points_of_interest.name: Musée Gustave Moreau
points_of_interest.description:
The Musée national Gustave Moreau is an art museum dedicated to the works of Symbolist painter Gustave Moreau . It is located in the 9th arrondissement of Paris at 14, rue de la Rochefoucauld, Paris, France.

The museum was originally Moreau's dwelling, transformed by his 1895 decision into a studio and museum of his work with his apartment remaining on the first floor. Today the museum contains Moreau's drawings, paintings, watercolors, and sculptures.

points_of_interest.name: Cimetière de Montmartre
points_of_interest.description: Cimetière de Montmartre, located in Paris's 18th arrondissement, is a historic cemetery with roots tracing back to the early 19th century. Tucked away in the heart of the city, this peaceful site offers a serene escape from the urban bustle. Known for its cultural significance, the cemetery is the final resting place of many notable artists and writers, providing a fascinating glimpse into Montmartre's rich history. Visitors can stroll through its winding paths and discover the stories behind its ornate tombstones, making it a captivating destination for those exploring this iconic Parisian neighborhood.

points_of_interest.name: Palais du Luxembourg
points_of_interest.description: Visitable only by reservation and then only one Saturday every month. A richly decorated palace built for Marie de Medici in the early 17th century, which is now the French Senate. For those interested in seeing a Parisian monument normally unavailable to the public, or for those interested in the inner workings of the French Government. The large '''Luxembourg Garden''' is open to the public year-round. The garden is home to the Medici fountain, a children's playground, and vintage toy boats for hire that children push around in the Grand Bassin duck pond (a 90-year tradition).

points_of_interest.name: Musée Marmottan-Monet
points_of_interest.description:
Nestled in the heart of Paris, the Musée Marmottan-Monet is a hidden gem that offers a unique cultural experience. Owned by the French Académie des Beaux-Arts, this enchanting museum is renowned for its diverse and impressive collections. 

The museum's holdings are the result of several significant donations, showcasing a wide range of artistic treasures. Visitors can explore an extensive collection of First Empire art and furnishings, which provide a fascinating glimpse into the opulence of the Napoleonic era. Additionally, the museum is home to a remarkable array of illuminated manuscripts, highlighting the artistry and craftsmanship of medieval and Renaissance periods.

However, the true crown jewel of the Musée Marmottan-Monet is its extraordinary collection of Impressionist art. As the largest repository of Claude Monet's works in the world, the museum offers an unparalleled opportunity to delve into the master's creative genius. Alongside Monet, the collection features pieces by other iconic Impressionist artists, including Renoir, Manet, Morisot, Caillebotte, and Gauguin. This makes the museum a must-visit destination for anyone passionate about Impressionism and its enduring legacy.
points_of_interest.hours: Tu W F-Su 10:00-18:00; Th 10:00-21:00; last entry 30 min before closing

points_of_interest.name: Notre Dame des Victoires
points_of_interest.description: Notre-Dame-des-Victoires is a charming minor basilica located in the heart of Paris, on rue Notre-Dame-des-Victoires in the 2nd arrondissement. Built in the French classical style between 1629 and 1740, it was originally an abbey church. The basilica’s name was given by King Louis XIII, who dedicated it to his victory over the Protestants at La Rochelle in 1628. Today, it’s renowned for its stunning collection of ex voto offerings, with over 37,000 devotional plaques, hearts, and military decorations left by the faithful. A unique and historic gem, it’s easily accessible via the Bourse Métro station.
points_of_interest.address: 7 Passage Des Petits Pères, 75002 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Bercy Village
points_of_interest.description: For a taste of the French countryside, a visit to Bercy Village brings to life the spirit of market shopping inside Paris.

points_of_interest.name: Jardin des Plantes
points_of_interest.description: The Paris Botanical Garden, founded as the royal medicinal garden in 1626 by King Louis XIII's doctor, contains over 10,000 species. The grounds also include a small zoo known as ''La Ménagerie'', and the '''Muséum National d'Histoire Naturelle''', which includes the ''Grande Galerie de l'Evolution'' (where you can see thousands of naturalized animals from all over the world) and the ''''Galerie de paléontologie et d'anatomie comparée'''' (same thing, but with skeletons).

points_of_interest.name: La Conciergerie
points_of_interest.description: The ancient medieval fortress and prison of the city's island, site of some remarkable medieval royal architecture and the scene of Marie Antoinette's imprisonment in the period leading to her execution in 1793; lots of revolutionary associations.

points_of_interest.name: Cimetière de Montparnasse
points_of_interest.description: Montparnasse Cemetery The burial place of existentialist philosopher Jean-Paul Sartre, feminist Simone de Beauvoir (both of whom lived nearby); musician Serge Gainsbourg; artist Man Ray; the poets Charles Baudelaire, Guy de Maupassant, Charles Sainte-Beuve, and Marguerite Duras; the founders of the Theatre of the Absurd Samuel Becket and Eugene Ionesco; the sculptors Constantin Brancusi and Ossip Zadkine; the composers Camille de Saint-Saens and César Franck; the actors Maria Montez and Jean Seberg; the French officer Alfred Dreyfus; the founder of the Larousse encyclopedia, Pierre Larousse; the industrialist André Citroen, and many others.

points_of_interest.name: La Butte aux Cailles
points_of_interest.description: La Butte aux Cailles is a charming little district nestled on a hill in the 13th arrondissement. Its narrow, cobblestone streets and village-like atmosphere make it a delightful place to explore. Known for its cozy restaurants and inviting cafés, it's a great spot to enjoy a meal or simply soak in the ambiance. This picturesque area offers a peaceful retreat from the bustling city.
points_of_interest.address: 10 Rue De La Butte-Aux-Cailles, 75013 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Les Invalides
points_of_interest.description: Les Invalides, a historic complex founded by Louis XIV in 1671, was originally built as a hospital to care for a large number of wounded soldiers, which inspired its name. Today, it continues to serve as an infirmary while also housing the Musée de l'Armée, offering insights into French military history. The complex is perhaps most famous for the stunning golden dome of l'Eglise du Dôme, where Napoleon Bonaparte's tomb is located, making it a significant landmark in Paris.

points_of_interest.name: Appartement de la Reine
points_of_interest.description: Queen's Apartment This suite Washington built for Louis XIV's wife Marie-Therese. The original decoration was redone between 1729 and 1735 with renowned white and gold woodwork. It features several famous rooms including a battle gallery room, a coronation room, and the royal birthing room. Tourists are always welcome to tour through the house and gaze at the spectacles of each room.
points_of_interest.address: 2b Rue De L'indépendance Américaine, 78000 Versailles, France

points_of_interest.name: Museum of the 1930s
points_of_interest.description: The Museum of the 1930s offers a fascinating journey through one of the most transformative decades of the 20th century. Explore exhibits that highlight the global economic and political upheavals, including the Great Depression and the rise of fascism. Discover how leaders like Franklin D. Roosevelt responded to crises with initiatives like the New Deal. The museum also captures the cultural vibrancy of the era, from the golden age of cinema to the rise of swing music. A must-visit for history enthusiasts and anyone curious about this pivotal decade that shaped the modern world.

points_of_interest.name: Rue des Rosiers
points_of_interest.description: Rue des Rosiers, which translates to "Street of the Rosebushes," is a charming and historically rich street in Paris's 4th arrondissement, located in the heart of the Marais district. Known as the center of the city's Jewish quarter, or "the Pletzl," this vibrant street is a hub of culture and history. It’s one of the few areas in Paris where shops and cafés remain open on Sundays and holidays, attracting a diverse crowd. While it has evolved into a hotspot for fashion boutiques, Rue des Rosiers still retains its unique character, blending tradition with modern style.

points_of_interest.name: Place de la Bastille
points_of_interest.description:
The Place de la Bastille (French pronunciation: [plas də la bastij]) is a square in Paris where the Bastille prison once stood, until the storming of the Bastille and its subsequent physical destruction between 14 July 1789 and 14 July 1790 during the French Revolution. No vestige of the prison remains.

The square straddles 3 arrondissements of Paris, namely the 4th, 11th and 12th. The square and its surrounding areas are normally called simply Bastille. The July Column (Colonne de Juillet) which commemorates the events of the July Revolution (1830) stands at the center of the square.  Other notable features include the Bastille Opera, the Bastille subway station and a section of the Canal Saint Martin.  Prior to 1984, the former Bastille railway station stood where the opera house now stands.
points_of_interest.address: 12 Place De La Bastille, 75011 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile
points_of_interest.description:
The Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile, often called simply the Arc de Triomphe, is one of the most famous monuments in Paris, France, standing at the western end of the Champs-Élysées at the centre of Place Charles de Gaulle, formerly named Place de l'Étoile—the étoile or "star" of the juncture formed by its twelve radiating avenues. The location of the arc and the plaza is shared between three arrondissements, 16th , 17th , and 8th . The Arc de Triomphe honours those who fought and died for France in the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars, with the names of all French victories and generals inscribed on its inner and outer surfaces. Beneath its vault lies the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier from World War I.

The central cohesive element of the Axe historique , the Arc de Triomphe was designed by Jean Chalgrin in 1806; its iconographic programme pits heroically nude French youths against bearded Germanic warriors in chain mail. It set the tone for public monuments with triumphant patriotic messages. Inspired by the Arch of Titus in Rome, Italy, the Arc de Triomphe has an overall height of 50 m , width of 45 m and depth of 22 m , while its large vault is 29.19 m high and 14.62 m wide. The smaller transverse vaults are 18.68 m high and 8.44 m wide.

Paris's Arc de Triomphe was the tallest triumphal arch until the completion of the Monumento a la Revolución in Mexico City in 1938, which is 67 m high. The Arch of Triumph in Pyongyang, completed in 1982, is modeled on the Arc de Triomphe and is slightly taller at 60 m . The Grande Arche in La Défense near Paris is 110 metres high, and, if considered to be a triumphal arch, is the world's tallest.
points_of_interest.address: Place de l'Étoile, Place Charles de Gaulle

points_of_interest.name: Centre des nouvelles industries et technologies
points_of_interest.description: The Centre des nouvelles industries et technologies, located in Puteaux, France, is a historic landmark in the La Défense district, just west of Paris. Opened in 1958 as the first building in this bustling business area, the CNIT serves as a versatile convention center, while also hosting shops, offices, and a Hilton hotel. Its striking triangular design reflects the shape of its original plot, which once housed the Zodiac factories. Over the years, the CNIT has undergone renovations in 1988 and 2009 to maintain its modern appeal, making it a fascinating blend of history and functionality.
points_of_interest.address: 1 Place De La Défense, 92800 Puteaux, France

points_of_interest.name: Square Béla Bartók
points_of_interest.description: Tucked away between two high-rise buildings on the Front de Seine, Square Béla Bartók is a small, peaceful park that offers a quiet retreat from the bustling city. The park is home to two eye-catching sculptures dedicated to the renowned musician Béla Bartók, adding a touch of culture and artistry to this urban oasis. It’s a charming spot to pause, relax, and enjoy the surroundings while exploring the area.

points_of_interest.name: Carnavalet
points_of_interest.description: Housed in two beautifully restored historic mansions, known as hôtels, Carnavalet Museum offers a fascinating journey through the history of Paris. With more than 140 rooms filled with artifacts, artwork, and exhibits, the museum provides a comprehensive look at the city's rich past. From prehistoric times to the modern era, visitors can explore the evolution of Paris through its art, culture, and daily life. The museum's historic setting adds to its charm, making it a must-visit for anyone interested in the story of this iconic city.

points_of_interest.name: Opera Garnier
points_of_interest.description: The Palais Garnier, famously known as the setting for "The Phantom of the Opera," captivates visitors with its grandeur. Inside, the opulence mirrors the exterior, offering a visually stunning experience. Since the opening of the Opéra Bastille in 1989, the Palais Garnier has primarily become a venue for dance, particularly ballet, adding to its cultural significance.

points_of_interest.name: Artists' Square
points_of_interest.description: Here, local artists gather to create vibrant works of art, offering custom portraits for visitors and showcasing their paintings for sale. This bustling hub is a great spot to capture memories of your trip or find unique souvenirs.

points_of_interest.name: Eglise de Saint Sulpice
points_of_interest.description: a Roman Catholic church on the east side of the Place Saint-Sulpice within the rue Bonaparte, in the Luxembourg Quarter of the VIe arrondissement. At 113 metres long, 58 metres in width and 34 metres tall, it is only slightly smaller than Notre-Dame and thus the second largest church in the city. It is dedicated to Sulpitius the Pious. During the 18th century, an elaborate gnomon, the Gnomon of Saint-Sulpice, was constructed in the church. In front of the church itself is the magnificent Place Saint-Sulpice which contains the 'Fountain of the Four Bishops'. The church has a long-standing tradition of talented organists that dates back to the eighteenth century. In 1862, Aristide Cavaillé-Coll reconstructed and improved the existing organ built by François-Henri Clicquot. Though using many materials from Clicquot's French Classical organ, it is considered to be Cavaillé-Coll's magnum opus, featuring 102 speaking stops, and is perhaps the most impressive instrument of the romantic French symphonic-organ era. Its organists have also been renowned, starting with Nicolas Séjan in the 18th century, and continuing with Charles-Marie Widor (organist 1870-1933) and Marcel Dupré (organist 1934-1971), both great organists and composers of organ music. The current organists are 'titulaire' Daniel Roth (since 1985) and 'assistant titulaire' Sophie-Véronique Cauchefer-Choplin. In Saint-Sulpice Sunday organ recitals are held on a regular basis (Auditions du Dimanche, following the High Mass, usually from 11:30am till 12:05pm, during the subsequent mass, a visit of the organ loft is possible).

points_of_interest.name: Musée en Herbe
points_of_interest.description: With a teaching style based on fun and humour, the Musée en Herbe offers classes and games about art especially designed for '''children'''. Observation, imagination and identification games permit kids to discover the works of art and objects shown, at their own pace. The exhibits are all hands-on so kids can have a free reign in the museum, and if that's not enough there are workshops as well.

points_of_interest.name: Porte Saint Denis
points_of_interest.description: The Porte Saint-Denis is a monumental arch in Paris, located in the 10th arrondissement. This historic landmark stands on the site of one of the gates from the former Wall of Charles V. Today, it serves as a striking reminder of Paris's medieval past, blending seamlessly into the vibrant modern streetscape. Visitors can admire its grandeur while exploring the lively area surrounding it.
points_of_interest.address: 1 Boulevard De Bonne Nouvelle, 75002 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Place des Victoires
points_of_interest.description: Nestled in central Paris, the Place des Victoires is a charming circular square located near the Palais-Royal. This historic site, which straddles the 1st and 2nd arrondissements, is where several streets converge, creating a vibrant yet tranquil spot to explore. Known for its elegant design and rich history, the square offers a glimpse into Paris' architectural heritage. Visitors can admire the surrounding buildings and soak in the lively ambiance of this picturesque destination.

points_of_interest.name: Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie
points_of_interest.description:
Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie is a must-visit destination for anyone fascinated by science and technology. Opened in 1986 and continually updated, this expansive museum offers a wealth of interactive exhibits that bring the wonders of science to life. One of the highlights is the Louis Lumière 3D cinema, where visitors can immerse themselves in cutting-edge visual experiences.

While the museum is particularly popular with families and children, its engaging displays and hands-on activities appeal to visitors of all ages. From exploring the frontiers of technology to discovering the marvels of the natural world, Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie is a place where learning is made fun and accessible. Whether you're a science enthusiast or just curious about the world around you, this iconic attraction promises an inspiring and educational experience.

points_of_interest.name: AccorHotels Arena
points_of_interest.description: An indoor sports arena that seats around 17,000 for sports and slightly over 20,000 for major concerts; formerly known as ''Palais des Omnisports de Paris-Bercy'' and ''Bercy Arena''. Home to numerous concerts and major sporting events, most notably the Paris Masters tournament on the ATP World Tour in men's tennis.

points_of_interest.name: Panthéon
points_of_interest.description:
The Panthéon, originally envisioned by Louis XV as a grand neo-classical church dedicated to St. Geneviève, the patron saint of Paris, underwent a significant transformation after the French Revolution. It became a mausoleum honoring the great minds and heroes of the French Republic. The crypt holds the remains of esteemed figures such as Voltaire, Rousseau, Victor Hugo, and the Curies, among others, reflecting the nation's rich intellectual and cultural heritage.

One of the Panthéon's most striking features is its dome, which offers a breathtaking view of the city after climbing 206 steps. This architectural marvel is a must-visit for anyone seeking a panoramic perspective of Paris. Inside, visitors can also find a fascinating reconstruction of Foucault's pendulum, adding a touch of scientific intrigue to the historical ambiance.

For those planning a visit, it's advisable to check the tour departure times at the information desk to make the most of your experience. The Panthéon seamlessly blends historical significance with architectural beauty, making it a compelling destination for travelers interested in exploring Paris's cultural and scientific treasures.
points_of_interest.hours: Daily, April-September 10:00-18:30, October-March: 10:00-18:00, Last admission 45 mins before closing

points_of_interest.name: Église Saint-Eustache
points_of_interest.description: The massive parish church of the Les Halles area is a notable example of late Gothic interspersed with Renaissance details (including the entire front façade), as it was only completed in the 17th century. Its unique form results from a combination of relatively short length and impressive height of over 30 metres inside. The latter allows room not only for an array of stained glass windows and paintings, but also France's largest church organ of 8,000 pipes. The sculpture ''Écoute'', depicting an oversized human head, was placed in front of the church's southern facade and has become a favourite photo spot.

points_of_interest.name: Cité Internationale Universitaire de Paris
points_of_interest.description: C.I.U.P. The C.I.U.P. is a student quarter established in 1925, providing homes for about 10,000 students, scientists, and artists from 120 countries. It has 40 houses attributed to individual nations. The individual houses organise top quality cultural and political events. Among the most remarkable buildings are the ''Fondation Deutsch de la Meurthe'', the ''Heinrich Heine House (Maison Heinrich Heine - Fondation de l'Allemagne)'', the ''Swedish Student House (Maison des Etudiants Suédois)'', and the ''Swiss Pavilion (Pavillon Suisse)'' which was built in 1933 on plans of Le Corbusier.

points_of_interest.name: Manufacture des Gobelins
points_of_interest.description: The Gobelins Manufactory is a historic tapestry factory in Paris, France. It is located at 42 avenue des Gobelins, near Les Gobelins métro station in the 13th arrondissement of Paris. It was originally established on the site as a medieval dyeing business by the family Gobelin.

points_of_interest.name: Musée de l'Armée
points_of_interest.description: This museum is in the historic Invalides complex and presents the history of the French Army. It is co-located with Napoleon Bonaparte's tomb (entry to which is included in the ticket price). Most of the exhibitions are very old fashioned, and the coverage of the First World War is surprisingly limited. A highlight is the Musée des Plans-Reliefs, which displays painstakingly accurate models of French fortresses and includes its own shop.
points_of_interest.hours: 10:00-17:00 (1 Oct-31 Mar), 10:00-18:00 (1 Apr-30 Sep), closed on the first M of each month

points_of_interest.name: The Grandes Eaux Musicales
points_of_interest.description: The Grandes Eaux Musicales is a stunning garden renowned for its impressive fountains. The centerpiece is the 17th-century Bassin de Neptune, a grand fountain featuring 99 individual jets of water. Another highlight is the Bassin d'Apollon, adding to the garden's visual splendor. Visitors seeking a breathtaking and memorable experience will find this location truly captivating.

points_of_interest.name: Marmottan Library
points_of_interest.description: The Bibliothèque Marmottan is a specialized library located within the Marmottan Museum in Paris, dedicated to preserving and showcasing rare books and documents from the Napoleonic era. This unique collection offers a fascinating glimpse into the history of the period, with manuscripts, letters, and other historical materials. It serves as a valuable resource for historians and enthusiasts alike, providing insight into the cultural and political landscape of Napoleon's time. Visitors can explore the library's treasures, making it a must-visit for those interested in this pivotal era of French history.

points_of_interest.name: Île Saint-Louis
points_of_interest.description: Île Saint-Louis is a charming island in the Seine River, offering a tranquil retreat from the bustling streets of Paris. Known for its narrow cobblestone streets, historic 17th- and 18th-century buildings, and quaint boutiques, the island exudes a sense of timeless elegance. Visitors can enjoy leisurely strolls along the Seine, taking in views of Notre-Dame Cathedral and the city skyline. The island is also famous for its artisanal ice cream shops and charming cafes, making it a perfect spot to relax and soak in the Parisian atmosphere. Its peaceful ambiance and rich history make it a must-visit destination.
points_of_interest.address: 19b Rue Des Deux Ponts, 75004 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Notre Dame Cathedral
points_of_interest.description:
Notre Dame Cathedral is one of the most iconic landmarks in the world, and a must-visit attraction for anyone traveling to Paris. This stunning early Gothic cathedral, also known as "Cathédrale de Notre Dame" or "Our Lady," showcases the evolution of Gothic architecture. While its design was conceived in the 12th century, the cathedral wasn't fully completed until the 14th century. Its intricate design and soaring vaults make it a masterpiece of medieval engineering and artistry.

The cathedral's west portal, or main entrance, is particularly notable for its rigid, almost austere design, which stands out from the more fluid lines of the rest of the building. This contrast highlights the dynamic nature of Gothic architecture and its development over time.

In April 2019, Notre Dame suffered a devastating fire that caused significant damage to the structure, including the loss of its iconic spire. However, after a meticulous and extensive restoration process, the cathedral reopened to the public in December 2024. This resilience and renewal make Notre Dame not only a historical treasure but also a symbol of hope and rebirth.

Visitors to Notre Dame can marvel at its towering ceilings, stunning stained-glass windows, and the serene atmosphere that fills the space. Whether you're drawn by its religious significance, its architectural brilliance, or its cultural importance, Notre Dame Cathedral promises an unforgettable experience.
points_of_interest.address: Ile de la Cité 6, Place du Parvis Notre Dame

points_of_interest.name: Rue Nicolas-Appert
points_of_interest.description: This street is named in honor for Nicolas Appert, a French businessman who invented airtight food preservation. On January 7th, 2015, it was the site of the ''Charlie Hebdo'' terrorist attack, which resulted in the deaths of 12 people. A plaque in front of a former office building memorializes the victims of the satirical magazine's staff.

points_of_interest.name: Église de la Madeleine
points_of_interest.description: La Madeleine One of the best-known and most beautiful churches in Paris, in the guise of a Corinthian order classical temple. Construction started in 1764, although the church was not finally consecrated until 1845. The Madeleine has a lavish interior of marble and gold.

points_of_interest.name: Musée de La Défense
points_of_interest.description: Musée de La Défense offers a fascinating glimpse into the history and evolution of the iconic La Défense district. Through an impressive collection of architectural plans and detailed scale models, the museum brings to life the transformation of this bustling business area. Visitors can explore how the district has grown over the years, gaining insight into its development and significance. Perfect for both history enthusiasts and those curious about urban planning, the museum provides a unique perspective on one of Paris' most dynamic regions.

points_of_interest.name: Statue de la Liberté
points_of_interest.description: This charming replica stands on the site where French sculptor Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi once worked on the original Statue of Liberty. It serves as a touching tribute to the iconic landmark and offers a glimpse into its creation. Nestled in a quiet Parisian setting, the statue is a must-visit for history enthusiasts and art lovers alike, celebrating both freedom and creativity.
points_of_interest.address: 3 Pont De Grenelle - Cadets De Saumur, 75015 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Musée Cognacq-Jay
points_of_interest.description: Nestled in the historic Hôtel Donon in Paris's 3rd arrondissement, the Musée Cognacq-Jay is a treasure trove of fine art and decorative arts. Founded by Théodore-Ernest Cognacq and his wife Marie-Louise Jaÿ, the creators of La Samaritaine department store, the museum showcases a stunning collection assembled between 1900 and 1925. With a focus on 18th-century France, highlights include paintings by Watteau, Fragonard, and Chardin, as well as sculptures by Houdon and exquisite furniture. The museum also features works from the 17th and 19th centuries, including pieces by Rembrandt, Corot, and Degas, offering a rich journey through French art history.

points_of_interest.name: Colorful basketball court
points_of_interest.description: Pigalle Duperré An unusually colorful court in the middle of buildings.

points_of_interest.name: Place Pigalle
points_of_interest.description: The sleaze of boulevard de Clichy between ''place Pigalle'' and ''place Blanche'' can provide a moment of distraction. Be warned if you are male it is better to do this in the company of a female fellow traveller, as the clubs often send the girls outside to attempt to physically drag passing men off of the street. These strip clubs are big ripoffs. They tempt you with a free drink for €10 entry; once in the girl who starts dancing orders a couple of drinks (Red Bull) and then before you realise you are presented with a bill ranging from €500-700. They have these big bouncers who threaten/manhandle you till you arrive at some settlement with them. The whole of Pigalle is a rip off, best avoided. The police know about these places but nothing is done.

points_of_interest.name: Monument to Balzac
points_of_interest.description: The Monument to Balzac, a sculpture by Auguste Rodin, honors the French novelist Honoré de Balzac. Rodin aimed to capture the writer's spirit rather than his likeness. Commissioned in 1891, the work faced criticism and was initially rejected. Rodin moved it to his home in Meudon, where it remained until it was cast in bronze in 1939 and placed on Boulevard du Montparnasse. Today, it is celebrated as a landmark of modern sculpture, with casts in museums worldwide. Kenneth Clark once called it the greatest sculpture of the 19th century, praising its bold defiance of convention and its enduring inspiration.

points_of_interest.name: Palais de Tokyo
points_of_interest.description: Site de création contemporaine The Palais de Tokyo is Paris's largest specialist contemporary art exhibition venue, owned and operated by the national government. The building dates to 1937 and also includes the Museum of Modern Art of the City of Paris.

points_of_interest.name: La Tour Jean-sans-Peur
points_of_interest.description: The Tour Jean-sans-Peur or Tour de Jean sans Peur , located in the 2nd arrondissement of Paris, is the last vestige of the Hôtel de Bourgogne , the residence first of the Counts of Artois and then the Dukes of Burgundy. The tower contained bed chambers and the grand stairway of the original residence, which stood next to it. It was completed between 1409–1411 by Jean sans Peur. The original hôtel occupied about a hectare of land, the boundaries of which are now marked by the rues Étienne Marcel, Montorgueil, Saint-Sauveur, and Saint-Denis. The tower itself is located at 20 rue Étienne Marcel, in the courtyard of an elementary school. It is one of the best surviving examples of medieval residential architecture in Paris. The tower is open to the public and presents changing expositions on life in the Middle Ages.

points_of_interest.name: Opéra Bastille
points_of_interest.description: One of the truly great venues for the performing arts anywhere in the world, Paris' new opera house actually managed to inspire some neighborhood protest during its planning and construction. Pretty much everybody is a believer nowadays though. Check out the website for upcoming shows, it might even make sense to plan a trip to Paris around one.

points_of_interest.name: Musée Curie
points_of_interest.description: This charming scientific museum preserves the offices and laboratories of Pierre and Marie Curie, pioneers in the discovery of radioactivity. Their instruments, equipment, and furniture is arranged as it was during their critically important research. Guided tours in English available.
points_of_interest.hours: M-F 13ː30-17ː00 except bank holidays and during Aug

points_of_interest.name: Jardin des Tuileries
points_of_interest.description: Built adjoining the now-lost royal palace of the Tuileries, these gardens lying immediately west of the Louvre offer a central open space for Parisians and visitors with semi-formal gardens (an outdoor gallery for modern sculpture), various cafés, ice cream and crépe stalls, and a summer fun fair. The gardens are frequently home to a giant Ferris wheel and enclose the ''Musée de la Orangerie'' and the ''Jeu de Paume''.

points_of_interest.name: Fondation Henri-Cartier-Bresson
points_of_interest.description: The foundation opened its doors in May 2003. It preserves Henri Cartier-Bresson and Martine Franck’s archives. Exhibition of photographs, paintings, sculptings, and illustrations.

points_of_interest.name: Stade Charléty
points_of_interest.description: Stade Sébastien-Charléty , also known as Stade Charléty or Charléty, is a multi-purpose stadium located in the 13th arrondissement of Paris, France. Comprising a running track and a football field, the stadium is a 20,000-seat state-owned venue used for numerous sports and events. It is also the current home ground of the rugby union team of Paris Université Club, who operate the venue, and the association football clubs Paris FC and Paris 13 Atletico.

points_of_interest.name: Musée d'Orsay
points_of_interest.description: Housed in a former ''Beaux-Arts'' railway station (completed in 1900 for the ''Exposition Universelle'', later saved from demolition and converted to its present use), the rambling, open-plan museum is home to the works of the great artists of the 19th century (1848-1914) - Impressionists, post-Impressionists, and the rest - that were formerly displayed in the l'Orangerie. This is perhaps the most spectacular collection of European impressionism in the world—breath-taking rooms full of Manet, Renoir, Monet, Van Gogh, and many others. Impressionist represent the biggest draw, but there is much more to explore.
points_of_interest.address: 1, rue de la Légion d'Honneur / rue de Lille

points_of_interest.name: Potager du Roi
points_of_interest.description: The Potager du Roi, located near the Palace of Versailles, is a historic kitchen garden that once supplied fresh produce to Louis XIV's court. Created by Jean-Baptiste de La Quintinie between 1678 and 1683, it showcases meticulous gardening techniques from the 17th century. Today, it is managed by the École nationale supérieure du paysage and is recognized as a Remarkable Garden of France. Visitors can explore its beautifully maintained plots, offering a glimpse into France's rich horticultural heritage.

points_of_interest.name: Paul Belmondo Museum
points_of_interest.description: The Paul Belmondo Museum is a museum dedicated to the works of the French sculptor Paul Belmondo. As the father of the famous actor Jean-Paul Belmondo, the museum offers a unique glimpse into both art and celebrity history. Visitors can explore a collection of his sculptures, each showcasing his skill in capturing form and emotion. This museum is a must-visit for art lovers and those curious about French cultural heritage.

points_of_interest.name: Élysée Palace
points_of_interest.description: Palais de l'Élysée The official residence of the President of France since 1848. Dating to the early 18th century, it contains the office of the President and the meeting place of the Council of Ministers. It is located near the Champs-Élysées in the 8th arrondissement of Paris, the name Élysée deriving from Elysian Fields, the place of the blessed dead in Greek mythology. Not open to the public, except occasionally during the annual National Heritage Days (usually a weekend in mid-September). Important foreign visitors are hosted at the nearby Hôtel de Marigny, a palatial residence.

points_of_interest.name: Tours Aillaud
points_of_interest.description: South-west from the Grande Arche you can find these tall cylindrical concrete residential towers, painted in various colours. Representing a 1970s urbanistic experiment, the 18 towers remain controversial and unique, and continue to house thousands of inhabitants in over 1600 apartments.
points_of_interest.address: 15 Allée Des Demoiselles D'avignon, 92000 Nanterre, France

points_of_interest.name: St Christophe de Javel
points_of_interest.description: Saint-Christophe-de-Javel is a Roman-Catholic church located at 4 rue Saint-Christophe in the 15th arrondissement of Paris. It was constructed between 1926 and 1930 in the newly industrialized neighborhood of Paris by the architect Charles-Henri Besnard , a follower of the architect and historian Viollet-le-Duc. While the church architecture is inspired by the Gothic architecture of the 13th century, it was constructed using a modern material, reinforced concrete, and made an innovative use of molded cement for the decoration of the facade and interior.

points_of_interest.name: Musée des Arts et Métiers
points_of_interest.description: Museum of Arts and Trades An industrial design museum in Paris that houses the collection of the Conservatoire National des Arts et Métiers (National Conservatory of Arts and Industry), which was founded in 1794 as a repository for the preservation of scientific instruments and inventions.
points_of_interest.hours: Tu-Su, 10:00-18:00, Th until 21:30, closed M and public holidays

points_of_interest.name: Moulin de la Galette
points_of_interest.description: Moulin de la Galette, nestled in the heart of Montmartre, is a historic windmill turned cultural icon. Once a functioning mill, it became a popular gathering spot in the 19th century, offering wine, fresh bread, and lively entertainment. Its name comes from the brown galette bread made from its flour. This charming spot has inspired many artists, including Renoir, whose painting *Bal du moulin de la Galette* captures its vibrant spirit. Today, it remains a must-visit for those exploring Paris' artistic heritage.

points_of_interest.name: Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris
points_of_interest.description: The east wing of the Palais de Tokyo holds the modern art collection of the city of Paris, dating roughly from World War I to date (the older part of the collection is at the Petit Palais in the 8th), including around 10,000 works.

points_of_interest.name: Promenade Plantée
points_of_interest.description: Coulée verte René-Dumont If you were a city planner in one of the great cities of our Earth and you discovered that a railroad right-of-way had been abandoned and would never be used again what might you do? Perhaps if you knew your stuff you'd convert it into a 4 mile long park, about half of which is elevated above street level on the old rail viaduct. This long narrow park pretty much allows the visitor to walk in carfree bliss from Place de Bastille to the Bois de Vincennes.

points_of_interest.name: Musée de l'Institut du Monde Arabe
points_of_interest.description: Arab World Institute The building has a freely accessible rooftop which allows for a beautiful bird's-eye view of the northern half of Paris.

points_of_interest.name: Le Palais Royal
points_of_interest.description: Ordered by Cardinal de Richelieu (1585-1642), King Louis XIII's prime Minister in 1629 (completed in 1636); originally called ''Palais Cardinal''; it became ''Le Palais Royal'' when Anne d'Autriche, Louis XIII's wife, came to live here to get away from the ''Louvre'' palace. It eventually housed Louis XIV until the move to Versailles. It includes also a beautiful garden ''Les jardins du Palais Royal'', enclosed by the buildings. It's been the theatre of one of the seminal events of the French Revolution (Camille Desmoulins made a famous declaration here in 1789). The ''Théatre Français'' nearby was built in 1716. There are numerous restaurants inside the garden , including famous ''Le Grand Véfour''. There's also the controversial ''Colonnes de Buren'', striped columns installed within the inside yard amid the 17th century architecture.
points_of_interest.hours: 07:00-23:00 during the summer and 07:00-20:30 in the winter with hours varying spring and autumn

points_of_interest.name: Lion of Belfort
points_of_interest.description: This is a bronze replica in smaller scale of a monument created by Bartholdi, the sculptor of the Statue of Liberty, in order to commemorate Denfert-Rochereau, who defended the city of Belfort in the Franco-Prussian war of 1870.

points_of_interest.name: Musée du quai Branly
points_of_interest.description: Opened in 2006, this is the newest and the most modern of Paris' great museums, housing an outstanding collection of tribal art, with a particular emphasis on France's former (and present) territories in Oceania and Africa. The museum is large and you can easily spend half a day browsing, especially if you pause to explore the multimedia presentations.

points_of_interest.name: The Grand Trianon Castle
points_of_interest.description: Louis XIV requested that it be built as a retreat for the king or as a place for the king and his guests to dine without the strict etiquette of the court. Today, it houses visiting foreign dignitaries. It is renowned for its Italian architecture, pink marble, and geometrical french-style gardens. All visitors who come to see the Trianon leave in awe of the beautifully designed castle.
points_of_interest.address: Allée Des Deux Trianons, 78000 Versailles, France

points_of_interest.name: Parc Edmond de Rothschild
points_of_interest.description: Parc Edmond de Rothschild is a charming park features a stunning Japanese garden, perfect for relaxation and reflection. Surrounding the garden is the remnants of a historic estate, adding a touch of intrigue to the landscape. Visitors can explore the grounds, enjoying the peaceful atmosphere and the unique fusion of cultures and eras that make this park a standout destination.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel de Ville
points_of_interest.description: Town Hall Many feel that this, Paris' town hall, is one of the loveliest buildings in the city. You might not get that from the front view, but try watching the light change on its roofs and towers during sunset from one of the cafés on the Ile de St. Louis, the '''Lutece''' for instance. Alternatively, go to the top floor of the Bazar de l'Hôtel de Ville (BHV) department store opposite, on rue de Rivoli and walk up a flight of stairs to the roof terrace (terrasse), from which there is a dramatic view of both the roof of the Hôtel de Ville and the immediate surroundings and river. The present Hôtel de Ville replaced the 16th century original which was burned down during the Commune in 1871. A pastiche of its predecessor, but on a far larger scale, it was designed by the architects Ballu and Deperthes, chosen after a competition, and was mostly completed by 1882. The building is lavishly, and some would say heavy-handedly, decorated both inside and out, and finished in an arrestingly white stone, similar to that used for the even more eye-catching Sacre-Coeur basilica. The statue on the garden wall on the south side is of Etienne Marcel, the most famous holder of the post of "prevôt des marchands" (provost of merchants) which pre-dated the office of mayor. Marcel came to a sticky end, lynched in 1358 by an angry mob after trying to assert the city's powers a little too energetically. The Hôtel de Ville was for many years the private fiefdom of Jacques Chirac, France's president before Sarkozy, and was the site of a scandal centring on both illegal jobs given to Chirac's party members and an immense entertainment budget. General de Gaulle greeted the crowds from a front window in 1944 when Paris was liberated from the Germans and Robespierre was shot in the jaw and arrested in the original building in 1794. Admirers of Hôtel de Ville's architecture will want to know that Ballu also built the Church of La Trinité in the 9th arrondissement and the belfry of the town hall of the 1st arrondissement, opposite the Louvre's east façade. Ballu also restored the Tour St Jacques (see below), which was uncovered after restoration work lasting over a decade.
points_of_interest.address: Place de la Hôtel de Ville

points_of_interest.name: Pont Alexandre III
points_of_interest.description: Pont Alexandre III is an iconic bridge in Paris, known for its elegant design and ornate details. Spanning the Seine, it connects the Champs-Élysées with the Invalides and Eiffel Tower areas. This beautiful deck arch bridge is celebrated for its extravagant architecture and has been recognized as a French historic monument since 1975. Visitors can admire its grand statues and intricate ironwork while strolling across, taking in stunning views of the river and the city skyline. It’s a must-visit spot for photography and soaking in Parisian charm.

points_of_interest.name: Parc André Malraux
points_of_interest.description: The expansive, calm park around a lake extends westwards behind the Tours Aillaud, and is to La Défense what Central Park is to Downtown Manhattan. You can take spectacular pictures of the skyline juxtaposed against the park's greenery from there.

points_of_interest.name: Pont de Bir-Hakeim
points_of_interest.description: Pont de Bir-Hakeim, formerly known as Pont de Passy, is an elegant arch bridge spanning the Seine in Paris. Connecting the 15th and 16th arrondissements, it passes over the Île aux Cygnes. Built between 1903 and 1905, it replaced an earlier footbridge and features two levels: one for vehicles and pedestrians, and an upper viaduct for Line 6 of the Paris Métro. Its sleek steel design and strategic location make it a notable landmark for both function and aesthetics.
points_of_interest.address: 2 Pont De Bir Hakeim, 75015 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Picasso Museum
points_of_interest.description: Most of the works by Picasso and others which were in the master's possession at the time of his death are now on display here.
points_of_interest.hours: 09:30-18:00, W-M & 09:30-20:00 on Th, except during winter when closing time is always 17:30

points_of_interest.name: Moulin Blute-Fin
points_of_interest.description: The windmill is within fenced private property, and may be difficult to see from the street expecially if there are leaves on the nearby trees. It is near the more visible Moulin de la Galette.

points_of_interest.name: Musée Dapper
points_of_interest.description: Musée Dapper was a French museum specializing in African art. It was opened in May 1986, and closed on 18 June 2017. The Dapper Foundation is still located at the same premises in the 16th arrondissement of Paris at 35 rue Paul Valéry, Paris, France.

points_of_interest.name: Parc de Bercy
points_of_interest.description: Between the River Seine and the rail yards attached to ''Gare de Lyon'' and ''Gare de Bercy'' is a green space which would seem pretty huge if the 12th weren't also the home of the ''Bois de Vincennes''. The park is a good place to hang out waiting for the line to form for sporting events and concerts at ''AccorHotels Arena''.

points_of_interest.name: Musée national du Moyen Âge
points_of_interest.description: Musée de Cluny Housed in a 15th-century abbey, alongside 1st century Gallo-Roman baths, the museum has an extensive collection of medieval art and artifacts. Highlights include the medieval "Lady and the Unicorn" tapestries, a papal golden rose, and the original heads from the facade of Notre Dame.

points_of_interest.name: Saint-Germain l'Auxerrois
points_of_interest.description: This Gothic church functioned until the 19th century as the parish church of the kings of France. In this role, the church has sometimes played a gruesome part in history. Its bell called 'Marie' sounded on the night of 23 August 1572, to launch the St. Bartholomew's Day Massacre, in which thousands of Huguenots were killed by Catholic mobs. Nowadays, the church is peaceful and an active parish church for commoners (the monarchy having long since given way to the Republic), and well worth visiting.

points_of_interest.name: Observatoire
points_of_interest.description: The observatory was erected by Claude Perrault from 1667 to 1672 by order of Colbert. The building is oriented to the four cardinal directions. It is crossed in the centre by the Paris meridian (2° 20′ 14″ east of Greenwich). The observatory is not open to the public.
points_of_interest.address: 61, av de l'Observatoire, entrance: 77, av Denfert-Rochereau

points_of_interest.name: Rodin Museum
points_of_interest.description:
The Rodin Museum is a must-visit destination for art enthusiasts and anyone looking to immerse themselves in the works of one of history's greatest sculptors. This museum offers a unique opportunity to explore the life and artistry of Auguste Rodin through an extensive and beautifully curated collection of his sculptures, drawings, and other works. 

Housed in a spacious and elegant building, the museum's interior is as impressive as its contents. Large windows allow natural light to flood the galleries, creating a bright and airy atmosphere that enhances the viewing experience. The thoughtful presentation of the artworks, combined with the building's open design, makes the museum a pleasure to wander through.

Surrounding the museum is a beautiful garden, perfect for a relaxing stroll after exploring the galleries. The entire experience—whether indoors or outdoors—provides a deeper appreciation for Rodin's genius and leaves a lasting impression on all who visit.
points_of_interest.hours: Tu-Su: museum: 10:00-17:45, park: till 18:00; ticket office: till 17:15. Closed M

points_of_interest.name: The Temple of Love
points_of_interest.description: A nice sight to stop by. The temple was built in 1778 in the middle of a small island in The Parc. In the center of this circular temple is a replica Bouchardon statue. The original can be found in The Louvre Museum. It is an especially popular sight for couples who often enjoy sharing a kiss at the center of the temple.

points_of_interest.name: Tour St Jacques
points_of_interest.description: A Gothic church tower in a square 150m to the west of the Hôtel de Ville was restored by Ballu, is all that remains of Eglise Saint-Jacques-de-la-Boucherie, which was the meeting place in Paris for pilgrims heading to Santiago de Compestela. As such it is included on the UNESCO World Heritage List as part of the Routes of Santiago de Compostela in France.

points_of_interest.name: Le Grand Palais
points_of_interest.description: The Grand Palais, located in Paris's 8th arrondissement, is a stunning historic site and exhibition hall that showcases French art and culture. Built for the 1900 Universal Exposition, this Beaux-Arts masterpiece features ornate stone facades, glass vaults, and innovative iron and concrete framing. Its design reflects its purpose as a grand venue for artistic events, with a pediment proclaiming it a monument to French art. A designated historic monument, the Grand Palais continues to host major exhibitions and events, making it a must-visit destination in the heart of Paris.

points_of_interest.name: Nanterre Cathedral
points_of_interest.description: Église Notre Dame de Pitié Built in the 1920s, it is no match for the Notre Dame de Paris in either historical importance or architectural detailing, but it can be an interesting destination for those interested in sacral architecture.

points_of_interest.name: Pont Mirabeau
points_of_interest.description: Pont Mirabeau is a beautiful arch bridge spanning the Seine in Paris, built between 1895 and 1897. Named after Honoré Gabriel Riqueti de Mirabeau, it was designated a historical monument in 1975. This elegant structure offers stunning views of the river and is a popular spot for both locals and visitors to admire the city's architectural heritage.

points_of_interest.name: Musée de la Serrure
points_of_interest.description: The Musée de la Serrure, also known as the Musée Bricard, was a unique museum in Paris's 3rd arrondissement dedicated to the art of locks, keys, and door knockers. Housed in the historic Hôtel Libéral Bruant, the museum showcased a fascinating collection spanning from Roman times to the 19th century. Visitors could explore an array of locks, keys, and ironwork, including ancient bronze keys and medieval knockers. A locksmith's workshop added an interactive touch, offering insights into the craft. Though the museum closed in 2003, it remains a memorable highlight for those who had the chance to visit.

points_of_interest.name: Espace Dali
points_of_interest.description: A fantastic and undeservedly little-known collection of the great surrealist artist's often overlooked sculptural works. Those travellers seeking a more authentic experience should be warned that the majority of works here are reproductions, and that this "museum" is more appropriately considered as a for-profit, tourist-oriented homage to the artist rather than a carefully curated collection of original work. To find it, head up to Sacré Cœur and stand facing it and take a left. Keep your eye out for small Dali signs.
points_of_interest.hours: Sep-Jun: 10:00-18:00 daily; Jul-Aug: 10:00-20:00 daily. Guided tours 15:00

points_of_interest.name: Fondation Louis Vuitton
points_of_interest.description: The Fondation Louis Vuitton is a contemporary art museum and cultural center located in the Bois de Boulogne, Paris. Designed by renowned architect Frank Gehry, the building is a striking example of Deconstructivist architecture. Opened in 2014, the museum showcases an impressive collection of modern and contemporary art, along with rotating exhibitions and cultural events. Surrounded by lush greenery, it offers a unique blend of art, design, and natural beauty. With over 1.4 million visitors annually, it has become a must-visit destination for art enthusiasts and travelers alike.

points_of_interest.name: Bois de Vincennes
points_of_interest.description: Bois de Vincennes, located on the eastern edge of Paris, is the city's largest public park. Created between 1855 and 1866 by Emperor Napoleon III, it offers a peaceful escape from the urban bustle. The park features an English landscape garden with four lakes, a zoo, an arboretum, and a botanical garden. It also includes a horse-racing track, a velodrome, and the campus of the French national institute of sports and physical education. Situated near the historic Château de Vincennes, this expansive green space provides a serene retreat with plenty of opportunities for outdoor activities and exploration.
points_of_interest.address: Route De La Demi-Lune, 75012 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Eglise Saint-Étienne-du-Mont
points_of_interest.description: St. Geneviève was responsible for saving Paris from the Huns in 451 and her shrine in the church has been a popular place of pilgrimage ever since. The church as it stands dates from between 1492 and 1626 and is a mix of Gothic and Renaissance architectural styles. A unique feature is the Renaissance rood screen, the sole survivor in the city.

points_of_interest.name: Sainte-Chapelle
points_of_interest.description: Soaring stained glass windows beaming ample light onto the rich primary colours of the tile mosaics on the floor, this photogenic church was built by the French kings to house the relics of the Crown of Thorns. Make sure you go on a sunny day, as the highlight of this small chapel in Rayonnante Gothic style are the large stained-glass windows which soar up to near the vaulted ceiling. Also of interest is the extremely ornate lower level. If it happens to be rainy or cloudy, give Sainte-Chapelle a miss, as the play of coloured lights on the floor is well worth the wait for a sunnier day. As the chapelle is inside the Courts of Justice, there will thus be a security check.

points_of_interest.name: Parc Montsouris
points_of_interest.description: Considered one of the most colourful Parisian parks, a local favourite, the Parc Montsouris was opened in 1878, having been designed by Alphand for Baron Haussmann. A large man-made lake and waterfalls are surrounded by long stretches of gently sloping lawns. Bronze statues are to be found studding the grounds, amongst the 1,400 trees, including such exotic varieties as the giant sequoia and the ginkgo. The park is featured in the film ''Cléo de 5 à 7''. It is popular among families (there are two playground areas for children) and students.

points_of_interest.name: Musée des Égouts de Paris
points_of_interest.description: Tucked beneath the streets of Paris, the Musée des Égouts de Paris offers a fascinating glimpse into the city's underground sewer system. Located near the Pont de l'Alma in the 7th arrondissement, this unique museum showcases the historic infrastructure that has supported Paris for centuries. Open every day except Monday, it provides an intriguing look at a side of the city often overlooked by visitors.

points_of_interest.name: Hameau de la Reine
points_of_interest.description: The Queen's hamlet A rustic retreat, which served as a private meeting place for the Queen and her closest friends, a place of leisure. The style of the place is completely different to the royal Versailles, it was fashionable among the French aristocracy at the time. It makes for a pleasant interruption from the grand buildings.

points_of_interest.name: La Bastille
points_of_interest.description: Enter Bastille station through any entrance or on any train and then make your way to the ''Bobigny/Pablo Picasso''-bound platform. All that's left of the fortress whose front steps used to lead up from ''place de la Bastille'' are some foundation stones which you can see while waiting for a north bound train on this ''metro'' platform. There are maps and explanations showing where the fortress used to be relative the ''place'' and surroundings (basically the location of the old front steps are now occupied by '''Café des Phares''').
points_of_interest.address: 12 Place De La Bastille, 75011 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Musée du Petit Palais
points_of_interest.description: The Petit Palais was built as a complement to the Grand Palais for the 1900 universal exhibition, and afterwards became the prime exhibition venue for the City of Paris' vast collection of artworks spanning centuries from ancient history to around 1914. (Later material is at the Museum of Modern Art of the City of Paris in the 16th). There is a permanent exhibition of selected artworks of artifacts, complemented by temporary exhibitions of historic artworks. The Petit Palais also features an on-site cafe/restaurant, as well as a book and gift shop.
points_of_interest.hours: Open daily except except Mondays and public holidays from 10:00 to 18:00. Thursdays until 20:00 for temporary exhibitions only. Ticket office closes at 17:00

points_of_interest.name: Paris La Défense Arena
points_of_interest.description: A domed stadium near the Grande Arche. It opened in October 2017, and its main tenant is the rugby union club Racing 92. The facility can host everything from court sports to concerts, with configurations ranging from 10,000 for court sports, 32,000 for rugby, and 40,000 for concerts. It will host gymnastics events when Paris next hosts the Summer Olympics in 2024.

points_of_interest.name: Galerie Michèle Broutta
points_of_interest.description: Discover an exquisite collection of rare etchings, limited-edition prints, and beautifully crafted collectors' books at Galerie Michèle Broutta. This charming gallery showcases works of exceptional quality, offering art lovers and collectors a chance to explore unique pieces. Whether you're seeking inspiration or a special souvenir, the gallery's thoughtfully curated selection promises to captivate. A must-visit for anyone passionate about art and literature.

points_of_interest.name: Foundation Henri Cartier-Bresson
points_of_interest.description: The Foundation of Henri Cartier-Bresson is a private foundation for public use and for the memories and conservation of the photographer Henri Cartier Bresson and his wife Martine Franck. There are permanent displays and three major expositions planned each year.

points_of_interest.name: Musée de Montmartre
points_of_interest.description: The museum is located in a 17th century house with a garden, and features the history and culture of Montmartre. Several famous artists had lived in the house including Renoir.

points_of_interest.name: Musée Yves Saint Laurent
points_of_interest.description: The Musée Yves Saint Laurent is a celebration of the legendary designer's enduring legacy. Located in a stunning space, the museum showcases iconic designs, archival materials, and insights into the history of the fashion house. Visitors can explore the creative journey of Yves Saint Laurent, from his groundbreaking collections to his lasting impact on fashion. A must-visit for fashion enthusiasts, the museum offers a fascinating glimpse into the world of haute couture and the man who revolutionized it.

points_of_interest.name: Picpus Cemetery
points_of_interest.description: Cimetière de Picpus A must for anyone interested in the history of the American Revolution. This small cemetery includes three mass graves from the French Revolution, plus a section that includes many of France's most noble families that lost members during the French Revolution and consequently have a continuing right to be buried there. In the farthest right hand corner is the tomb of General Lafayette, the friend and fellow soldier of George Washington. Beside him is his beloved wife plus other members of her family, the de Noailles, who were almost completely wiped out during the French Revolution because of their closeness to the Court. Since 1834 the American flag has apparently flown continuously over his grave, even during the German occupation of Paris during World War II. Well worthy of a visit.

points_of_interest.name: Eglise Saint-Julien-le-Pauvre
points_of_interest.description:
Saint-Julien-le-Pauvre, in full Église Saint-Julien-le-Pauvre (French for Church of Saint Julian the Poor), is a Melkite Greek Catholic parish church in Paris, France, and one of the city's oldest religious buildings. Begun in Romanesque style during the 12th century, most of its architecture is Primary Gothic. It is situated in the 5th arrondissement, on the Left Bank of the Seine River, about 500 meters away from the Musée de Cluny and in the proximity of the Maubert-Mutualité Paris Métro station. It shares a city block with the Square René Viviani.
Originally a Roman Catholic place of worship, Saint-Julien-le-Pauvre was built in stages from the 12th to the 19th centuries, and granted to the Eastern Catholic Melkite community in 1889.

points_of_interest.name: La Samaritaine
points_of_interest.description: La Samaritaine is one of Paris's greatest department stores located in a spectacular art nouveau building dating back to 1870. It reopened on June 23, 2021 after a 16-year closure for renovations.

points_of_interest.name: Port-Royal Abbey
points_of_interest.description: Famous people who stayed here include Marie de Rohan, intriguer during the Fronde; Jeanne Baptiste d'Albert de Luynes, future mistress of a duke of Savoy; Marie Angélique de Fontanges, mistress of Louis XIV, died here giving birth to his child who also died. Today its main cloister (illustration) forms part of the modern Hôpital Cochin.

points_of_interest.name: Hall of Mirrors
points_of_interest.description: Of one of the most emblematic royal rooms, this Baroque-style gallery has been the scene of significant historical events, including where Otto von Bismarck proclaimed the first German Empire.
points_of_interest.address: 2b Rue De L'indépendance Américaine, 78000 Versailles, France

points_of_interest.name: Mémorial de la Shoah
points_of_interest.description: The Holocaust Memorial Opened in January 2005, the Holocaust Memorial comprises a major documentation centre and a wall bearing 76,000 names of Jews deported from France to the Nazi camps between 1942-1944. Includes an archive of a million artefacts, including 55,000 photographs. Excursions are run from the memorial to French internment camp sites such as Drancy.

points_of_interest.name: Palais de la decouverte
points_of_interest.description: Palace of discovery CLOSED UNTIL 2025 FOR RENOVATION WORKS. Located in a magnificent the western wing of the Grand Palais, this museum forms a part of science-themed education-oriented ''universcience'' establishment together with the La Cite des Sciences in La Villette. In the Palais, you will find two large floors with rooms dedicated to different branches of science, including physics, chemistry, mathematics and life-sciences, as well as a planetarium.
points_of_interest.hours: Tu-Sa 09:30-18:00, Su 10:00-19:00, closed on Mondays and public holidays and on the day Tour de France finishes in Paris.

points_of_interest.name: Pavillon des Indes
points_of_interest.description: The wooden Indian pavilion was moved from Paris to Courbevoie following the Universal Exhibition of 1878, and remains a curiosity amidst the much more modern architecture of the commune.

points_of_interest.name: Musée Bourdelle
points_of_interest.description: Nestled in Paris's 15th arrondissement, the Musée Bourdelle is a captivating art museum located in the former studio of renowned sculptor Antoine Bourdelle. Open daily except Mondays, visitors can explore the permanent collection for free. The museum beautifully preserves Bourdelle's studio, offering a glimpse into Parisian artistic life from the late 19th to early 20th centuries. It features over 500 works, including sculptures, paintings, and Bourdelle's personal art collection, showcasing pieces by artists like Delacroix and Rodin. After a two-year renovation, the museum reopened in March 2023, inviting visitors to experience Bourdelle's artistic journey in a refreshed setting.

points_of_interest.name: Institut Tessin
points_of_interest.description: The Institut Tessin, nestled in the 3rd arrondissement at 11, rue Payenne, is a hidden gem showcasing the rich history of Franco-Swedish artistic exchanges. Housed in the elegant Hôtel de Marle, this cultural hub offers free admission and is open weekdays, excluding Monday. As Sweden's sole cultural center outside its borders, it highlights a diverse collection of art spanning the 17th to 20th centuries, including works by notable artists like Gustaf Lundberg and Alexander Roslin. Visitors can explore not only the gallery but also a theater, library, Swedish café, and spaces for temporary exhibitions, making it a vibrant destination for culture enthusiasts.

points_of_interest.name: "I love you" wall
points_of_interest.description: The "I love you" wall is a charming and romantic spot that celebrates love in its many forms. This unique attraction features the phrase "I love you" written in hundreds of different languages, creating a vibrant and heartfelt display. Perfect for couples and solo travelers alike, the wall is a beautiful representation of love's universal language. Its colorful and whimsical design makes it a must-visit for anyone looking to experience a touching piece of cultural artistry.

points_of_interest.name: Musée Nationale de la Marine
points_of_interest.description: National Maritime Museum The Paris branch of the National Maritime Museum is closed for renovation until 2021.

points_of_interest.name: Château de Vincennes
points_of_interest.description: The Château de Vincennes is a historic fortress and former royal residence located on the eastern edge of Paris, near the Bois de Vincennes. Built primarily in the 14th century, it served as a favored retreat for French kings for over 200 years. The château is renowned for its impressive keep, the tallest medieval tower in Europe, and the stunning Sainte-Chapelle de Vincennes, a masterpiece of Flamboyant Gothic architecture. Historically, it functioned as a royal sanctuary, prison, and military headquarters. Today, much of the château is open to visitors, offering a glimpse into France's rich medieval past.

points_of_interest.name: Eglise Saint-Médard
points_of_interest.description: The Church of Saint-Médard (French: église Saint-Médard) is a Roman Catholic church located in Tremblay-en-France in the department of Seine-Saint-Denis, France. It is dedicated to Saint Medard and listed as a Class Historic Monument.

points_of_interest.name: The Louvre
points_of_interest.description: Its exhibits come from such diverse origins as ancient Egypt, classical Greece and the Roman Empire, medieval Europe, and Napoleonic France, but controversially including many items that were looted from their places of origin. Its most famous exhibit, of course, is Leonardo da Vinci's painting of the Mona Lisa (French: ''La Joconde'', Italian: ''La Gioconda''), generally to be found surrounded by hordes of camera-flashing tourists. The Louvre poses many of the same challenges to the visitor as Paris itself; overwhelming in size, crowded in high seasons, and much information available only in French. If you want to see everything in the Louvre, plan ''at least'' two full days. However, it is better to pick and choose, as the collection was assembled with an eye to completeness rather than quality. As of July 2019, due to intense crowding and reports of ticket fraud, entry now almost always requires a pre-booked timed ticket, even for holders of the Paris Museum Pass.
points_of_interest.hours: W-M 09:00-18:00, closed public holidays; evening openings W and F until 21:45

points_of_interest.name: Barrière d’Enfer
points_of_interest.description: Barrière d’Enfer, located near the lively Place Denfert-Rochereau in Paris, is a historic landmark that offers a glimpse into the city's past. Once part of the Wall of the Farmers-General, this pair of tollhouses now stands as a charming reminder of Parisian history. While its role as a gate has diminished, the structure seamlessly blends into the modern urban landscape. Visitors can admire its architectural details and historical significance while exploring the surrounding area.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel de Ville
points_of_interest.description: Hôtel de Ville is a stunning 19th-century town hall located on Avenue de Paris, just a short walk from the Château de Versailles. This beautiful building offers a glimpse into the region's history and architecture. Visitors can explore the interior, making it a worthwhile stop for those interested in historic landmarks. Its central location also makes it easily accessible from the nearby Versailles-Rive-Gauche station.

points_of_interest.name: Centre Georges Pompidou
points_of_interest.description: Those who are unfamiliar with conceptual art sometimes don't know quite what to expect, or how to approach it. Such travellers should rest assured that the curators at the Pompidou Centre have assembled a marvellous introduction consisting of mostly approachable works which delight, amuse, and entertain. The art is far from the only reason for a visit, as the building also contains a vast public library and a fine restaurant (run by the Costes brothers) on the roof. In fact the place is ''literally'' surrounded by some of the nicest pavement cafés in the city, in its superb location between the car-free above ground part of Forum Les Halles and the Marais art district.

points_of_interest.name: Jerome de Noirmont
points_of_interest.description: This museum represents some key contemporary and emerging artists such as Jean Pierre Raynaud, Eva and Adele, and Jeff Koons.

points_of_interest.name: Théâtre des Hauts-de-Seine
points_of_interest.description: Théâtre des Hauts-de-Seine is a charming 19th-century theatre that offers a glimpse into the region's rich cultural heritage. With its elegant architecture and historic charm, it provides a unique setting for a variety of performances and events. Visitors can enjoy a diverse program of plays, concerts, and cultural activities, making it a must-visit for both locals and travelers alike. The theatre's intimate atmosphere and acoustic excellence ensure an unforgettable experience for all who step inside.

points_of_interest.name: Musée Mendjisky
points_of_interest.description: Écoles de Paris housed in a Mallet Stevens Building.

points_of_interest.name: Abbesses métro station
points_of_interest.description: Abbesses métro station boasts a stunning entrance designed by Hector Guimard, one of only two remaining glass-covered "dragonfly" structures from 1900. While the entrance is authentic, it was relocated here and did not originally belong to this station. The station gained fame for its appearance in the film *Le Fabuleux destin d'Amélie Poulain*, making it a charming and iconic spot for both metro enthusiasts and movie fans. Its elegant design and cinematic ties make it a must-see for anyone exploring the area.

points_of_interest.name: Musée de l'Homme
points_of_interest.description: Museum of Mankind The Museum of Mankind, accommodated in the Palais du Chaillot, is an anthropological museum covering the history of mankind and human societies.

points_of_interest.name: Palais de la Porte Dorée
points_of_interest.description: Housed in an amazing Art Deco building, purpose-built for the 1931 Colonial Exhibition, featuring an elaborate frieze across the front facade that depicts the achievement of French overseas territories. It houses an [http://www.aquarium-portedoree.fr Aquarium] and an [http://www.histoire-immigration.fr Immigration Museum]. The aquarium can be seen in about an hour and is popular with families with small children.

points_of_interest.name: Eglise Saint Nicolas du Chardonnet
points_of_interest.description:
Saint-Nicolas du Chardonnet is a Catholic church in the centre of Paris, France, in the 5th arrondissement. It was constructed between 1656 and 1763. The facade was designed in the classical style by Charles Le Brun. It contains many notable art works from the 19th century, including a rare religious painting by Jean-Baptiste Corot.

Since the expulsion of the parish priest and his assistants by traditionalist Catholics in 1977, the church has been run by the Society of St. Pius X, which celebrates Traditional Latin Masses there.

points_of_interest.name: Musée de l'Orangerie
points_of_interest.description: Musée de la Orangerie Reopened after extensive renovations, this small museum near the Louvre houses the ''Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume Collection'', sold to the French Republic on very generous terms and numbering 143 paintings from the late 19th century and the first half of the 20th century (15 Cézannes, 24 Renoirs, 10 Matisses, 12 Picassos, 28 Derains, 22 Soutines). The collection joined the eight immense ''Water Lilies'' that Monet gave France in 1922 and which have been displayed since 1927 in two huge oval rooms purpose-built on the artist's instructions.
points_of_interest.hours: W-M (closed Christmas Day and 1 May) individuals 12:30-19:00, Th till 21:00; groups, 09:30-12:30;

points_of_interest.name: Cartier Foundation for Contemporary Art
points_of_interest.description: Fondation Cartier pour l'Art Contemporain A museum of contemporary art. It was founded in 1984 by the well-known jewel and watch manufacturer, Cartier. In 1994 it moved to the new building erected on plans of the architect Jean Nouvel.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel de la Péfecture
points_of_interest.description: Hôtel de la Péfecture is a charming landmark located across from the town hall, offering a beautiful example of elegant architecture. Its striking façade makes it a standout feature in the area, and it serves as a lovely spot for photos or simply to admire its design. While its historical significance adds to its allure, the building’s proximity to the town hall makes it a great place to soak in the local atmosphere and appreciate the blend of history and daily life.

points_of_interest.name: Maison de Victor Hugo
points_of_interest.description: Maison de Victor Hugo is a writer's house museum located where Victor Hugo lived for 16 years between 1832 and 1848. It is one of the 14 City of Paris' Museums that have been incorporated since January 1, 2013 in the public institution Paris Musées.

points_of_interest.name: Musée Cernuschi
points_of_interest.description:
The Musée Cernuschi (French pronunciation: [myze tʃɛʁnuski]; 'Cernuschi Museum'), officially also the Musée des arts de l'Asie de la Ville de Paris ('Asian Arts Museum of the City of Paris'), is an Asian art museum located at 7 avenue Vélasquez, near Parc Monceau, in Paris, France. Its Asian art collection is second in Paris only to that of the Musée Guimet.

The nearest Paris Métro stops to the museum are Villiers or Monceau on Line 2.
points_of_interest.hours: Daily 10:00-17:40. Closed M and public holidays

points_of_interest.name: Villa Léandre
