points_of_interest.description: Villa Léandre is a short residential street where the houses have small front gardens giving the street an English look.

points_of_interest.name: Cité de l'architecture & du patrimoine
points_of_interest.description: City of Architecture & Heritage (former National Museum of French Monuments) The City of Architecture and Heritage, accommodated in the Palais du Chaillot, is a museum and gallery of French architecture. The centrepiece is the spectacular Hall of Casts, a collection of full-size plaster casts of facades, towers, doorways and windows of great buildings from all over France. Architecture of the late 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries is represented by additional galleries of models and images.

points_of_interest.name: Le Musée Fragonard
points_of_interest.description: L'Ecole Nationale Vétérinaire This is a hidden gem. A veterinary museum that doubles as natural history museum. A lot of medical oddities, mostly of animals, but also include real human specimens. Move over Bodyworlds, this museum holds Fragonard's original human preservation (wax, not plastic) including the famous "horseman of the apocalypse."
points_of_interest.hours: Closed in Aug; W Th 14:00-18:00; Sa Su 13:00-18:00

points_of_interest.name: Grande Mosquée de Paris
points_of_interest.description: Grand Mosque of Paris Established in 1926, it was meant to show appreciation for Muslim help in fighting the Germans. The café serves excellent mint tea and North African food.
points_of_interest.address: 2 bis, place du puits de l'Ermite

points_of_interest.name: Jeu de Paume
points_of_interest.description: Built during the First Empire, in imitation of the ''Orangerie'', this small building is used by the ''Galerie Nationale'' to display temporary exhibitions of art photography, either contemporary or historic. This museum once housed many of the Impressionist painters that are now to be found in the Musée d'Orsay on the other side of the River Seine.

points_of_interest.name: The Liberation of Paris, General Leclerc Museum, Jean Moulin Museum
points_of_interest.description: Le Musée de la Liberation de Paris - Musée du Général Leclerc - Musée Jean Moulin Museum documenting Paris at war.

points_of_interest.name: Royal Stables
points_of_interest.description: Academy of Equestrian Arts If you plan to go at the right time, you can even get into a royal horse show. Not only will you get the opportunity to see horses who have been trained by the best of the best perform, but you will also have the chance to see the fascinating royal stables. This is a sight many children often enjoy.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel de Sully
points_of_interest.description: The Hôtel de Sully is a Louis XIII style hôtel particulier, or private mansion, located at 62 rue Saint-Antoine in the Marais, IV arrondissement, Paris, France. Built at the beginning of the 17th century, it is nowadays the seat of the Centre des Monuments Nationaux, the French national organization responsible for national heritage sites. It has been listed since 1862 as a monument historique by the French Ministry of Culture.

points_of_interest.name: Jacquemart-Andre Museum
points_of_interest.description: Jacquemart-Andre Museum Private collection of French, Italian, Dutch masterpieces in a typical XIXth century mansion.

points_of_interest.name: Musée Pasteur
points_of_interest.description: Pasteur Museum The Pasteur Museum is housed in the apartment where the great scientist spent the last 7 years of his life. Hardly touched since that time, the museum is full of personal memorabilia and scientific instruments. Pasteur is buried on the grounds in a flamboyant mosaic-decorated mausoleum. The museum was closed to individual visitors for security reasons after the 13th November 2015 Paris terrorist attacks.

points_of_interest.name: Vigne du Clos Montmartre
points_of_interest.description: Montmartre has a small vineyard which can be seen through a chain-linked fence. One of its products (''vin Clos Montmartre'') can be purchased at the nearby Musée de Montmartre.

points_of_interest.name: Guimet Museum
points_of_interest.description: Searching Wikipedia...

points_of_interest.name: Cinema Museum
points_of_interest.description: La Cinémathèque française Housed in modern building designed by Frank Gehry, contains a cinema showing French & international films, temporary exhibitions lasting about 6 months, Museum dedicated to the history of cinema. Exhibitions are fairly visual.
points_of_interest.hours: Exhibition & Museum M, W-F noon-7PM; Sa-Su 11AM-8PM. closed Tu

points_of_interest.name: Église Saint-Jacques-du-Haut-Pas
points_of_interest.description: Saint-Jacques du Haut-Pas is a Roman Catholic parish church in Paris, France. The church is located at the corner of Rue Saint-Jacques and Rue de l'Abbé de l'Épée in the 5th arrondissement of Paris. The first church on the site, a monastery chapel, was built in 1360. The present church was completed in 1685. The church is  named for Saint-Jacques Du-Haut-Pas," (in English Saint James the Minor), a cousin of Christ and the first bishop of Jerusalem,  who was martyred in the year 60 A.D. It was registered as an historical monument on  4 June 1957.

points_of_interest.name: Musée des Arts Décoratifs
points_of_interest.description: The Musée des Arts Décoratifs is a must-visit museum in Paris, located in the 1st arrondissement within the historic Palais du Louvre. As one of the largest decorative arts museums in Europe, it showcases a vast collection of decorative arts, spanning centuries and styles. From intricate furniture to dazzling jewelry, the museum offers a fascinating glimpse into the evolution of design and craftsmanship. Operated by the MAD arts association since 1882, it remains a cornerstone of Parisian cultural heritage, inviting visitors to explore the beauty and creativity of decorative arts.

points_of_interest.name: The Coach Gallery
points_of_interest.description: A display of several coaches, sedans, and sleds used by 19th century monarchs and presidents of France.

points_of_interest.name: Parc Monceau
points_of_interest.description: One of Paris's best kept secrets, painted by Monet numerous times. It is a very elegant centre of green in the middle of cosmopolitan Paris. Make sure you check out the statues, entrance rotunda and the surrounding mansions. Thanks to Haussmann himself this precious slice of parkland was reserved for the enjoyment and leisure of the people of Paris. It is unusual in France due to its casual, informal "English" style planning, and is a contrast to other Parisian parks such as the classically laid out and formal Luxembourg Gardens and the Tuileries. Randomly placed throughout the park are scaled-down architectural replicas including an Egyptian pyramid, Dutch windmill, and a Chinese fort. Free Wi-Fi in the park.

points_of_interest.name: Jardin atlantique
points_of_interest.description: Escape to the Jardin Atlantique, a serene green oasis perched atop the Gare Montparnasse railway station. This 3.4-hectare park, designed by landscape architects Brun, Penna, and Schnitzler, offers a peaceful retreat from the city bustle. Opened in 1994, it provides a unique blend of modern design and natural beauty, making it a hidden gem for both locals and visitors.
points_of_interest.address: 1, place des Cinq Martyrs du Lycée Buffon

points_of_interest.name: Buste de Dalida
points_of_interest.description: Dalida was a chanteuse and actrice who sold 170 million albums and singles worldwide. The bust faces the attractive Rue de l'Abreuvoir. The breast area of her bronze bust has a bleached colour possibly due attention given by overly enthusiastic admirers.

points_of_interest.name: Jardin d'Acclimatation
points_of_interest.description: The northwest corner of the Bois de Boulogne is occupied by the oldest operating amusement park in the world, the Jardin d'Acclimatation, which is mainly known for offering a wide range of amusements which are appropriate even for very small children. They have miniature roller-coasters for children as small as three years, and the usual range of pony rides etc.
points_of_interest.address: 8 Avenue Du Mahatma Gandhi, 75116 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Musée en Herbe
points_of_interest.description: The little brother of the original Musée en Herbe in the Bois de Boulogne, this museum is also geared to '''children'''. They have games and hands-on exhibits, so you won't have to supervise quite as closely as in other museums. Arts workshops are available as well, but you'll need to reserve a space in advance.

points_of_interest.name: Cathédrale Saint-Louis
points_of_interest.description: Cathédrale Saint-Louis is a historic landmark that offers a glimpse into the region's rich cultural and spiritual heritage. This stunning cathedral, known for its striking architecture, features intricate designs and soaring vaults that create a sense of awe and tranquility. Visitors can admire the beautiful stained-glass windows, which filter in vibrant hues of light, and explore the serene atmosphere that makes it a perfect spot for reflection. The cathedral also hosts various cultural events and religious services throughout the year, making it a must-visit destination for both history enthusiasts and those seeking a peaceful retreat.

points_of_interest.name: Parc André Citroën
points_of_interest.description: The large park occupies the 14 ha formerly occupied by a Citroën factory. Several gardens have specific themes, including water games. On sunny weekends or vacation days many people chill out or jog there.

points_of_interest.name: Le Passe-Muraille
points_of_interest.description: The sculture of a man walking through a store wall like a ghost was inspired by a novel by Marcel Aymé about a civil servant who takes revenge on people who humiliated him after he discovered he could pass through walls.

points_of_interest.name: Jardins du Trocadéro
points_of_interest.description: The Jardins du Trocadéro is a stunning green space located in the 16th arrondissement of Paris, offering breathtaking views of the Eiffel Tower. Situated between the Palais de Chaillot and the Seine River, the gardens provide a serene escape in the heart of the city. Visitors can enjoy the beautifully landscaped grounds, perfect for picnics or simply taking in the iconic scenery. The Pont d'Iéna crosses the Seine nearby, connecting the gardens to the Eiffel Tower, making this spot a must-visit for photography enthusiasts and anyone looking to experience Paris' timeless beauty.
points_of_interest.address: 12 Avenue Gustave V De Suède, 75016 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Bourse de commerce - Pinault Collection
points_of_interest.description: Commodities Exchange Building Since 2021 the 18th-century former Bourse de Commerce building has been the Paris home of the art collection of the French business magnate François Pinault, showing a rotating selection of contemporary artworks either newly commissioned or taken from his collection.
points_of_interest.hours: W-Mo 11:00-19:00. Closed Tu. Fr and first Sa of month late opening until 21:00

points_of_interest.name: The Royal Tennis Court
points_of_interest.description: Salle du Jeu de Paume Site of the Tennis Court Oath, a pivotal event during the beginning of the French Revolution
points_of_interest.address: 1 Rue Du Jeu De Paume, 78000 Versailles, France

points_of_interest.name: Parc Georges-Brassens
points_of_interest.description: Parc Georges-Brassens  is a public park located in the 15th arrondissement of Paris, between rue des Morillons and rue de Périchaux.  Opened in 1984, it occupies 7.74 hectares on the site of a former fish market, horse market and slaughterhouse, and preserves some of the old market structures.  It is named for the French popular singer Georges Brassens (1921–1981) who lived in the neighborhood of the park at 9 impasse Florimont and 42 rue Santos Dumont.   The nearest metro stations to the park are Convention and Porte-de-Vanves.

points_of_interest.name: Villa La Roche
points_of_interest.description:
Villa La Roche, also Maison La Roche, is a house in Paris, designed by Le Corbusier and his cousin Pierre Jeanneret in 1923–1925. It was designed for Raoul La Roche, a Swiss banker from Basel and collector of avant-garde art. Villa La Roche now houses the Fondation Le Corbusier.

La Roche commissioned Le Corbusier to build a villa as well as a gallery to house his art collection.

In July 2016, the house, Villa Jeanneret, and sixteen other works by Le Corbusier were inscribed as UNESCO World Heritage Sites.

points_of_interest.name: The municipal library
points_of_interest.description: In the former Louis XIV's ministry of foreign affairs, 5 rue de l'Indépendance Américaine. You can enter on opening hours. They also organise open-doors on certain days, to get a glimpse inside the old cabinets.
points_of_interest.address: 5 Rue De L'indépendance Américaine, 78000 Versailles, France

points_of_interest.name: Parc des Expositions
points_of_interest.description:
The Parc des expositions de Paris-Nord Villepinte (English: Paris Nord Villepinte) is a large convention center located in Villepinte near Paris-Charles de Gaulle Airport. The center opened in 1982 and is the second-largest in France.

The center encompasses 115 hectares and has 246,000 m2 of convention space in eight halls. The center is served by the Parc des Expositions station on the RER B. Paris Nord Villepinte is one metro stop from Charles de Gaulle Airport and 30 minutes from Gare du Nord, Chatelet-Les Halles, Saint Michel RER B stations in Paris city.

points_of_interest.name: Villa Jeanneret
points_of_interest.description:
Villa Jeanneret and Villa La Roche are two houses in Paris, designed by Le Corbusier and Pierre Jeanneret in 1923-1925 and renovated by Charlotte Perriand in 1928. No longer inhabited, they house the Fondation Le Corbusier museum and archives. They are located at 8-10 square du Docteur-Blanche, 16th arrondissement, Paris. Villa Jeanneret is not open to the public.

In July 2016, the house, Villa La Roche, and several other works by Le Corbusier were inscribed as UNESCO World Heritage Sites.

points_of_interest.name: Église Notre-Dame
points_of_interest.description:
The church was built at the command of Louis XIV by Jules Hardouin-Mansart in the French Baroque architectural style (also known as French Classicism) and was consecrated on 30 October 1686. The parish of Notre-Dame included the Palace of Versailles and thus registered the baptisms, marriages and burials of the French royal family.

In 1791 it was declared a cathedral but converted to a Temple of Reason in 1793. After the Revolution the bishop of Versailles chose instead as his seat the Church of Saint-Louis (the present Versailles Cathedral).

Between 1858 and 1873, a new chapel was added by the architect Le Poittevin, who also built the market-halls of the Marché Notre-Dame.

The church contains sculptures by Pierre Mazzeline and Noël Jouvenet.

The church has been classed as a monument historique since 4 August 2005.

points_of_interest.name: The Musee Lambinet
points_of_interest.description: It is housed in a beautiful 18th century home and displays many 18th century furnishings such as ceramics, sculptures, paintings, furniture, and other objects that are a part of Versailles' history, some of which are from the revolutionary period. People who appreciate fine arts and history will definitely want to make this a stop during their trip. Text only in French.
points_of_interest.address: 50 Boulevard De La Reine, 78000 Versailles, France

points_of_interest.name: Domaine de Madame Élisabeth
points_of_interest.description: Domaine de Madame Élisabeth is a charming park surrounding the country retreat of Princess Elisabeth. Nestled near Paris, it offers a serene escape from the city. Visitors can explore the beautifully landscaped grounds, enjoy leisurely strolls along winding trails, and take in the picturesque views. This historic estate provides a peaceful atmosphere, perfect for those seeking a relaxing day outdoors.

points_of_interest.name: Paroisse Saint Symphorien de Versailles
points_of_interest.description: Take a trip to this quaint and beautifully constructed chapel, dedicated to Saint Symphorien. It is a landmark in history dating all the way back to 560. In 1722 a monk requested the expansion of the chapel believing it was far too small to hold services and his request was answered years later under the order of Louis XV. This chapel contains classic and gorgeous architecture as well as beautiful historical paintings. Any one who travel to this chapel can not help but to fall in love with the cascading decor.

points_of_interest.name: Arboretum de Chèvreloup
points_of_interest.description: The Arboretum de Versailles-Chèvreloup is a beautiful arboretum located just north of the Palace of Versailles. As part of the Muséum national d'histoire naturelle, it offers a peaceful retreat with a diverse collection of plant species. Visitors can explore the grounds during the warmer months, making it a great addition to a day trip to Versailles. This serene destination provides a natural escape from the bustling palace grounds.
points_of_interest.address: 32 Route De Versailles, 78150 Le Chesnay-Rocquencourt, France

points_of_interest.name: Artazart
points_of_interest.description: A bookshop, specializing in design & graphic design. Lots of imports.

points_of_interest.name: Marché St-Quentin
points_of_interest.description: Market that offers a variety of goods from flowers and produce to antiques and candies.

points_of_interest.name: Boulangerie Utopie
points_of_interest.description: This prize-winning "destination boulangerie" is worth a detour. There is always waiting line so be patient. Only four stools and a small bar. Diverse bakery of many breads and pastry selections. Pastries range from elegant to purely simple. Fresh sandwiches on rustic baguettes are excellent. Discount menu combinations offered at lunch. English spoken.

points_of_interest.name: Du Pain et des Idées
points_of_interest.description: One of the best new bakeries in Paris.

points_of_interest.name: La Gallerie Vivienne
points_of_interest.description: Start with the best preserved of the galleries and whose décor has been maintained in authentic colours from the era. It's really the mosaic floor which is the star of the show. The shops are distinctly upscale, and all about conspicuous consumption: a wine seller, a tea shop, and a dealer in antique books are among the highlights.

points_of_interest.name: Puzzle Michèle Wilson
points_of_interest.description: Hand-made wooden puzzles, games, brain teasers and original playing cards by a French artisan featuring jigsaw puzzles for adults and children since 1975.

points_of_interest.name: Citypharma Du Four Bonaparte
points_of_interest.description: Cosmetic products of famous brands like "Avène", "Vichy" and "La Roche" can be bought cheaper here.

points_of_interest.name: Passage Choiseul
points_of_interest.description: A considerably more down-to-earth gallery, the passage mainly serves traders on their way to the bourse, with the same class of shops that one might find in a pedestrian tunnel in New York or Chicago: a shoeshine stand, a newsstand, and little almost-but-not-quite fast-food restaurants.

points_of_interest.name: Galeries Lafayette
points_of_interest.description: Founded in 1894, and is the flagship store of the department store chain. The ''gourmet'' section is a Paris institution that takes up an entire floor, featuring (among many other things) several competing vendors of deluxe baguettes, a few hundred types of cheese, and an entire aisle devoted to mustard. Depending on your home country you may be eligible for a 10% discount for all goods (you just need to show a flyer that is attached to tourist office Paris maps).

points_of_interest.name: La Chambre Claire
points_of_interest.description: La librairie de la photographie The library is specialised on books about photography. They regularly organise book signings.

points_of_interest.name: Magasin Variantes
points_of_interest.description: Boutique Variantes All kind of games are sold here, logic, go and check of course too.

points_of_interest.name: Malongo Café
points_of_interest.description: Sells all kind of different Malongo café's. Next to the shop is a nice little bar to directly taste different ones.

points_of_interest.name: Le Bon Marché
points_of_interest.description: One of the world's first department stores, the oldest and one of the largest in modern Paris.

points_of_interest.name: Les 4 Temps
points_of_interest.description: The Quatre Temps shopping mall, which when constructed was the largest shopping centre in Europe, has numerous big name and small stores, several cinemas (showing French and subtitled foreign movies) as well as a large supermarket and grocery store. It is accessible from an entrance to the left of the "Grande Arche" or via the metro station. 230 stores (Auchan, C&A, Darty, Virgin, Zara, Go Sport, H&M, Uniqlo, Toys’R’Us), 16 movie theater screens, 40 restaurants.

points_of_interest.name: Marché bio Boulevard Raspail
points_of_interest.description: The market sells organic fruits and vegetables.

points_of_interest.name: Rue Montorgueil pedestrian area
points_of_interest.description: Rue Montorgueil is like a scene from a movie. Closed to traffic, the street is a food-lovers delight, with cafes, bars, and all types of fresh produce for sale in the open air.

points_of_interest.name: Magasin Sennelier
points_of_interest.description: Couleurs du Quai Voltaire In 1887 Gustave Sennelier founded this house next to the Ecole des Beaux Arts.

points_of_interest.name: Pâtisserie Sadaharu Aoki
points_of_interest.description: Japanese interpretation of French patisserie.

points_of_interest.name: Terroirs d'Avenir
points_of_interest.description: Slow food distribution on three different stores: a grocer, a fish monger and a butcher. They all source fresh, quality, mostly organic produce.

points_of_interest.name: Rue Cler
points_of_interest.description: Market street 10 minutes from the Eiffel Tower. The market is at its best on Tu–Sa, 08:30–13:00 or 15:00–19:30; Su, 08:30–12:00; closed on M.

points_of_interest.name: Marché aux fleurs Reine-Elizabeth-II
points_of_interest.description: Flower Market and Bird Market On the north side of the ''Ile de la Cité'', the main island at the centre of Paris you'll find a burgeoning daily flower market, where you can buy just about any type of flower, and oddly enough, a range of exotic tropical birds.

points_of_interest.name: La librairie gourmande
points_of_interest.description: The book shop is specialized on books for chefs, interested cooks or foodies.

points_of_interest.name: l'Epée de Bois
points_of_interest.description: The name of the store and the street it's on both translate to the "wooden sword", and you find those here along with any number of wooden toys for children ages 1 to 10. They also have books and games.

points_of_interest.name: Opéra BD
points_of_interest.description: Comics (''Bandes Dessinées'') are a serious art form in France and even regular corporate bookstores have a good selection, but it's much better to look for them where they are really appreciated, in one of Paris's many private BD dealers. This one is friendly, well stocked, and keeps late hours so pay them a visit if you would like to pick up a copy of one of the many volumes of ''Lone Wolf and Cub'' in French.

points_of_interest.name: La Fontaine aux Vins
points_of_interest.description: One of several wine shops along the lower part of the street. The wines are of high quality, but barely more pricey than the ones you'll find in the grocery store. They offer tastings outside on the street, and delivery if you buy a case. Prices start at around €4 per bottle which is around what you'll pay for a glass in a bar.

points_of_interest.name: Mariage Frères
points_of_interest.description: If you love tea, you'll love this old salon de the in the Marais.

points_of_interest.name: Carre Marigny
points_of_interest.description: The open-air market for trading postage stamps and other similar collectibles

points_of_interest.name: Gepetto & Vélos
points_of_interest.description: OK, so if you are just staying for a day or two it makes no sense whatever to buy a bike, but if you are going to be around for a while having your own might just feel better than renting one from the RATP. If so, you could do a lot worse than Gepetto, where you'll find a range of real bikes rather than the usual cheap MTB you'd see at a sporting goods store. Prices start at around €100 for a sturdy used, 3-speed city bike.

points_of_interest.name: BHV
points_of_interest.description: Bazar de l'Hôtel de Ville Is a general store with most of everything: clothes, perfumes, furniture, you name it—it's especially famous for its basement section, dedicated to handiwork & DIY --think of it as a small ''Home Depot'' in a basement, though with French hardware and house and garden accessories that look distinctive in other settings.

points_of_interest.name: C42
points_of_interest.description: C42 is the flasghip Citroen store occupying an entire building, designed by Manuelle Gautrand and completed in 2007, being the first new building in the Avenue in some 30 years. The unmistakable facade is inspired by Citroen's chevron logo, and the building has no less than seven storeys exhibiting Citroen's past, present and future, including iconic classics, the concept cars and winning sportscars from its many decades of history, and of course the current lineup. The interior is just as spectacular and unique as the exterior and well worth a visit.

points_of_interest.name: Shakespeare and Co.
points_of_interest.description: Probably one of the most eccentric bookstores you will ever visit, this must-see was established in 1951 by George Whitman. Three rambling floors literally crammed with books, both new and (mainly) second-hand. The bedding shoved amid the shelves is for the (largely American) expats (called tumbleweeds) who doss down here at night. It is the sister store to City Lights in San Francisco.

points_of_interest.name: Atelier Renault
points_of_interest.description: Renault has opened its Champs-Elysees showroom at this location in 1910. The highlight of its current form, launched in 2011, is the cafe/restaurant/bar in the "floating" mezzanine, where you can enjoy some good drinks and food as well as a nice view over the Champs Elysees and the Renault cars from the past and present exhibited below.

points_of_interest.name: Antoine
points_of_interest.description: This shop sells stylish umbrellas and old-style canes, meant to last a lifetime. Also fancy hats, scarfs and gloves.

points_of_interest.name: Marché aux Puces de St-Ouen
points_of_interest.description: Clignancourt Flea Market Widely-acclaimed as the largest flea market in all of Europe, in existence since 1885, this sprawling bazaar is made up of both permanent stalls and temporary stands (over 2,000 of them), arranged in winding, sometimes chaotic arcades, over 15 km of walkways, and over 10 differently-themed sub-markets. Everything from fine antiques through to collectible kitsch and bric-a-brac. Big on retro fashion also. Very popular with tourists, making it more difficult here to find a real bargain, but it is always worth looking. Convenient, competitive shipping is available at the market to send your precious finds back home all over the world. Be prepared to bargain!

points_of_interest.name: Carrefour Express Paris Saint Honoré
points_of_interest.description: A small version of the French Carrefour supermarket chain has the appearance of a neighbourhood shop, with stalls filled with fresh fruit and vegetables on its shopfront, and is about the only place to get reasonably-priced nourishment and beverages on the go when visiting the Vendôme area.

points_of_interest.name: Avenue Peugeot
points_of_interest.description: While not as spectacular from the outside as its sister brand Citroen's building, the Avenue Peugeot is also worth a visit if you are a car fan, as it always has a temporary exhibition of some of Peugeot's concept or competition cars the brand is famous for. You can obviously also explore the regular range of Peugeot cars and purchase one, as well as an extensive range of Peugeot merchandise from the on-site "boutique Peugeot", including the Peugeot condiment grinders the company makes for much longer than it does build cars.

points_of_interest.name: Ouistitipop
points_of_interest.description: New and used kids' clothing, toys, strollers and furniture. They take consignments too.

points_of_interest.name: Le Carrousel du Louvre
points_of_interest.description: A diverse underground shopping precinct adjoining the Louvre Museum. Open daily including Sundays. There is also a direct access into the Louvre.

points_of_interest.name: Louis Vuitton Building
points_of_interest.description: An unmistakable piece of modernist architecture at the corner of Avenue George V, the Louis Vuitton Building was erected in 1913 and in the 21st century continues to serve as the flagship for the luxury brand, housing the largest Louis Vuitton boutique in the world.

points_of_interest.name: Thibault van der Straete
points_of_interest.description: Clothing boutique featuring designs made of the rare and luxurious alpaca wool. His soft and sumptuous men's and women's designs are a favourite of those enchanted by ethno-chic.

points_of_interest.name: Forum les Halles
points_of_interest.description: In the late 1960s what was Paris's primary farmers' market moved out to the suburbs to be replaced by a park above ground, and a sprawling underground shopping centre below. The interior design is strikingly period (think ''Logan's Run''). The place is showing its age now, but still draws nearly a half-million Parisians per day, mostly teenagers. There's a movie theatre and a media library too. Les Halles underwent extensive refurbishment in 2016.

points_of_interest.name: Spree
points_of_interest.description: Hip and trendy bazaar that features designs and clothes from all around the world. Its large space also hold artist exhibitions.

points_of_interest.name: Jean-Paul Hévin
points_of_interest.description: The chocolatier is known for his excellent hand made chocolates especially the "praliné croquant".

points_of_interest.name: Au Marché de la Butte
points_of_interest.description: Maison Collignon The grocery store featured in the film ''Le Fabuleux destin d'Amélie Poulain'' still functions as such but also displays memorabilia from the film in its windows, and sells some as souvenirs.

points_of_interest.name: Librairie Galignani
points_of_interest.description: British and American bookshop, specialising in fine arts.

points_of_interest.name: Beaugrenelle Shopping Center
points_of_interest.description: The mall has 10 movie theaters, shops and restaurants.

points_of_interest.name: Minuit Moins 7
points_of_interest.description: The "cordonnerie" repairs shoes and leather with the best materials.

points_of_interest.name: Fromagerie aux produits d'Auvergne
points_of_interest.description: The small shop sells delicious cheese from all over France plus excellent organic eggs. The owners give hints according to ones taste.

points_of_interest.name: Rue de Passy
points_of_interest.description: Lined with high-end clothes and homewares shops

points_of_interest.name: Laurent Dubois
points_of_interest.description: The cheese shop has a number of choices and let you taste their newest. Plus usually one gets interesting personalized guidance.

points_of_interest.name: Passy Plaza
points_of_interest.description: Includes a large supermarket and several mid-range retailers

points_of_interest.name: Lorenz Bäumer
points_of_interest.description: On her wedding day Princess Charlène de Monaco wore a Lorenz Bäumer tiara. This new jewellery-maker fashions novel forms combined with classical influences.

points_of_interest.name: Marché du livre ancien et d'occasion
points_of_interest.description: Antique and second-hand books are sold.

points_of_interest.name: Van Cleef & Arpels
points_of_interest.description: Princess Caroline de Monaco got her wedding ornament at this traditional shop, open since 1906.

points_of_interest.name: Hermes flagship store
points_of_interest.description: Hermes has been occupying those premises since 1880, contributing to the street's long-lasting reputation as the hub for luxury apparel and accessories.

points_of_interest.name: Aux Merveilleux de Fred
points_of_interest.description: Meringues and meringues, all colors, all sizes.

points_of_interest.name: Patek Philippe Salons
points_of_interest.description: The Swiss luxury watch manufacturer, founded in 1851, is known for precise mechanics.

points_of_interest.name: Lanvin flagship store
points_of_interest.description: Jeanne Lanvin moved her ''maison de couture'' to premises facing Hermes in 1889, where it remained to this day.
points_of_interest.address: 22 Rue Du Faubourg Saint-Honoré, 75008 Paris, France

points_of_interest.name: Roulez Champions
points_of_interest.description: The bike shop repairs any kinds of bikes. They are specialized in selling folding bikes.

points_of_interest.name: W.H. Smith
points_of_interest.description: The largest English-language bookshop in Paris carries many of the newest releases.

points_of_interest.name: Village Suisse
points_of_interest.description: Quality antique dealers and galleries.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Bridget
points_of_interest.description: 3-star hotel, which opened in 2020. Very good online ratings.

points_of_interest.name: Boulogne Résidence Hôtel
points_of_interest.description: 3 stars.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Scarlett
points_of_interest.description: Another 3-star hotel with happy guests according to their online ratings.

points_of_interest.name: Auberge de Jeunesse Paris Le d'Artagnan
points_of_interest.description: Popular Youth Hostel (IYHA), 135 rooms with 1-9 beds. Breakfast Included in price. A good basic budget option if you like this sort of thing. Private rooms are also available.

points_of_interest.name: Adagio La Défense Esplanade
points_of_interest.description: Accor's mid-range aparthotel is right off the Esplanade, next door to Sofitel .
points_of_interest.address: 31 Esplanade Du Général De Gaulle, 92800 Puteaux, France

points_of_interest.name: St Christopher’s Inns Paris Hostel
points_of_interest.description: A brand new purpose built hostel in Paris opened in 2008.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Crimee
points_of_interest.description: Close to the Metro, the hotel boasts a quick and easy connection to downtown Paris.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Novotel Paris La Défense
points_of_interest.description: A rather generic, modern Novotel, with "executive rooms" providing global standards, and the regular rooms the standard French Novotel fare with toothpaste-inspired bathroom fit-outs. Some rooms (available at a small extra) provide views over the river Seine.

points_of_interest.name: Jack's
points_of_interest.description: On a very quiet street. Jean Genet died in this hotel in 1986.

points_of_interest.name: Fraser Suites Harmonie Paris La Défense
points_of_interest.description: A higher-end apart-hotel close to the Esplanade de la Défense metro station

points_of_interest.name: ibis Paris la Villette Cite des Sciences
points_of_interest.description: Hotel with view of the Junction of the Canals Ourcq & St Denis from rooms at the front of the hotel.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Eldorado
points_of_interest.description: A former ''maison de rendez-vous'', a home to the kept women of the 19th century bourgeois. Now a very cute ''no'' star hotel, its charm more than makes up for what it lacks in amenities (who needs a TV in Paris anyway?). The staff is super friendly, the decor is garage sale chic, and there's a lovely courtyard that fills with neighbourhood hipsters on warm evenings. It also has a very good location & you can easily avoid the noise of Pigalle or Montmartre's high prices, but they're within stumble distance if you decide to explore. For early risers breakfast (€5, until 10ː00) is served in the attached restaurant/bar. Some English spoken, especially for those who pet the cat sprawled across the reception desk.

points_of_interest.name: Hilton
points_of_interest.description: The Hilton is part of the CNIT convention centre.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Elysées Parc Monceau
points_of_interest.description: Three star charm in an outstanding residential district, just around the corner from Parc Monceau.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Pullman Paris La Défense
points_of_interest.description: Renovated in 2013 as a part of Accor's initiative to refurbish all five Pullmans in Paris. Less expensive rooms retain much of the 1990s-style furniture, while the more expensive ones conform better to the current Pullman corporate standards.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Prince Albert Monceau
points_of_interest.description: Free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Best Western Opéra d'Antin
points_of_interest.description: When you exit Hotel Best Western Opéra d’Antin and leave the large department stores behind you (Galeries Lafayette & Le Printemps), just cross boulevard Haussmann and you will find yourself before the Opera Garnier.

points_of_interest.name: Holiday Inn Express Paris Place d'Italie
Sofitel La Défense
points_of_interest.description: There is nothing truly exceptional about the Sofitel La Défense, and the views out of the windows are downright unspectacular compared to other La Défense hotels, but this hotel garners good reviews by providing solid standards and reliable service for a fraction of the prices of downtown Sofitels. The hotel was renovated after 2010, with all but the cheapest ''Classic'' rooms getting new furnishings and bathrooms (with showers rather than bathtubs, a Paris rarity).

points_of_interest.name: Hotel George Opera
points_of_interest.description: Friendly and English speaking staff. Free Wi-Fi in the rooms.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel de Maubeuge
points_of_interest.description: Simple and decent.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Acacias Etoile
points_of_interest.description: A clean, well run hotel in the side streets near Place Charles de Gaulle. The staff is friendly, the rooms aren't large, but they are immaculate.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Ampère
points_of_interest.description: One of the most inexpensive luxury 4 star hotels in Paris. A garden in the heart of the elegant 17th arrondissement, not far from the Arc de Triomphe and the Champs Elysées.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Saint Quentin
points_of_interest.description: Quiet location in a little street, just in front of the Gare du Nord.

points_of_interest.name: Mercure Paris Arc de Triomphe Etoile
points_of_interest.description: Modern rooms featuring frosted glass and stiff curtain dividers between sleeping areas and bathrooms, which may not be to everybody's liking. The most expensive rooms enjoy terraces with views over the 17th all the way to La Défense.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Formula 1
points_of_interest.description: Very cheap private rooms, close enough to the metro to make it worth it. Rooms are very clean, and have TV, free Wi-Fi, and washbasin only. Shared showers and toilets. The showers are fine, but, there are no toilet-seats and no urinals (thus, the shared toilets get very nasty, very fast and people have to go back to their rooms to wash their hands in their washbasin), so the quality of the bathrooms may keep this hotel chain out of reach for serious germ-a-phobes. It is, nevertheless, cheaper for two people to stay here than just about any youth hostel in Paris. Nice and safe neighbourhood, too, with several supermarkets and kebab vendors for eats.
points_of_interest.address: 23, av de la Porte de Chatillon

points_of_interest.name: Mercure Gobelins
points_of_interest.address: 8 bis, av de la Soeur Rosalie

points_of_interest.name: Novotel Paris 17 Porte d'Asnières
points_of_interest.description: A typical Novotel in a faraway corner of the 17th, not really close to anything nor particularly conveniently located.

points_of_interest.name: Urban Bivouac
points_of_interest.description: 3-star hotel, 32 rooms.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Secret de Paris
points_of_interest.description: Boutique hotel of 29 rooms.

points_of_interest.name: Hyatt Regency Paris Étoile
points_of_interest.description: former Concorde Lafayette The tallest hotel in Paris is the lone skyscraper in the northwest of Paris, adjacent to the Palais du Congres. It enjoys an unobstructed line of sight towards the Eiffel Tower from the rooms facing it and its top-floor bar. After Hyatt took over the property, it is being gradually updated, but still not entirely up to the best Hyatt worldwide standards.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Aiglon
points_of_interest.description: Bunuel and Giacometti stayed in this hotel, which has good views, just next to the metro.

points_of_interest.name: Austin's Arts et Metiers Hôtel
points_of_interest.description: The rooms are small (as usual) and kept very clean. You are best off asking for something facing the front since the central courtyard is not very attractive. Particularly the 6th floor rooms are said to be quite nice.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Bonne Nouvelle
points_of_interest.description: Old world charm.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Le Quartier Bercy - Square
points_of_interest.description: Hotel Le Quartier Bercy Square, located in the 12th arrondissement, is right between Metro stations Dugommier and Daumesnil (Lines 6 and 8). It has easy access to Palais Omnisports at Bercy, Cours St. Emillon with its lively area of shops, restaurants, and bars, and train stations Gare de Bercy and Gare de Lyon. And with Line 14 at Bercy station just down the road, the rest of Paris is only minutes from you.

points_of_interest.name: Le Méridien Etoile
points_of_interest.description: The very first Le Meridien in the world, built in 1972 to cater for Air France passengers arriving on the newly-acquired widebody jets. Behind the distinctive 1970s facade are updated rooms and common areas with contemporary design and facilities. The hotel faces the Palais du Congres and caters mostly for business travellers. This is the largest hotel by room count in Paris, with 1,025 rooms of various types. The less expensive Classic and Deluxe rooms have more dated decor, the Urban and Executive rooms have been thoroughly updated to 21st century standards.

points_of_interest.name: L'hôtel du Lion
points_of_interest.description: An independent hotel on Place Denfert-Rochereau, near Montparnasse.

points_of_interest.name: Auberge Internationale des Jeunes
points_of_interest.description: Rooms available for 2-4 persons. Price Includes are breakfast, shower, pillow, blanket and bed sheet for the mattress, access to the luggage room use of safe deposit box at the front desk. Age limit 30 years.

points_of_interest.name: Paris Hotel
points_of_interest.description: 3 star near Pigalle. The rooms are of decent quality and the views of the street are charming and typically Parisian (lots of balconies and shutters at the front, and a pleasant garden view at the back.) There's free Wi-Fi in the rooms and a nice breakfast room. The street can get a little noisy at night, but that's typical of the area and probably not enough to keep you awake but you should be aware in case you happen to be a light sleeper. There is a Renault parking garage round the corner which charged €52 for 72 hours.

points_of_interest.name: AIJ Paris
points_of_interest.description: Auberge Internationale des Jeunes Some sites (including their own) says they are a youth-only hostel, but there do not enforce any age restrictions. Wifi and a small non-buffet continental breakfast is included. Each room has a sink, but the top sheet for each bunk is not included and will cost extra if you don't just want the blanket. No alcohol is allowed in the hostel. The hostel is 24 hr but the rooms close between 11:00-15:00 for cleaning.

points_of_interest.name: Renaissance Paris Arc de Triomphe
points_of_interest.description: The Renaissance is a thoroughly modern property with floor-to-ceiling windows in the posh Avenue Wagram, just a short walk from Place de l'Étoile. The building was designed by the same Christian de Portzamparc who gave the Palais du Congres its current appearance.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Le M
points_of_interest.description: The hotel offers 59 fully renovated, comfortable and soundproofed rooms, in an elegant designer setting.

points_of_interest.name: Bastille Hostel
points_of_interest.description: This youth hostel features 29 rooms, some shared, some restricted to females only. Apartments available.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Saint Petersbourg Opéra
points_of_interest.description: Founded in 1860, this elegant historic hotel was upgraded in 2016 to become a four-star hotel after a refit of some of its most important sections.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Apostrophe
points_of_interest.description: Hôtel Poème Set between Montparnasse and the Jardin du Luxembourg public park, near Saint-Germain-des-Prés, the Apostrophe hotel offers you an atmosphere full of poetry.16 guest rooms equipped with all the modern comfort, jet showers with light or "Chromo" jacuzzi-bath, audio CD & DVD player, complimentary Wi-Fi access.Each room has its own decor and invites you in a unique setting. Gay-friendly.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Voltaire République
points_of_interest.description: A few steps away from Republic Square. Local bakery, supermarket, laundry, and many other services are close to the hotel. All rooms are en suite, with TV and direct dial telephone. Wi-Fi is available in room.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Scribe
points_of_interest.description: Crown jewel in the Sofitel chain and owned by Pakistan's national carrier PIA, this elegantly redecorated 4 star hotel hasn't lost any of its charm since it was first opened in 1895. All rooms are sound proofed and come with Wi-Fi. The apartments have a separate entrance and they can provide you with a nanny if needed.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Le Saint Gregoire
points_of_interest.description: On a small, quiet street, the Hotel Le Saint-Gregoire has 20 rooms decorated by David Hicks with antique furnishings, paintings and lamps purchased by the owner. All rooms are air conditioned and equipped with Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Tiquetonne Hôtel
points_of_interest.description: Closed during August, and between Christmas and New Year's.

points_of_interest.name: Pullman Paris Montparnasse
points_of_interest.description: formerly Le Meridien Montparnasse, and built as Sheraton Paris The gargantuan former Le Meridien was taken over by Accor's upscale brand Pullman and saw a complete renovation of its massive building housing 953 hotel rooms (the largest room count in Paris) on 26 floors. It has all the pros and cons of a huge business hotel, plus the added value of sweeping vistas from its rooms, due to its unusual height (116 metres) versus the Paris average.

points_of_interest.name: Au Royal Mad
points_of_interest.description: Budget hotel, with free toiletries, fridge, microwave, and TV in the rooms, and toilets & showers in the corridors. A stone's throw from Place Léon Blum (supermarket, bars, etc.) and Voltaire metro. Friendly staff. There is a room set aside for leaving luggage on the last day. Powerful, free wifi.

points_of_interest.name: Le Clos Medicis
points_of_interest.description: This charming little hotel is only steps from the ''Jardin du Luxembourg'' and has air-conditioning in every room, and a very cozy - and usually empty - bar in the lobby in which to wind down after a day of exploring, if you and your travelling companions need some quiet time. The helpful staff speaks English readily (some even as a first language), and the usual continental breakfast is served in the lovely (but tiny) courtyard every morning 07:00-11:00.

points_of_interest.name: Timhôtel Best Western Tour Eiffel Invalides
Hotel Le Bellechasse Saint-Germain
points_of_interest.description: The Bellechasse converted into a delightful hotel, full of character, being altogether impressive and intimate, entirely dressed by Christian Lacroix. In the heart of the left bank, between the 7th aristocratic and the 6th artistic districts, this elegant private hotel is now a real jewel of "haute couture".

points_of_interest.name: Le Général Hôtel
points_of_interest.description: 3-star hotel. They've certainly put a certain amount of budget into graphic and interior design. Breakfast is not included.

points_of_interest.name: Le Hameau de Passy
points_of_interest.description: Clean, quiet and good value hotel located in the centre of the Passy area

points_of_interest.name: Pullman Paris Bercy
points_of_interest.description: formerly Sofitel Paris Bercy The former Sofitel was demoted to Pullman, but has since been afforded a thorough renovation (finished in autumn of 2013) to bring it up to current Pullman brand standards along with other Pullman hotels in Paris. Friendly and helpful staff.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Esmerelda
points_of_interest.description: An excellent example of what happens when a "find" hotel is discovered by the travel guides, the Esmerelda has lost none of its charm, but the prices have crept up into nearly the two-star range, and you'll have to book ahead by at least a couple of months in the high season or around the winter holidays. On the plus side the place really does deserve the attention (and solid bookings), as it really is super charming, the welcome couldn't possibly be better and it's still on the cheap side. Try not to trip over the ample knick-knacks in your room, which will likely be named after a French singing star.

points_of_interest.name: Grand Hotel Français
points_of_interest.description: The Grand Hotel Français Paris has been operated by the same family for over 100 years. They're quite proud of their hotel-operations lore handed down through the generations.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Eiffel Kennedy
points_of_interest.description: Small three star hotel (33 rooms).

points_of_interest.name: Park Hyatt Paris - Vendome
points_of_interest.description: Palatial hotel with a residential feel and personalised service. Within walking distance of Place Vendôme.

points_of_interest.name: Grand Hôtel Nouvel Opera
points_of_interest.description: 3-star hotel.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Au Manoir Saint Germain des Prés
points_of_interest.description: In front of the Cafe de Flore and Aux Deux Magots offering guests a view over these two cafés and the Church of Saint Germain des Prés. Refurbished in 2008.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Gavarni
points_of_interest.description: In the heart of the Passy village and its fashion boutiques. It's the first independent hotel in Paris to have been awarded the European Ecolabel. Fully air-conditioned, free WiFi.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Stendhal Place Vendôme Paris - MGallery Collection
Hôtel du Nord et de l'Est
points_of_interest.description: Found among a cluster of two-star hotels off of Place de la République, the North and East has been in the process lately of doing some renovation, bringing ''some'' of the rooms up to high three-star standards. Regardless of which type of room you book the place is quiet and cheerful and has Wi-Fi. It's a good value, and to top it off they often have vacancies when all of the hotels in more popular quarters are booked.

points_of_interest.name: Holiday Inn Paris Elysees
points_of_interest.description: Contemporary 4-star hotel near Champs Elysees and rue Faubourg Saint-Honoré.

points_of_interest.name: l'Hôtel
points_of_interest.description: This hotel is beautiful inside, with baroque and modern rooms. There is a hamam style pool and sauna in the basement which can be reserved for clients of the hotel, and the restaurant is good too. Oscar Wilde lived and died here.

points_of_interest.name: Mon Hotel
points_of_interest.description: A boutique hotel in the vicinity of Place d'Etoile

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Cujas Pantheon
points_of_interest.description: A small and tidy hotel situated on a quiet side street right beside the Sorbonne University and 5 min walking distance from the nearest métro station (Cluny-La Sorbonne) and the Panthéon.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Hor Les Lumiéres
points_of_interest.description: A budget hotel just a bit from République which offers a fitness centre, and free Wi-Fi, though "Le Marais" is a bit of a stretch.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Le Lavoisier
points_of_interest.description: Brands itself as a boutique hotel, with unique décor combining classical and contemporary in a Haussmann-style building on the street of the same name. 25 double rooms with old-style furniture, air conditioning, satellite television, a telephone socket, Wi-Fi, and baths with both tub and shower.

points_of_interest.name: Auberge de jeunesse Hi Paris Yves Robert
points_of_interest.description: IYHA youth hostel close to Gare du Nord & Gare de l’Est.

points_of_interest.name: Milestay Saint-Germain
points_of_interest.description: 3- & 4-bedroom furnished apartments for short stays. Available for groups (up to 8 people). Nice view on Eiffel Tower.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Longchamp Elysées
points_of_interest.description: 3-star boutique hotel.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Fabric
points_of_interest.description: Boutique hotel in an artistic neighborhood with 33 rooms is restyled in a 19th century textile factory that is both modern and characteristic of another era. The bold decor with brick walls and iron-works are comforting. Many services are available including fitness, hammam, massages, afternoon tea and concierge.

points_of_interest.name: Mercure Paris Opera Garnier
points_of_interest.description: A conservatively-styled Mercure with no particularly unique characteristics.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Keppler
points_of_interest.description: In the entertainment district with 34 guestrooms and 5 suites. A winter garden and bar is available within the hotel.

points_of_interest.name: Albert's Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Boutique hotel near many public transportation connections. Near lively neighborhoods but without the noise. Modernized bathrooms and bedrooms.

points_of_interest.name: Mercure Paris Royal Madeleine
points_of_interest.description: Decorated in brown and beige, this Mercure tries to make the most out of a historic ''immeuble'', with all the necessary compromises - some bedrooms are smaller than their en-suite bathrooms!

points_of_interest.name: Plug-Inn Hostel
points_of_interest.description: A small and inexpensive, but clean and well-located hostel. Free Wi-Fi, but the signal is weak in the rooms. Free breakfast.

points_of_interest.name: Peninsula Paris
points_of_interest.description: Opening in 2014, the meticulously hotel, known before the Second World War as the Hotel Majestic, has 200 rooms including 24 suites in this 19th century classic Haussman building.

points_of_interest.name: Mercure Paris Haussmann St Augustin
points_of_interest.description: Another typical Parisian Mercure, farther to the east than the other two.

points_of_interest.name: Renaissance Paris Le Parc Trocadero
points_of_interest.description: A quiet small hotel with a courtyard north of metro Victor Hugo. Wired internet at rooms.

points_of_interest.name: Champs Elysées Plaza
points_of_interest.description: Unusually large rooms and suites. Elegant and sophisticated, with high tech equipment and comfort, they offer a unique mix of contemporary chic décor with ceiling moldings, marble fireplaces, and large windows looking at two beautiful and quiet streets.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Molitor - MGallery Collection
points_of_interest.description: The ''Piscine Molitor'' swimming pool complex, featured prominently in the book and film ''The Life of Pi'', has been pretty much dismantled and rebuilt after many years of decay, becoming reborn triumphantly in 2014 as a luxury hotel, a part of the MGallery Collection.

points_of_interest.name: Four Seasons Hotel George V
points_of_interest.description: Steps from the Champs-Elysées, with private terraces that command all Paris.

points_of_interest.name: Grand Hôtel du Loiret
points_of_interest.description: A good value for the price and location.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Astor Saint Honoré
points_of_interest.description: 4-star hotel on a quiet street.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Mercure Paris La Sorbonne
points_of_interest.description: In the centre of Paris between the 5th and the 6th, in front of the Sorbonne, and one block from the Latin quarter and Saint Germain des Prés. Notre Dame is five minutes walking distance from the hotel. Fully renovated in a contemporary style, this hotel is very quiet and charming.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Balzac
points_of_interest.description: This elegantly furnished luxury boutique hotel exudes opulence from its fine classic interior to the personalised butler service.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Damremont
points_of_interest.description: Close to Butte Montmartre in a quiet residential quarter.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Hospitel
points_of_interest.description: You can't beat the location of this no-star but mid-range offering on the ''Ile de la Cité'' located on the 6th floor of the ''Hospital Hôtel-Dieu'' a functioning hospital which is also classified as an official historical monument. '''Hôspitel''' offers quite a bit of service and comfort.
points_of_interest.address: 1, Place du Parvis Notre Dame-Galerie B2, 6F

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel de Crillon
points_of_interest.description: The legendary hotel overlooking Place de la Concorde has been the epitome of Parisian luxury for centuries.

points_of_interest.name: Ibis Montmartre
points_of_interest.description: The rooms are a little small, but this offering of the Ibis chain is up to the usual high standard of cleanliness and service. Of course if you need a toothbrush you can find it in the vending machine downstairs. Reception is staffed around the clock for late arrivals.

points_of_interest.name: Centre International BVJ Paris-Louvre
points_of_interest.description: This is just about as cheap as it's going to get in the 1st. If you are here to study at the Louvre, and want to stay focused it has a location which can't be beat, just across rue Rivoli.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Bastille Speria
points_of_interest.description: This lovely little three-star is at the far end of the 4th bumped right up against Place de Bastille. The place is inviting and the rooms are quite comfy and air conditioned. The location is good especially if you are interested in fine dining, as the place is surrounded by some of the better bistros on the right bank.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Pershing Hall
points_of_interest.description: Charming five-star boutique hotel with a secluded patio and lush vertical garden.

points_of_interest.name: Timhotel Montmartre
points_of_interest.description: This cute, very well kept two-star is closer to a three-star in quality and price, it's just that the rooms are on the small side. Some of the rooms in the upper floors have fantastic views of the city.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Karraz
points_of_interest.description: Next to Les Halles Metro Station.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Plaza Elysees
points_of_interest.description: Near the Champs Elysées and Faubourg Saint-Honoré, very close to the Arc-de-Triomphe.

points_of_interest.name: Kube Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Stylish and atmospheric, the Kube Hotel exudes a high tech and luxurious decor. All the rooms come equipped with individual air conditioning, digital door opening, multi-function computer (DVD, CD, TV screen), cable TV, ADSL Internet, strongbox, mini bar, and fully equipped bathroom. As its name might suggest, the rooms feature some sort of cubism design and even the bedside tables look like ice cubes. Go out at night in your very own hotel, with a DJ spinning in the bar nightly, as well as being Paris's first-ever ice bar.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Montpensier
points_of_interest.description: Another semi-cheapie right in the middle of everything.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel San Régis
points_of_interest.description: Five-star boutique hotel with 44 individually decorated rooms and suites.

points_of_interest.name: Terrass Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Excellent four star hotel in Montmartre with 98 rooms, en suite baths, air conditioning, Wi-Fi, good restaurant, business facilities. The rooftop restaurant with fantastic views of Paris is open May-Sep.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Saint-Honoré
points_of_interest.description: Close to the Louvre. The place was renovated in the last few years, so the comfort level is pretty good considering it hasn't received a star rating yet.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Notre Dame
points_of_interest.description: On a typical and quiet little street, looking out on the Seine and facing Notre Dame Cathedral. Every room is uniquely styled and decorated and equipped with a complete, marble bathroom.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Sofitel Le Faubourg-Paris
points_of_interest.description: 154 rooms and 20 suites spread over two buildings dating from the 18th and 19th centuries.

points_of_interest.name: Aloha Youth Hostel
points_of_interest.description: No membership card required.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Brighton
points_of_interest.description: The executive and deluxe rooms offer a breathtaking views of the Louvre, the Jardin des Tuileries, and the Eiffel Tower. Classic Parisian-style hotel next to shopping and cultural hot spots.

points_of_interest.name: Hyatt Paris Madeleine
points_of_interest.description: Close to the shopping centres on Boulevard Haussmann-Printemps and Galeries Lafayette. 86 hotel rooms and suites, High-speed Wi-Fi available. Views of Boulevard Malesherbe. Business services available.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Britannique
points_of_interest.description: Anglophiles in Paris could do worse than to stay at this most Anglophile of French hotels. The location is good, at the very east end of the 1st.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Plaza Athénée
points_of_interest.description: The legendary hotel in Avenue Montaigne, home-away-from-home to numerous celebrities, in the ownership (Sultanate of Brunei)

points_of_interest.name: Campanile Paris XV - Tour Eiffel
points_of_interest.description: English & Spanish spoken at reception.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Louvre Bon Enfants
points_of_interest.description: Hôtel le Loiret Most reviewers give the hotel very high marks for cleanliness and comfort, but the real draw is the location: only steps from the ''Palais Royal/Louvre'' stop on ''Métro'' Line 1.

points_of_interest.name: Prince de Galles
points_of_interest.description: Named after Edward VIII, the erstwhile Prince of Wales and son of George V, this art-deco hotel opened in 1928 and amassed a veritable potpourri of celebrities in its guest book, ranging from Winston Churchill to Elvis Presley. It was thoroughly renovated and reopened in 2013 as a part of Starwood's Luxury Collection.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Mansart
points_of_interest.description: This charming 3-star hotel is next to the Place Vendôme and 2 minutes' walk from the Opera Garnier and famous Parisian department stores. Antique furniture and paintings create an atmosphere of typical Parisian house.

points_of_interest.name: Intercontinental Paris Avenue Marceau
points_of_interest.description: The "other" Intercontinental in Paris contrasts with the lavish historic ''Grand'' by having a more subtle, postmodern decor. The location in a converted historic building provides for spatial limitations clear in all areas of the hotel, but with only 57 rooms the property has almost a boutique feel to it.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Mirabeau Eiffel
points_of_interest.description: Though it is off centered, It is new, clean and somewhat affordable

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel de la Place du Louvre
points_of_interest.description: As its name suggests, this hotel is really close to the Louvre. Rooms on the street offer an impressive view on the Louvre.
points_of_interest.address: 21, rue des Prêtres Saint Germain l'Auxerrois

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Duo
points_of_interest.description: Stylish, modern and very clean boutique hotel.

points_of_interest.name: Marriott Champs-Elysees
points_of_interest.description: Behind the ''fin de siecle'' facade on the Champs-Elysees hides a much larger, late 20th-century building housing almost 200 rooms decorated in a subdued, for a Marriott property, way.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Victoria Châtelet
points_of_interest.description: A cozy, competitively priced 24 room hotel with a friendly Art Deco atmosphere. It is located next to the Chatelet Theatre in the very centre of Paris across from Notre Dame. It is close to bus, taxi, Metro and RER stations: Chatelet les Halles, as well as three nearby monitored parking garages.

points_of_interest.name: Radisson Blu
points_of_interest.description: Compared to the many opulent and extravagant hotels in the 8th arrondissement, the Radisson does not come across as spectacular, but can provide good value with the balconies of its front-side rooms offering views of the Arc de Triomphe.

points_of_interest.name: Mercure Paris Centre Tour Eiffel
points_of_interest.description: A relatively large mid-range hotel very close to the Eiffel Tower, in a nice, quiet and green area of Grenelle. Despite the closeness, only about a quarter of the rooms, designated as such and commanding higher rates, feature a view of the tower itself. All of the rooms and common spaces have been renovated and feature modern decor inspired by the tower and the metro. The rooms are very functional and feature operable windows, but the amounts of plastic and the violet theme may not provide for a romantic Parisian experience.

points_of_interest.name: Milestay Paris Les Halles
points_of_interest.description: Modern aparthotel with 9 furnished apartments, from budget studios to 2BR duplex. Various amenities including AC, kitchen and digital concierge.

points_of_interest.name: Mercure Paris Tour Eiffel Grenelle
points_of_interest.description: Not to be confused with the other Mercure, this one is not far away but in quite a different setting, facing the busy Boulevard Grenelle and the overground Metro 6 line. Neither as quiet nor as modern or comfortable as the other Mercure. On balance it is one of the cheaper hotels in its class close to the core tourist centre of Paris.

points_of_interest.name: Novotel Paris Les Halles
points_of_interest.description: Renovated to Novotel's newest standards, it is one of the brand's flagships and earns consistently good reviews. While much cheaper than the luxury hotels closer to Place Vendôme, it is one of the pricier Novotels in Paris, if not the world.

points_of_interest.name: Novotel Paris Tour Eiffel
points_of_interest.description: The largest Novotel in the world was built as a Japanese hotel Nikko, and retains many interesting design elements of the former, like the capsule-style windows, and the Japanese restaurant Benkay. It is by now not ageing that well though and awaits the long-overdue renovation.

points_of_interest.name: Castille Paris
points_of_interest.description: In the fashion district of Paris, the Castille Paris offers chic rooms that all look out onto the Rue Cambon. Some rooms are designed in a "Coco Chanel" style with beige and black tones.

points_of_interest.name: Novotel Paris Gare Montparnasse
points_of_interest.description: Located in a quiet corner of Montparnasse, and if you don't mind a 10-min walk to the Metro, this is a nice and relatively new hotel. Easy access from the Montparnasse-Bienvenüe Metro: just take the stairs all the way up to the train platforms, exit on Boulevard de Vaugirard, take a left and follow the street up to the hotel. There is a Velib' City Bike Rental park just outside the hotel.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Costes
points_of_interest.description: When the Costes brothers, who made their fortune in the Paris café trade, opened this designer hotel a couple of years ago it became an instant hit with the rich and famous, especially those of Hollywood. Whether it's worth the price for the exquisite interior decoration and the chance to rub elbows with a few movie stars is up to you to decide. They don't pay travel agent commissions, so either book it yourself, or pony up the extra €50 the agent would normally get.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Sublim Eiffel
points_of_interest.description: Funky decorated rooms located within 15min walk from the Tour Eiffel.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Ritz
points_of_interest.description: If there is any one hotel in the world which is not merely "putting on" the Ritz it would be this one, whose very name has entered the English language as a generic word for luxury (or the appearance thereof). The Ritz may not in fact be the fanciest hotel in Paris anymore, but it's always in the running. It's 350 times the price of a budget room in the neighborhood, but heck, maybe it's your honeymoon.

points_of_interest.name: Pullman Paris Tour Eiffel
points_of_interest.description: The former Hilton was taken over by Accor's upscale business hotel brand Pullman and underwent extensive renovation to its rooms and public spaces. It continues to offer close-up views of the Eiffel Tower from the balconies of its relatively spacious for Paris Deluxe (32 m²) and Superior (26 m²) rooms, while the Classic rooms (26 m²) face the courtyard.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel de Vendôme
points_of_interest.description: Occupying a building which was once the site of the Embassy of the Republic of Texas, the Hôtel de Vendôme is one of the most exclusive addresses anywhere, much like the neighbouring Ritz. The 29 rooms each have been decorated in the style of a different period, such as Classic, Baroque, or Deco.

points_of_interest.name: Hôtel Du Louvre, a Hyatt Hotel
points_of_interest.description: The hotel, built in 1855, is a brand itself enough for Hyatt to take second place to it. The hotel is a cornerstone for the Unbound Collection, a new Hyatt sub-brand created for notable properties, many of which pre-date the Hyatt chain itself. It is literally next to the Louvre and keeps the ''belle epoque'' charm alive throughout the property, albeit remaining contemporary and not pretentious. The Brasserie, where breakfasts are served, has a terrace with a splendid direct view of the Louvre.

points_of_interest.name: Le Meurice
points_of_interest.description: In business since 1815 and founded to cater to English travellers, Le Meurice has a rare distinction of being considered an actual palace by the French government (yes, they do regulate such things). Refurbished many times, the last time in 2007 by Philippe Stark, it has followed the changing demands of travellers yet retains numerous artefacts of its long history. Both its rooms and its famous ground-floor restaurant are frequent haunts of celebrities of all sorts, and it becomes a true potpourri of famous faces during the Paris Fashion Weeks.

points_of_interest.name: Renaissance Paris Vendôme Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Hidden in a side street and slightly demure, the Renaissance offers a welcome break from the revival-furniture-and-chandelier-filled surrounding hotels. Tasteful decor and quality service make up for the fact that some rooms are on the small side.

points_of_interest.name: The Westin Paris Vendôme
points_of_interest.description: A favourite with wealthy Russian tourists, the Westin Vendôme seems almost like a poor relative to other luxury hotels in the district, and certainly rises above the chain's average to match them. Not all rooms are created equal, and to get the best, one needs to shell out a significant supplement for the Tuileries view and high floor. All rooms are quite large by Parisian standards, though. The hotel has a sizeable area devoted to function rooms, and there is almost always something happening inside. When not closed for an event, the Summer Terrace is a highlight.

pois.name: Avenue des Champs-Elysées
pois.description:
The Avenue des Champs-Élysées is an avenue in the 8th arrondissement of Paris, France, 1.9 kilometres long and 70 metres wide, running between the Place de la Concorde in the east and the Place Charles de Gaulle in the west, where the Arc de Triomphe is located. It is known for its theatres, cafés, and luxury shops; as the finish of the Tour de France cycling race; and for its annual Bastille Day military parade.

The name is French for the Elysian Fields, the place for dead heroes in Greek mythology. It has been described as the "most beautiful avenue in the whole world".

pois.name: Eiffel Tower
pois.description:
The Eiffel Tower is a wrought-iron lattice tower on the Champ de Mars in Paris, France. It is named after the engineer Gustave Eiffel, whose company designed and built the tower from 1887 to 1889.

Locally nicknamed "La dame de fer" , it was constructed as the centerpiece of the 1889 World's Fair, and to crown the centennial anniversary of the French Revolution. Although initially criticised by some of France's leading artists and intellectuals for its design, it has since become a global cultural icon of France and one of the most recognisable structures in the world. The tower received 5,889,000 visitors in 2022. The Eiffel Tower is the most visited monument with an entrance fee in the world: 6.91 million people ascended it in 2015. It was designated a monument historique in 1964, and was named part of a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1991.

The tower is 330 metres tall, about the same height as an 81-storey building, and the tallest structure in Paris. Its base is square, measuring 125 metres on each side. During its construction, the Eiffel Tower surpassed the Washington Monument to become the tallest human-made structure in the world, a title it held for 41 years until the Chrysler Building in New York City was finished in 1930. It was the first structure in the world to surpass both the 200-metre and 300-metre mark in height. Due to the addition of a broadcasting aerial at the top of the tower in 1957, it is now taller than the Chrysler Building by 5.2 metres . Excluding transmitters, the Eiffel Tower is the second tallest free-standing structure in France after the Millau Viaduct.

The tower has three levels for visitors, with restaurants on the first and second levels. The top level's upper platform is 276 m above the ground—the highest observation deck accessible to the public in the European Union. Tickets can be purchased to ascend by stairs or lift to the first and second levels. The climb from ground level to the first level is over 300 steps, as is the climb from the first level to the second, making the entire ascent a 600-step climb. Although there is a staircase to the top level, it is usually accessible only by lift. On this top, third level is a private apartment built for Gustave Eiffel's personal use. He decorated it with furniture by Jean Lachaise and invited friends such as Thomas Edison.

pois.name: Château de Versailles
pois.description:
Nestled in the heart of France, the Château de Versailles stands as a testament to the country's rich history and architectural brilliance. This iconic estate is a must-visit destination for anyone drawn to grandeur, art, and the elegance of a bygone era. As you approach the château, its imposing facade, adorned with intricate stone carvings and gilded details, sets the tone for an unforgettable experience.

Step inside, and you're transported into a world of opulence. The Hall of Mirrors, with its dazzling array of mirrors and crystal chandeliers, is a sight to behold. Each room is a masterpiece, showcasing exquisite furnishings and artworks that reflect the lavish lifestyle of French monarchy. The Royal Chapel, with its soaring vaulted ceiling, is another highlight, offering a glimpse into the spiritual life of the royal family.

The true magic of Versailles, however, lies in its expansive gardens. Stroll through the meticulously manicured lawns, where perfectly aligned trees and vibrant flowerbeds create a symphony of color and texture. The Orangery, with its citrus trees, and the Grand Canal, where you can enjoy a leisurely boat ride, are just a few of the many treasures waiting to be discovered. Don’t miss the stunning fountains, which come alive with choreographed water displays, especially during the summer months.

Beyond the main palace, the estate boasts charming additions like the Trianon palaces and the Hamlet, offering a more intimate glimpse into the private lives of the royals. These lesser-known areas are perfect for those seeking a peaceful retreat from the crowds.

Throughout the year, Versailles hosts various cultural events and seasonal activities, from classical music concerts to ice skating in the winter. Whether you're exploring the palace, wandering the gardens, or simply soaking in the atmosphere, every moment at Château de Versailles is a step back in time. Plan to spend a full day here to fully appreciate the depth of history, art, and natural beauty that this incredible attraction has to offer.
pois.address: 1 Rue Robert De Cotte, 78000 Versailles, France
pois.hours: Nov-Mar: Tu-Su 09:00-1730, Apr-Oct: Tu-Su 09:00-18:30; closed Jan 1, May 1 and Dec 25

pois.name: Père-Lachaise Cemetery
pois.description:
Père-Lachaise Cemetery is one of the most visited and iconic cemeteries in the world, offering a fascinating glimpse into history, art, and culture. Located in Paris, this vast and picturesque site is renowned for its elaborate tombstones and monuments, which line winding pathways and avenues. Visitors can explore thousands of graves, each telling a unique story of the lives they commemorate.

What truly sets Père-Lachaise apart is its association with some of the most influential figures in history and the arts. The cemetery is the final resting place of luminaries such as Frédéric Chopin, the brilliant composer and pianist; Oscar Wilde, the celebrated author and wit; and Jim Morrison, the charismatic lead singer of The Doors. Other notable residents include French writer Honoré de Balzac, singer Edith Piaf, and playwright Molière. The cemetery also honors the likes of artists Eugène Delacroix and Georges Bizet, as well as writers Marcel Proust and Colette. These graves are not only tributes to their legacies but also draw visitors from around the globe.

A visit to Père-Lachaise Cemetery is as much about the living as it is about the deceased. The grounds are a peaceful retreat from the bustling city, with their ornate sculptures, shaded walkways, and historic charm. For those interested in history, art, or simply experiencing a unique side of Paris, Père-Lachaise Cemetery is a must-see destination. Be sure to bring a map, as the cemetery’s sprawling layout can make it easy to get lost in its beauty and significance.

pois.name: Le Marais
pois.description: The Marais (Le Marais French: [lə maʁɛ] ; "the marsh") is a historic district in Paris, France.
