It spreads across parts of the 3rd and 4th arrondissements on the Rive Droite, or Right Bank, of the Seine. Having once been an aristocratic district, it is home to many buildings of historic and architectural importance. It lost its status as a fashionable district in the late 18th century, with only minor nobles calling the area home. After the French Revolution, the district fell into disrepair and was abandoned by nobility. After a long period of decay, the district has undergone transformation in recent years and is now once again amongst the more fashionable areas of Paris, known for its art galleries, upscale restaurants and museums.
pois.address: 20a Rue Des Francs Bourgeois, 75003 Paris, France

pois.name: Cirque d'Hiver
pois.description: Cirque d'Hiver, a historic venue in Paris, has hosted an array of performances since its opening in 1852. Designed by architect Jacques Ignace Hittorff, it was originally known as Cirque Napoléon and later renamed in 1870. This iconic space has been a backdrop for circuses, musical concerts, and even fashion shows, blending tradition with modern entertainment. Its rich history includes the renowned Pasdeloup orchestral concerts, which ran for over two decades. Located near the Filles du Calvaire metro station, Cirque d'Hiver remains a cultural gem, offering a glimpse into Paris' vibrant past while continuing to inspire audiences today.

pois.name: Les Archives Nationales
pois.description: French Archives The Archives Nationales have one of the largest and most important archival collections in the world, a testimony to the very ancient nature of the French state which has been in existence for more than twelve centuries already.

pois.name: Sacré Coeur
pois.description:
Perched on a hill in the heart of Montmartre, the Basilique du Sacré Coeur is one of Paris's most iconic landmarks. This stunning white church, with its towering domes and intricate architecture, offers breathtaking views of the city. Built between 1875 and 1914, Sacré Coeur was constructed as a symbol of hope and reconciliation following the turmoil of the Franco-Prussian War and the Paris Commune. Its design, a mix of Romano-Byzantine styles, is both grand and graceful, making it a must-visit for architecture enthusiasts and history buffs alike.

Visitors can reach the top of the hill via a short but steep walk or by taking the Montmartre funicular, which runs regularly during the day. Once at the summit, the panoramic views of Paris from the dome and the square in front of the church are simply stunning, rivaling those from the Eiffel Tower. The square itself, 200 meters above sea level, is a popular spot to relax and take in the city's skyline.

While exploring the area, be mindful of a few local customs and safety tips. Photography inside the church is not allowed, so be respectful of the rules. Additionally, you may encounter street vendors or individuals approaching you near the lower steps. If you're uncomfortable, a firm but polite refusal is usually sufficient. Should you feel unsafe, don't hesitate to seek assistance from nearby authorities.

Sacré Coeur is more than just a beautiful building; it's a piece of Paris's history and a symbol of peace. Whether you're there to admire its architecture, enjoy the views, or simply soak in the atmosphere, it's an experience you won't want to miss.
pois.address: 4 Rue Du Cardinal Guibert, 75018 Paris, France

pois.name: Palais de Chaillot
pois.description: Great perspective on the Eiffel Tower and Left Bank from ''Place du Trocadéro'' in between the two buildings of the palais. Former location of the Palais du Trocadéro. It accommodates three museums, an aquarium, and the Theatre Nationale du Chaillot.

pois.name: la Bibliothèque Nationale de France
pois.description:
The Bibliothèque nationale de France, located in Paris, is a must-visit for book lovers and history enthusiasts. Spanning two sites—Richelieu and François-Mitterrand—it serves as France’s national repository, preserving a vast collection of published works, manuscripts, and cultural treasures. 

The Richelieu site is home to the BnF Museum, showcasing rare artifacts, artworks, and historical manuscripts. As a key cultural institution, the library offers a glimpse into France’s intellectual and artistic heritage, making it a fascinating destination for anyone exploring the city.
pois.hours: Reading rooms, M-F, 09:00-18:00; Sa, 09:00-17:00; exhibitions, Tu-Sa, 10:00-19:00

pois.name: Arènes de Lutèce
pois.description: An ancient Roman theater, the only surviving above-ground ruins of the Gallo-Roman era in Paris (ancient Lutetia, French ''Lutèce'') apart from the nearby ''Thermes de Cluny''. The theatre could hold approximately 15,000 spectators and measures some 132 m x 100 m. Built sometime in the 2nd century CE, the location of the actor's dressing room, the platform of the stage, and lapidary remains can still be seen. The remains were rediscovered in 1869, when new streets were being built. An excavation was subsequently ordered in 1883. The theatre has been preserved as a quiet archaeological park removed from the bustle of Parisian streets.
pois.address: 47, rue Monge et rue de Navarre

pois.name: Colonne Vendôme
pois.description: The centrepiece of a magnificent 8-sided square first laid out in 1699 to show off an equestrian statue of the Sun King, Louis XIV. The statue was removed amid revolutionary fervor in 1792 and replaced in 1806 with the ''Colonne de la Grande Armée''. This was modelled on Trajan's column in Rome and decorated with Napoleon's military exploits. The present column is a replica, however, as the original was pulled down during the 1871 Paris Commune. Place Vendôme represents the best of well-heeled Paris, being home to an abundance of exclusive boutiques, jewellers and fashion labels—Cartier, Boucheron, Trussardi, van Cleef & Arpels—several banks, the French Ministry of Justice, and the Hôtel Ritz.

pois.name: Les Catacombes de Paris
pois.description:
Les Catacombes de Paris offers a unique and fascinating glimpse into the city's history. This vast network of underground tunnels, originally carved out during the Roman era, now serves as the final resting place for the remains of over six million Parisians. In the late 18th and early 19th centuries, these bones were transferred here from overcrowded cemeteries and charnel houses across the city. The result is a hauntingly beautiful, if somewhat macabre, experience. Visitors can wander through the dimly lit passageways, where skulls and bones are neatly arranged in a somber yet orderly fashion.

The atmosphere of the catacombs is undeniably eerie, though not overwhelmingly so. It’s a place that invites reflection and curiosity, making it a must-visit for those interested in history, architecture, or the unconventional. Be aware that the site has a limited capacity, allowing only 200 visitors at a time. This may result in a wait, especially during peak hours, so planning your visit in advance is a good idea.

Visitors should also note that the exit involves climbing a steep stairwell, which may pose a challenge for the elderly or those with mobility issues. Tickets can be purchased online for a small premium (€29, including an audioguide), allowing you to select a specific date and time and skip the queues. This option is highly recommended for a smoother experience.
pois.hours: Tu-Su 9:45-20:30; last admission 19:30; closed Mo and public holidays

pois.name: Musée Edith Piaf
pois.description: The Musée Edith Piaf is a charming cultural destination dedicated to the life and legacy of the iconic French singer Edith Piaf. Located in the heart of Paris, this intimate museum offers a fascinating glimpse into the world of "La Môme Piaf," showcasing her rise from a street performer to a global star. Exhibits feature rare memorabilia, personal artifacts, and interactive displays that highlight her career, struggles, and enduring impact on French music and culture. Visitors can explore her story through photographs, costumes, and recordings, gaining a deeper appreciation for her artistry and the timeless appeal of her music.

pois.name: Place de la Concorde
pois.description: The largest square in Paris with fantastic vistas in every direction. It was in this square (then called ''la Place de la Revolution'') that the French King Louis XVI, Marie Antoinette and many others were guillotined during the Terror. The large Egyptian obelisk in the centre of the Place de la Concorde was brought from the Temple of Luxor.

pois.name: Grande Arche de la Defense
pois.description:
The Grande Arche de la Defense is a striking modern landmark in Paris, known for its bold, cube-like design that reimagines the traditional concept of an arch. This monumental structure, located in the bustling La Defense district, is a testament to contemporary architecture and serves as a gateway to the city. While its design may appear more geometric than a conventional arch, it has become an iconic symbol of Paris's blend of history and innovation.

Visitors should note that the viewing platform at the top of the Grande Arche has experienced periodic closures over the years. After being closed following an elevator incident in 2010, it reopened to the public in May 2017. However, as of October 2023, the platform is once again closed. Travelers planning to visit are encouraged to check for updates on accessibility before heading to the site. Despite the viewing platform's current status, the Grande Arche remains a must-see attraction for its architectural significance and its role as a symbol of Paris's dynamic spirit.

pois.name: Musée Gustave Moreau
pois.description:
The Musée national Gustave Moreau is an art museum dedicated to the works of Symbolist painter Gustave Moreau . It is located in the 9th arrondissement of Paris at 14, rue de la Rochefoucauld, Paris, France.

The museum was originally Moreau's dwelling, transformed by his 1895 decision into a studio and museum of his work with his apartment remaining on the first floor. Today the museum contains Moreau's drawings, paintings, watercolors, and sculptures.

pois.name: Palais du Luxembourg
pois.description: Visitable only by reservation and then only one Saturday every month. A richly decorated palace built for Marie de Medici in the early 17th century, which is now the French Senate. For those interested in seeing a Parisian monument normally unavailable to the public, or for those interested in the inner workings of the French Government. The large '''Luxembourg Garden''' is open to the public year-round. The garden is home to the Medici fountain, a children's playground, and vintage toy boats for hire that children push around in the Grand Bassin duck pond (a 90-year tradition).

pois.name: Bercy Village
pois.description: For a taste of the French countryside, a visit to Bercy Village brings to life the spirit of market shopping inside Paris.

pois.name: La Conciergerie
pois.description: The ancient medieval fortress and prison of the city's island, site of some remarkable medieval royal architecture and the scene of Marie Antoinette's imprisonment in the period leading to her execution in 1793; lots of revolutionary associations.

pois.name: Les Invalides
pois.description: Les Invalides, a historic complex founded by Louis XIV in 1671, was originally built as a hospital to care for a large number of wounded soldiers, which inspired its name. Today, it continues to serve as an infirmary while also housing the Musée de l'Armée, offering insights into French military history. The complex is perhaps most famous for the stunning golden dome of l'Eglise du Dôme, where Napoleon Bonaparte's tomb is located, making it a significant landmark in Paris.

pois.name: Place de la Bastille
pois.description:
The Place de la Bastille (French pronunciation: [plas də la bastij]) is a square in Paris where the Bastille prison once stood, until the storming of the Bastille and its subsequent physical destruction between 14 July 1789 and 14 July 1790 during the French Revolution. No vestige of the prison remains.

The square straddles 3 arrondissements of Paris, namely the 4th, 11th and 12th. The square and its surrounding areas are normally called simply Bastille. The July Column (Colonne de Juillet) which commemorates the events of the July Revolution (1830) stands at the center of the square.  Other notable features include the Bastille Opera, the Bastille subway station and a section of the Canal Saint Martin.  Prior to 1984, the former Bastille railway station stood where the opera house now stands.
pois.address: 12 Place De La Bastille, 75011 Paris, France

pois.name: Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile
pois.description:
The Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile, often called simply the Arc de Triomphe, is one of the most famous monuments in Paris, France, standing at the western end of the Champs-Élysées at the centre of Place Charles de Gaulle, formerly named Place de l'Étoile—the étoile or "star" of the juncture formed by its twelve radiating avenues. The location of the arc and the plaza is shared between three arrondissements, 16th , 17th , and 8th . The Arc de Triomphe honours those who fought and died for France in the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars, with the names of all French victories and generals inscribed on its inner and outer surfaces. Beneath its vault lies the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier from World War I.

The central cohesive element of the Axe historique , the Arc de Triomphe was designed by Jean Chalgrin in 1806; its iconographic programme pits heroically nude French youths against bearded Germanic warriors in chain mail. It set the tone for public monuments with triumphant patriotic messages. Inspired by the Arch of Titus in Rome, Italy, the Arc de Triomphe has an overall height of 50 m , width of 45 m and depth of 22 m , while its large vault is 29.19 m high and 14.62 m wide. The smaller transverse vaults are 18.68 m high and 8.44 m wide.

Paris's Arc de Triomphe was the tallest triumphal arch until the completion of the Monumento a la Revolución in Mexico City in 1938, which is 67 m high. The Arch of Triumph in Pyongyang, completed in 1982, is modeled on the Arc de Triomphe and is slightly taller at 60 m . The Grande Arche in La Défense near Paris is 110 metres high, and, if considered to be a triumphal arch, is the world's tallest.
pois.address: Place de l'Étoile, Place Charles de Gaulle

pois.name: Opera Garnier
pois.description: The Palais Garnier, famously known as the setting for "The Phantom of the Opera," captivates visitors with its grandeur. Inside, the opulence mirrors the exterior, offering a visually stunning experience. Since the opening of the Opéra Bastille in 1989, the Palais Garnier has primarily become a venue for dance, particularly ballet, adding to its cultural significance.

pois.name: Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie
pois.description:
Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie is a must-visit destination for anyone fascinated by science and technology. Opened in 1986 and continually updated, this expansive museum offers a wealth of interactive exhibits that bring the wonders of science to life. One of the highlights is the Louis Lumière 3D cinema, where visitors can immerse themselves in cutting-edge visual experiences.

While the museum is particularly popular with families and children, its engaging displays and hands-on activities appeal to visitors of all ages. From exploring the frontiers of technology to discovering the marvels of the natural world, Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie is a place where learning is made fun and accessible. Whether you're a science enthusiast or just curious about the world around you, this iconic attraction promises an inspiring and educational experience.

pois.name: Panthéon
pois.description:
The Panthéon, originally envisioned by Louis XV as a grand neo-classical church dedicated to St. Geneviève, the patron saint of Paris, underwent a significant transformation after the French Revolution. It became a mausoleum honoring the great minds and heroes of the French Republic. The crypt holds the remains of esteemed figures such as Voltaire, Rousseau, Victor Hugo, and the Curies, among others, reflecting the nation's rich intellectual and cultural heritage.

One of the Panthéon's most striking features is its dome, which offers a breathtaking view of the city after climbing 206 steps. This architectural marvel is a must-visit for anyone seeking a panoramic perspective of Paris. Inside, visitors can also find a fascinating reconstruction of Foucault's pendulum, adding a touch of scientific intrigue to the historical ambiance.

For those planning a visit, it's advisable to check the tour departure times at the information desk to make the most of your experience. The Panthéon seamlessly blends historical significance with architectural beauty, making it a compelling destination for travelers interested in exploring Paris's cultural and scientific treasures.
pois.hours: Daily, April-September 10:00-18:30, October-March: 10:00-18:00, Last admission 45 mins before closing

pois.name: Église Saint-Eustache
pois.description: The massive parish church of the Les Halles area is a notable example of late Gothic interspersed with Renaissance details (including the entire front façade), as it was only completed in the 17th century. Its unique form results from a combination of relatively short length and impressive height of over 30 metres inside. The latter allows room not only for an array of stained glass windows and paintings, but also France's largest church organ of 8,000 pipes. The sculpture ''Écoute'', depicting an oversized human head, was placed in front of the church's southern facade and has become a favourite photo spot.

pois.name: Manufacture des Gobelins
pois.description: The Gobelins Manufactory is a historic tapestry factory in Paris, France. It is located at 42 avenue des Gobelins, near Les Gobelins métro station in the 13th arrondissement of Paris. It was originally established on the site as a medieval dyeing business by the family Gobelin.

pois.name: Notre Dame Cathedral
pois.description:
Notre Dame Cathedral is one of the most iconic landmarks in the world, and a must-visit attraction for anyone traveling to Paris. This stunning early Gothic cathedral, also known as "Cathédrale de Notre Dame" or "Our Lady," showcases the evolution of Gothic architecture. While its design was conceived in the 12th century, the cathedral wasn't fully completed until the 14th century. Its intricate design and soaring vaults make it a masterpiece of medieval engineering and artistry.

The cathedral's west portal, or main entrance, is particularly notable for its rigid, almost austere design, which stands out from the more fluid lines of the rest of the building. This contrast highlights the dynamic nature of Gothic architecture and its development over time.

In April 2019, Notre Dame suffered a devastating fire that caused significant damage to the structure, including the loss of its iconic spire. However, after a meticulous and extensive restoration process, the cathedral reopened to the public in December 2024. This resilience and renewal make Notre Dame not only a historical treasure but also a symbol of hope and rebirth.

Visitors to Notre Dame can marvel at its towering ceilings, stunning stained-glass windows, and the serene atmosphere that fills the space. Whether you're drawn by its religious significance, its architectural brilliance, or its cultural importance, Notre Dame Cathedral promises an unforgettable experience.
pois.address: Ile de la Cité 6, Place du Parvis Notre Dame

pois.name: Jardin des Tuileries
pois.description: Built adjoining the now-lost royal palace of the Tuileries, these gardens lying immediately west of the Louvre offer a central open space for Parisians and visitors with semi-formal gardens (an outdoor gallery for modern sculpture), various cafés, ice cream and crépe stalls, and a summer fun fair. The gardens are frequently home to a giant Ferris wheel and enclose the ''Musée de la Orangerie'' and the ''Jeu de Paume''.

pois.name: Musée d'Orsay
pois.description: Housed in a former ''Beaux-Arts'' railway station (completed in 1900 for the ''Exposition Universelle'', later saved from demolition and converted to its present use), the rambling, open-plan museum is home to the works of the great artists of the 19th century (1848-1914) - Impressionists, post-Impressionists, and the rest - that were formerly displayed in the l'Orangerie. This is perhaps the most spectacular collection of European impressionism in the world—breath-taking rooms full of Manet, Renoir, Monet, Van Gogh, and many others. Impressionist represent the biggest draw, but there is much more to explore.
pois.address: 1, rue de la Légion d'Honneur / rue de Lille

pois.name: Musée de l'Institut du Monde Arabe
pois.description: Arab World Institute The building has a freely accessible rooftop which allows for a beautiful bird's-eye view of the northern half of Paris.

pois.name: Le Palais Royal
pois.description: Ordered by Cardinal de Richelieu (1585-1642), King Louis XIII's prime Minister in 1629 (completed in 1636); originally called ''Palais Cardinal''; it became ''Le Palais Royal'' when Anne d'Autriche, Louis XIII's wife, came to live here to get away from the ''Louvre'' palace. It eventually housed Louis XIV until the move to Versailles. It includes also a beautiful garden ''Les jardins du Palais Royal'', enclosed by the buildings. It's been the theatre of one of the seminal events of the French Revolution (Camille Desmoulins made a famous declaration here in 1789). The ''Théatre Français'' nearby was built in 1716. There are numerous restaurants inside the garden , including famous ''Le Grand Véfour''. There's also the controversial ''Colonnes de Buren'', striped columns installed within the inside yard amid the 17th century architecture.
pois.hours: 07:00-23:00 during the summer and 07:00-20:30 in the winter with hours varying spring and autumn

pois.name: Picasso Museum
pois.description: Most of the works by Picasso and others which were in the master's possession at the time of his death are now on display here.
pois.hours: 09:30-18:00, W-M & 09:30-20:00 on Th, except during winter when closing time is always 17:30

pois.name: Musée national du Moyen Âge
pois.description: Musée de Cluny Housed in a 15th-century abbey, alongside 1st century Gallo-Roman baths, the museum has an extensive collection of medieval art and artifacts. Highlights include the medieval "Lady and the Unicorn" tapestries, a papal golden rose, and the original heads from the facade of Notre Dame.

pois.name: Rodin Museum
pois.description:
The Rodin Museum is a must-visit destination for art enthusiasts and anyone looking to immerse themselves in the works of one of history's greatest sculptors. This museum offers a unique opportunity to explore the life and artistry of Auguste Rodin through an extensive and beautifully curated collection of his sculptures, drawings, and other works. 

Housed in a spacious and elegant building, the museum's interior is as impressive as its contents. Large windows allow natural light to flood the galleries, creating a bright and airy atmosphere that enhances the viewing experience. The thoughtful presentation of the artworks, combined with the building's open design, makes the museum a pleasure to wander through.

Surrounding the museum is a beautiful garden, perfect for a relaxing stroll after exploring the galleries. The entire experience—whether indoors or outdoors—provides a deeper appreciation for Rodin's genius and leaves a lasting impression on all who visit.
pois.hours: Tu-Su: museum: 10:00-17:45, park: till 18:00; ticket office: till 17:15. Closed M

pois.name: Le Grand Palais
pois.description: The Grand Palais, located in Paris's 8th arrondissement, is a stunning historic site and exhibition hall that showcases French art and culture. Built for the 1900 Universal Exposition, this Beaux-Arts masterpiece features ornate stone facades, glass vaults, and innovative iron and concrete framing. Its design reflects its purpose as a grand venue for artistic events, with a pediment proclaiming it a monument to French art. A designated historic monument, the Grand Palais continues to host major exhibitions and events, making it a must-visit destination in the heart of Paris.

pois.name: Fondation Louis Vuitton
pois.description: The Fondation Louis Vuitton is a contemporary art museum and cultural center located in the Bois de Boulogne, Paris. Designed by renowned architect Frank Gehry, the building is a striking example of Deconstructivist architecture. Opened in 2014, the museum showcases an impressive collection of modern and contemporary art, along with rotating exhibitions and cultural events. Surrounded by lush greenery, it offers a unique blend of art, design, and natural beauty. With over 1.4 million visitors annually, it has become a must-visit destination for art enthusiasts and travelers alike.

pois.name: Musée de Montmartre
pois.description: The museum is located in a 17th century house with a garden, and features the history and culture of Montmartre. Several famous artists had lived in the house including Renoir.

pois.name: Hall of Mirrors
pois.description: Of one of the most emblematic royal rooms, this Baroque-style gallery has been the scene of significant historical events, including where Otto von Bismarck proclaimed the first German Empire.
pois.address: 2b Rue De L'indépendance Américaine, 78000 Versailles, France

pois.name: "I love you" wall
pois.description: The "I love you" wall is a charming and romantic spot that celebrates love in its many forms. This unique attraction features the phrase "I love you" written in hundreds of different languages, creating a vibrant and heartfelt display. Perfect for couples and solo travelers alike, the wall is a beautiful representation of love's universal language. Its colorful and whimsical design makes it a must-visit for anyone looking to experience a touching piece of cultural artistry.

pois.name: Château de Vincennes
pois.description: The Château de Vincennes is a historic fortress and former royal residence located on the eastern edge of Paris, near the Bois de Vincennes. Built primarily in the 14th century, it served as a favored retreat for French kings for over 200 years. The château is renowned for its impressive keep, the tallest medieval tower in Europe, and the stunning Sainte-Chapelle de Vincennes, a masterpiece of Flamboyant Gothic architecture. Historically, it functioned as a royal sanctuary, prison, and military headquarters. Today, much of the château is open to visitors, offering a glimpse into France's rich medieval past.

pois.name: The Louvre
pois.description: Its exhibits come from such diverse origins as ancient Egypt, classical Greece and the Roman Empire, medieval Europe, and Napoleonic France, but controversially including many items that were looted from their places of origin. Its most famous exhibit, of course, is Leonardo da Vinci's painting of the Mona Lisa (French: ''La Joconde'', Italian: ''La Gioconda''), generally to be found surrounded by hordes of camera-flashing tourists. The Louvre poses many of the same challenges to the visitor as Paris itself; overwhelming in size, crowded in high seasons, and much information available only in French. If you want to see everything in the Louvre, plan ''at least'' two full days. However, it is better to pick and choose, as the collection was assembled with an eye to completeness rather than quality. As of July 2019, due to intense crowding and reports of ticket fraud, entry now almost always requires a pre-booked timed ticket, even for holders of the Paris Museum Pass.
pois.hours: W-M 09:00-18:00, closed public holidays; evening openings W and F until 21:45

pois.name: Centre Georges Pompidou
pois.description: Those who are unfamiliar with conceptual art sometimes don't know quite what to expect, or how to approach it. Such travellers should rest assured that the curators at the Pompidou Centre have assembled a marvellous introduction consisting of mostly approachable works which delight, amuse, and entertain. The art is far from the only reason for a visit, as the building also contains a vast public library and a fine restaurant (run by the Costes brothers) on the roof. In fact the place is ''literally'' surrounded by some of the nicest pavement cafés in the city, in its superb location between the car-free above ground part of Forum Les Halles and the Marais art district.

pois.name: Musée de l'Orangerie
pois.description: Musée de la Orangerie Reopened after extensive renovations, this small museum near the Louvre houses the ''Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume Collection'', sold to the French Republic on very generous terms and numbering 143 paintings from the late 19th century and the first half of the 20th century (15 Cézannes, 24 Renoirs, 10 Matisses, 12 Picassos, 28 Derains, 22 Soutines). The collection joined the eight immense ''Water Lilies'' that Monet gave France in 1922 and which have been displayed since 1927 in two huge oval rooms purpose-built on the artist's instructions.
pois.hours: W-M (closed Christmas Day and 1 May) individuals 12:30-19:00, Th till 21:00; groups, 09:30-12:30;

pois.name: Jacquemart-Andre Museum
pois.description: Jacquemart-Andre Museum Private collection of French, Italian, Dutch masterpieces in a typical XIXth century mansion.

pois.name: Église Saint-Jacques-du-Haut-Pas
pois.description: Saint-Jacques du Haut-Pas is a Roman Catholic parish church in Paris, France. The church is located at the corner of Rue Saint-Jacques and Rue de l'Abbé de l'Épée in the 5th arrondissement of Paris. The first church on the site, a monastery chapel, was built in 1360. The present church was completed in 1685. The church is  named for Saint-Jacques Du-Haut-Pas," (in English Saint James the Minor), a cousin of Christ and the first bishop of Jerusalem,  who was martyred in the year 60 A.D. It was registered as an historical monument on  4 June 1957.

pois.name: Bourse de commerce - Pinault Collection
pois.description: Commodities Exchange Building Since 2021 the 18th-century former Bourse de Commerce building has been the Paris home of the art collection of the French business magnate François Pinault, showing a rotating selection of contemporary artworks either newly commissioned or taken from his collection.
pois.hours: W-Mo 11:00-19:00. Closed Tu. Fr and first Sa of month late opening until 21:00

pois.name: Avenue des Champs-Elysées
pois.description:
The Avenue des Champs-Élysées is an avenue in the 8th arrondissement of Paris, France, 1.9 kilometres long and 70 metres wide, running between the Place de la Concorde in the east and the Place Charles de Gaulle in the west, where the Arc de Triomphe is located. It is known for its theatres, cafés, and luxury shops; as the finish of the Tour de France cycling race; and for its annual Bastille Day military parade.

The name is French for the Elysian Fields, the place for dead heroes in Greek mythology. It has been described as the "most beautiful avenue in the whole world".

pois.name: Eiffel Tower
pois.description:
The Eiffel Tower is a wrought-iron lattice tower on the Champ de Mars in Paris, France. It is named after the engineer Gustave Eiffel, whose company designed and built the tower from 1887 to 1889.

Locally nicknamed "La dame de fer" , it was constructed as the centerpiece of the 1889 World's Fair, and to crown the centennial anniversary of the French Revolution. Although initially criticised by some of France's leading artists and intellectuals for its design, it has since become a global cultural icon of France and one of the most recognisable structures in the world. The tower received 5,889,000 visitors in 2022. The Eiffel Tower is the most visited monument with an entrance fee in the world: 6.91 million people ascended it in 2015. It was designated a monument historique in 1964, and was named part of a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1991.

The tower is 330 metres tall, about the same height as an 81-storey building, and the tallest structure in Paris. Its base is square, measuring 125 metres on each side. During its construction, the Eiffel Tower surpassed the Washington Monument to become the tallest human-made structure in the world, a title it held for 41 years until the Chrysler Building in New York City was finished in 1930. It was the first structure in the world to surpass both the 200-metre and 300-metre mark in height. Due to the addition of a broadcasting aerial at the top of the tower in 1957, it is now taller than the Chrysler Building by 5.2 metres . Excluding transmitters, the Eiffel Tower is the second tallest free-standing structure in France after the Millau Viaduct.

The tower has three levels for visitors, with restaurants on the first and second levels. The top level's upper platform is 276 m above the ground—the highest observation deck accessible to the public in the European Union. Tickets can be purchased to ascend by stairs or lift to the first and second levels. The climb from ground level to the first level is over 300 steps, as is the climb from the first level to the second, making the entire ascent a 600-step climb. Although there is a staircase to the top level, it is usually accessible only by lift. On this top, third level is a private apartment built for Gustave Eiffel's personal use. He decorated it with furniture by Jean Lachaise and invited friends such as Thomas Edison.

pois.name: Père-Lachaise Cemetery
pois.description:
Père-Lachaise Cemetery is one of the most visited and iconic cemeteries in the world, offering a fascinating glimpse into history, art, and culture. Located in Paris, this vast and picturesque site is renowned for its elaborate tombstones and monuments, which line winding pathways and avenues. Visitors can explore thousands of graves, each telling a unique story of the lives they commemorate.

What truly sets Père-Lachaise apart is its association with some of the most influential figures in history and the arts. The cemetery is the final resting place of luminaries such as Frédéric Chopin, the brilliant composer and pianist; Oscar Wilde, the celebrated author and wit; and Jim Morrison, the charismatic lead singer of The Doors. Other notable residents include French writer Honoré de Balzac, singer Edith Piaf, and playwright Molière. The cemetery also honors the likes of artists Eugène Delacroix and Georges Bizet, as well as writers Marcel Proust and Colette. These graves are not only tributes to their legacies but also draw visitors from around the globe.

A visit to Père-Lachaise Cemetery is as much about the living as it is about the deceased. The grounds are a peaceful retreat from the bustling city, with their ornate sculptures, shaded walkways, and historic charm. For those interested in history, art, or simply experiencing a unique side of Paris, Père-Lachaise Cemetery is a must-see destination. Be sure to bring a map, as the cemetery’s sprawling layout can make it easy to get lost in its beauty and significance.

pois.name: Sacré Coeur
pois.description:
Perched on a hill in the heart of Montmartre, the Basilique du Sacré Coeur is one of Paris's most iconic landmarks. This stunning white church, with its towering domes and intricate architecture, offers breathtaking views of the city. Built between 1875 and 1914, Sacré Coeur was constructed as a symbol of hope and reconciliation following the turmoil of the Franco-Prussian War and the Paris Commune. Its design, a mix of Romano-Byzantine styles, is both grand and graceful, making it a must-visit for architecture enthusiasts and history buffs alike.

Visitors can reach the top of the hill via a short but steep walk or by taking the Montmartre funicular, which runs regularly during the day. Once at the summit, the panoramic views of Paris from the dome and the square in front of the church are simply stunning, rivaling those from the Eiffel Tower. The square itself, 200 meters above sea level, is a popular spot to relax and take in the city's skyline.

While exploring the area, be mindful of a few local customs and safety tips. Photography inside the church is not allowed, so be respectful of the rules. Additionally, you may encounter street vendors or individuals approaching you near the lower steps. If you're uncomfortable, a firm but polite refusal is usually sufficient. Should you feel unsafe, don't hesitate to seek assistance from nearby authorities.

Sacré Coeur is more than just a beautiful building; it's a piece of Paris's history and a symbol of peace. Whether you're there to admire its architecture, enjoy the views, or simply soak in the atmosphere, it's an experience you won't want to miss.
pois.address: 4 Rue Du Cardinal Guibert, 75018 Paris, France

pois.name: Musée Delacroix
pois.description: Abbey of Saint-Germain-des-Prés The oldest church in Paris, founded in the year 542 by King Childebert. The church as it exists today dates mainly from the 11th century, the period in which it became the center of a powerful Benedictine abbey. The Revolution witnessed the suppression of the abbey in 1794, when most of the monastic buildings were put to the torch. Earlier, 318 priests had been hacked to death nearby by a mob on 3 September 1792. The church underwent significant restoration in the 19th century, ensuring the preservation of the building, which by that date represented a fascinating mix of styles: 6th century marble columns placed alongside Gothic vaults and supported by Romanesque arches. Famous burials within the church include René Descartes (philosopher), Nicolas Boileau (poet) and King John Casimir of Poland, who had become (in 1669, before his death) abbot of the church's monastery.

pois.name: Les Catacombes de Paris
pois.description:
Les Catacombes de Paris offers a unique and fascinating glimpse into the city's history. This vast network of underground tunnels, originally carved out during the Roman era, now serves as the final resting place for the remains of over six million Parisians. In the late 18th and early 19th centuries, these bones were transferred here from overcrowded cemeteries and charnel houses across the city. The result is a hauntingly beautiful, if somewhat macabre, experience. Visitors can wander through the dimly lit passageways, where skulls and bones are neatly arranged in a somber yet orderly fashion.

The atmosphere of the catacombs is undeniably eerie, though not overwhelmingly so. It’s a place that invites reflection and curiosity, making it a must-visit for those interested in history, architecture, or the unconventional. Be aware that the site has a limited capacity, allowing only 200 visitors at a time. This may result in a wait, especially during peak hours, so planning your visit in advance is a good idea.

Visitors should also note that the exit involves climbing a steep stairwell, which may pose a challenge for the elderly or those with mobility issues. Tickets can be purchased online for a small premium (€29, including an audioguide), allowing you to select a specific date and time and skip the queues. This option is highly recommended for a smoother experience.
pois.hours: Tu-Su 9:45-20:30; last admission 19:30; closed Mo and public holidays

pois.name: Grande Arche de la Defense
pois.description:
The Grande Arche de la Defense is a striking modern landmark in Paris, known for its bold, cube-like design that reimagines the traditional concept of an arch. This monumental structure, located in the bustling La Defense district, is a testament to contemporary architecture and serves as a gateway to the city. While its design may appear more geometric than a conventional arch, it has become an iconic symbol of Paris's blend of history and innovation.

Visitors should note that the viewing platform at the top of the Grande Arche has experienced periodic closures over the years. After being closed following an elevator incident in 2010, it reopened to the public in May 2017. However, as of October 2023, the platform is once again closed. Travelers planning to visit are encouraged to check for updates on accessibility before heading to the site. Despite the viewing platform's current status, the Grande Arche remains a must-see attraction for its architectural significance and its role as a symbol of Paris's dynamic spirit.

pois.name: Musée Marmottan-Monet
pois.description:
Nestled in the heart of Paris, the Musée Marmottan-Monet is a hidden gem that offers a unique cultural experience. Owned by the French Académie des Beaux-Arts, this enchanting museum is renowned for its diverse and impressive collections. 

The museum's holdings are the result of several significant donations, showcasing a wide range of artistic treasures. Visitors can explore an extensive collection of First Empire art and furnishings, which provide a fascinating glimpse into the opulence of the Napoleonic era. Additionally, the museum is home to a remarkable array of illuminated manuscripts, highlighting the artistry and craftsmanship of medieval and Renaissance periods.

However, the true crown jewel of the Musée Marmottan-Monet is its extraordinary collection of Impressionist art. As the largest repository of Claude Monet's works in the world, the museum offers an unparalleled opportunity to delve into the master's creative genius. Alongside Monet, the collection features pieces by other iconic Impressionist artists, including Renoir, Manet, Morisot, Caillebotte, and Gauguin. This makes the museum a must-visit destination for anyone passionate about Impressionism and its enduring legacy.
pois.hours: Tu W F-Su 10:00-18:00; Th 10:00-21:00; last entry 30 min before closing

pois.name: Les Invalides
pois.description: Les Invalides, a historic complex founded by Louis XIV in 1671, was originally built as a hospital to care for a large number of wounded soldiers, which inspired its name. Today, it continues to serve as an infirmary while also housing the Musée de l'Armée, offering insights into French military history. The complex is perhaps most famous for the stunning golden dome of l'Eglise du Dôme, where Napoleon Bonaparte's tomb is located, making it a significant landmark in Paris.

pois.name: Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile
pois.description:
The Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile, often called simply the Arc de Triomphe, is one of the most famous monuments in Paris, France, standing at the western end of the Champs-Élysées at the centre of Place Charles de Gaulle, formerly named Place de l'Étoile—the étoile or "star" of the juncture formed by its twelve radiating avenues. The location of the arc and the plaza is shared between three arrondissements, 16th , 17th , and 8th . The Arc de Triomphe honours those who fought and died for France in the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars, with the names of all French victories and generals inscribed on its inner and outer surfaces. Beneath its vault lies the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier from World War I.

The central cohesive element of the Axe historique , the Arc de Triomphe was designed by Jean Chalgrin in 1806; its iconographic programme pits heroically nude French youths against bearded Germanic warriors in chain mail. It set the tone for public monuments with triumphant patriotic messages. Inspired by the Arch of Titus in Rome, Italy, the Arc de Triomphe has an overall height of 50 m , width of 45 m and depth of 22 m , while its large vault is 29.19 m high and 14.62 m wide. The smaller transverse vaults are 18.68 m high and 8.44 m wide.

Paris's Arc de Triomphe was the tallest triumphal arch until the completion of the Monumento a la Revolución in Mexico City in 1938, which is 67 m high. The Arch of Triumph in Pyongyang, completed in 1982, is modeled on the Arc de Triomphe and is slightly taller at 60 m . The Grande Arche in La Défense near Paris is 110 metres high, and, if considered to be a triumphal arch, is the world's tallest.
pois.address: Place de l'Étoile, Place Charles de Gaulle

pois.name: Carnavalet
pois.description: Housed in two beautifully restored historic mansions, known as hôtels, Carnavalet Museum offers a fascinating journey through the history of Paris. With more than 140 rooms filled with artifacts, artwork, and exhibits, the museum provides a comprehensive look at the city's rich past. From prehistoric times to the modern era, visitors can explore the evolution of Paris through its art, culture, and daily life. The museum's historic setting adds to its charm, making it a must-visit for anyone interested in the story of this iconic city.

pois.name: Opera Garnier
pois.description: The Palais Garnier, famously known as the setting for "The Phantom of the Opera," captivates visitors with its grandeur. Inside, the opulence mirrors the exterior, offering a visually stunning experience. Since the opening of the Opéra Bastille in 1989, the Palais Garnier has primarily become a venue for dance, particularly ballet, adding to its cultural significance.

pois.name: Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie
pois.description:
Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie is a must-visit destination for anyone fascinated by science and technology. Opened in 1986 and continually updated, this expansive museum offers a wealth of interactive exhibits that bring the wonders of science to life. One of the highlights is the Louis Lumière 3D cinema, where visitors can immerse themselves in cutting-edge visual experiences.

While the museum is particularly popular with families and children, its engaging displays and hands-on activities appeal to visitors of all ages. From exploring the frontiers of technology to discovering the marvels of the natural world, Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie is a place where learning is made fun and accessible. Whether you're a science enthusiast or just curious about the world around you, this iconic attraction promises an inspiring and educational experience.

pois.name: Panthéon
pois.description:
The Panthéon, originally envisioned by Louis XV as a grand neo-classical church dedicated to St. Geneviève, the patron saint of Paris, underwent a significant transformation after the French Revolution. It became a mausoleum honoring the great minds and heroes of the French Republic. The crypt holds the remains of esteemed figures such as Voltaire, Rousseau, Victor Hugo, and the Curies, among others, reflecting the nation's rich intellectual and cultural heritage.

One of the Panthéon's most striking features is its dome, which offers a breathtaking view of the city after climbing 206 steps. This architectural marvel is a must-visit for anyone seeking a panoramic perspective of Paris. Inside, visitors can also find a fascinating reconstruction of Foucault's pendulum, adding a touch of scientific intrigue to the historical ambiance.

For those planning a visit, it's advisable to check the tour departure times at the information desk to make the most of your experience. The Panthéon seamlessly blends historical significance with architectural beauty, making it a compelling destination for travelers interested in exploring Paris's cultural and scientific treasures.
pois.hours: Daily, April-September 10:00-18:30, October-March: 10:00-18:00, Last admission 45 mins before closing

pois.name: Notre Dame Cathedral
pois.description:
Notre Dame Cathedral is one of the most iconic landmarks in the world, and a must-visit attraction for anyone traveling to Paris. This stunning early Gothic cathedral, also known as "Cathédrale de Notre Dame" or "Our Lady," showcases the evolution of Gothic architecture. While its design was conceived in the 12th century, the cathedral wasn't fully completed until the 14th century. Its intricate design and soaring vaults make it a masterpiece of medieval engineering and artistry.

The cathedral's west portal, or main entrance, is particularly notable for its rigid, almost austere design, which stands out from the more fluid lines of the rest of the building. This contrast highlights the dynamic nature of Gothic architecture and its development over time.

In April 2019, Notre Dame suffered a devastating fire that caused significant damage to the structure, including the loss of its iconic spire. However, after a meticulous and extensive restoration process, the cathedral reopened to the public in December 2024. This resilience and renewal make Notre Dame not only a historical treasure but also a symbol of hope and rebirth.

Visitors to Notre Dame can marvel at its towering ceilings, stunning stained-glass windows, and the serene atmosphere that fills the space. Whether you're drawn by its religious significance, its architectural brilliance, or its cultural importance, Notre Dame Cathedral promises an unforgettable experience.
pois.address: Ile de la Cité 6, Place du Parvis Notre Dame

pois.name: Musée d'Orsay
pois.description: Housed in a former ''Beaux-Arts'' railway station (completed in 1900 for the ''Exposition Universelle'', later saved from demolition and converted to its present use), the rambling, open-plan museum is home to the works of the great artists of the 19th century (1848-1914) - Impressionists, post-Impressionists, and the rest - that were formerly displayed in the l'Orangerie. This is perhaps the most spectacular collection of European impressionism in the world—breath-taking rooms full of Manet, Renoir, Monet, Van Gogh, and many others. Impressionist represent the biggest draw, but there is much more to explore.
pois.address: 1, rue de la Légion d'Honneur / rue de Lille

pois.name: Picasso Museum
pois.description: Most of the works by Picasso and others which were in the master's possession at the time of his death are now on display here.
pois.hours: 09:30-18:00, W-M & 09:30-20:00 on Th, except during winter when closing time is always 17:30

pois.name: Musée national du Moyen Âge
pois.description: Musée de Cluny Housed in a 15th-century abbey, alongside 1st century Gallo-Roman baths, the museum has an extensive collection of medieval art and artifacts. Highlights include the medieval "Lady and the Unicorn" tapestries, a papal golden rose, and the original heads from the facade of Notre Dame.

pois.name: Rodin Museum
pois.description:
The Rodin Museum is a must-visit destination for art enthusiasts and anyone looking to immerse themselves in the works of one of history's greatest sculptors. This museum offers a unique opportunity to explore the life and artistry of Auguste Rodin through an extensive and beautifully curated collection of his sculptures, drawings, and other works. 

Housed in a spacious and elegant building, the museum's interior is as impressive as its contents. Large windows allow natural light to flood the galleries, creating a bright and airy atmosphere that enhances the viewing experience. The thoughtful presentation of the artworks, combined with the building's open design, makes the museum a pleasure to wander through.

Surrounding the museum is a beautiful garden, perfect for a relaxing stroll after exploring the galleries. The entire experience—whether indoors or outdoors—provides a deeper appreciation for Rodin's genius and leaves a lasting impression on all who visit.
pois.hours: Tu-Su: museum: 10:00-17:45, park: till 18:00; ticket office: till 17:15. Closed M

pois.name: Sainte-Chapelle
pois.description: Soaring stained glass windows beaming ample light onto the rich primary colours of the tile mosaics on the floor, this photogenic church was built by the French kings to house the relics of the Crown of Thorns. Make sure you go on a sunny day, as the highlight of this small chapel in Rayonnante Gothic style are the large stained-glass windows which soar up to near the vaulted ceiling. Also of interest is the extremely ornate lower level. If it happens to be rainy or cloudy, give Sainte-Chapelle a miss, as the play of coloured lights on the floor is well worth the wait for a sunnier day. As the chapelle is inside the Courts of Justice, there will thus be a security check.

pois.name: Mémorial de la Shoah
pois.description: The Holocaust Memorial Opened in January 2005, the Holocaust Memorial comprises a major documentation centre and a wall bearing 76,000 names of Jews deported from France to the Nazi camps between 1942-1944. Includes an archive of a million artefacts, including 55,000 photographs. Excursions are run from the memorial to French internment camp sites such as Drancy.

pois.name: The Louvre
pois.description: Its exhibits come from such diverse origins as ancient Egypt, classical Greece and the Roman Empire, medieval Europe, and Napoleonic France, but controversially including many items that were looted from their places of origin. Its most famous exhibit, of course, is Leonardo da Vinci's painting of the Mona Lisa (French: ''La Joconde'', Italian: ''La Gioconda''), generally to be found surrounded by hordes of camera-flashing tourists. The Louvre poses many of the same challenges to the visitor as Paris itself; overwhelming in size, crowded in high seasons, and much information available only in French. If you want to see everything in the Louvre, plan ''at least'' two full days. However, it is better to pick and choose, as the collection was assembled with an eye to completeness rather than quality. As of July 2019, due to intense crowding and reports of ticket fraud, entry now almost always requires a pre-booked timed ticket, even for holders of the Paris Museum Pass.
pois.hours: W-M 09:00-18:00, closed public holidays; evening openings W and F until 21:45

pois.name: Centre Georges Pompidou
pois.description: Those who are unfamiliar with conceptual art sometimes don't know quite what to expect, or how to approach it. Such travellers should rest assured that the curators at the Pompidou Centre have assembled a marvellous introduction consisting of mostly approachable works which delight, amuse, and entertain. The art is far from the only reason for a visit, as the building also contains a vast public library and a fine restaurant (run by the Costes brothers) on the roof. In fact the place is ''literally'' surrounded by some of the nicest pavement cafés in the city, in its superb location between the car-free above ground part of Forum Les Halles and the Marais art district.

pois.name: Musée de l'Orangerie
pois.description: Musée de la Orangerie Reopened after extensive renovations, this small museum near the Louvre houses the ''Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume Collection'', sold to the French Republic on very generous terms and numbering 143 paintings from the late 19th century and the first half of the 20th century (15 Cézannes, 24 Renoirs, 10 Matisses, 12 Picassos, 28 Derains, 22 Soutines). The collection joined the eight immense ''Water Lilies'' that Monet gave France in 1922 and which have been displayed since 1927 in two huge oval rooms purpose-built on the artist's instructions.
pois.hours: W-M (closed Christmas Day and 1 May) individuals 12:30-19:00, Th till 21:00; groups, 09:30-12:30;

pois.name: Jacquemart-Andre Museum
pois.description: Jacquemart-Andre Museum Private collection of French, Italian, Dutch masterpieces in a typical XIXth century mansion.

pois.name: Guimet Museum
pois.description: Searching Wikipedia...

pois.name: Musée des Arts Décoratifs
pois.description: The Musée des Arts Décoratifs is a must-visit museum in Paris, located in the 1st arrondissement within the historic Palais du Louvre. As one of the largest decorative arts museums in Europe, it showcases a vast collection of decorative arts, spanning centuries and styles. From intricate furniture to dazzling jewelry, the museum offers a fascinating glimpse into the evolution of design and craftsmanship. Operated by the MAD arts association since 1882, it remains a cornerstone of Parisian cultural heritage, inviting visitors to explore the beauty and creativity of decorative arts.

pois.name: Eglise de Saint Sulpice
pois.description: a Roman Catholic church on the east side of the Place Saint-Sulpice within the rue Bonaparte, in the Luxembourg Quarter of the VIe arrondissement. At 113 metres long, 58 metres in width and 34 metres tall, it is only slightly smaller than Notre-Dame and thus the second largest church in the city. It is dedicated to Sulpitius the Pious. During the 18th century, an elaborate gnomon, the Gnomon of Saint-Sulpice, was constructed in the church. In front of the church itself is the magnificent Place Saint-Sulpice which contains the 'Fountain of the Four Bishops'. The church has a long-standing tradition of talented organists that dates back to the eighteenth century. In 1862, Aristide Cavaillé-Coll reconstructed and improved the existing organ built by François-Henri Clicquot. Though using many materials from Clicquot's French Classical organ, it is considered to be Cavaillé-Coll's magnum opus, featuring 102 speaking stops, and is perhaps the most impressive instrument of the romantic French symphonic-organ era. Its organists have also been renowned, starting with Nicolas Séjan in the 18th century, and continuing with Charles-Marie Widor (organist 1870-1933) and Marcel Dupré (organist 1934-1971), both great organists and composers of organ music. The current organists are 'titulaire' Daniel Roth (since 1985) and 'assistant titulaire' Sophie-Véronique Cauchefer-Choplin. In Saint-Sulpice Sunday organ recitals are held on a regular basis (Auditions du Dimanche, following the High Mass, usually from 11:30am till 12:05pm, during the subsequent mass, a visit of the organ loft is possible).

pois.name: Panthéon
pois.description:
The Panthéon, originally envisioned by Louis XV as a grand neo-classical church dedicated to St. Geneviève, the patron saint of Paris, underwent a significant transformation after the French Revolution. It became a mausoleum honoring the great minds and heroes of the French Republic. The crypt holds the remains of esteemed figures such as Voltaire, Rousseau, Victor Hugo, and the Curies, among others, reflecting the nation's rich intellectual and cultural heritage.

One of the Panthéon's most striking features is its dome, which offers a breathtaking view of the city after climbing 206 steps. This architectural marvel is a must-visit for anyone seeking a panoramic perspective of Paris. Inside, visitors can also find a fascinating reconstruction of Foucault's pendulum, adding a touch of scientific intrigue to the historical ambiance.

For those planning a visit, it's advisable to check the tour departure times at the information desk to make the most of your experience. The Panthéon seamlessly blends historical significance with architectural beauty, making it a compelling destination for travelers interested in exploring Paris's cultural and scientific treasures.
pois.hours: Daily, April-September 10:00-18:30, October-March: 10:00-18:00, Last admission 45 mins before closing

pois.name: Église Saint-Eustache
pois.description: The massive parish church of the Les Halles area is a notable example of late Gothic interspersed with Renaissance details (including the entire front façade), as it was only completed in the 17th century. Its unique form results from a combination of relatively short length and impressive height of over 30 metres inside. The latter allows room not only for an array of stained glass windows and paintings, but also France's largest church organ of 8,000 pipes. The sculpture ''Écoute'', depicting an oversized human head, was placed in front of the church's southern facade and has become a favourite photo spot.

pois.name: Notre Dame Cathedral
pois.description:
Notre Dame Cathedral is one of the most iconic landmarks in the world, and a must-visit attraction for anyone traveling to Paris. This stunning early Gothic cathedral, also known as "Cathédrale de Notre Dame" or "Our Lady," showcases the evolution of Gothic architecture. While its design was conceived in the 12th century, the cathedral wasn't fully completed until the 14th century. Its intricate design and soaring vaults make it a masterpiece of medieval engineering and artistry.

The cathedral's west portal, or main entrance, is particularly notable for its rigid, almost austere design, which stands out from the more fluid lines of the rest of the building. This contrast highlights the dynamic nature of Gothic architecture and its development over time.

In April 2019, Notre Dame suffered a devastating fire that caused significant damage to the structure, including the loss of its iconic spire. However, after a meticulous and extensive restoration process, the cathedral reopened to the public in December 2024. This resilience and renewal make Notre Dame not only a historical treasure but also a symbol of hope and rebirth.

Visitors to Notre Dame can marvel at its towering ceilings, stunning stained-glass windows, and the serene atmosphere that fills the space. Whether you're drawn by its religious significance, its architectural brilliance, or its cultural importance, Notre Dame Cathedral promises an unforgettable experience.
pois.address: Ile de la Cité 6, Place du Parvis Notre Dame

pois.name: Saint-Germain l'Auxerrois
pois.description: This Gothic church functioned until the 19th century as the parish church of the kings of France. In this role, the church has sometimes played a gruesome part in history. Its bell called 'Marie' sounded on the night of 23 August 1572, to launch the St. Bartholomew's Day Massacre, in which thousands of Huguenots were killed by Catholic mobs. Nowadays, the church is peaceful and an active parish church for commoners (the monarchy having long since given way to the Republic), and well worth visiting.

pois.name: Eglise Saint-Étienne-du-Mont
pois.description: St. Geneviève was responsible for saving Paris from the Huns in 451 and her shrine in the church has been a popular place of pilgrimage ever since. The church as it stands dates from between 1492 and 1626 and is a mix of Gothic and Renaissance architectural styles. A unique feature is the Renaissance rood screen, the sole survivor in the city.

pois.name: Sainte-Chapelle
pois.description: Soaring stained glass windows beaming ample light onto the rich primary colours of the tile mosaics on the floor, this photogenic church was built by the French kings to house the relics of the Crown of Thorns. Make sure you go on a sunny day, as the highlight of this small chapel in Rayonnante Gothic style are the large stained-glass windows which soar up to near the vaulted ceiling. Also of interest is the extremely ornate lower level. If it happens to be rainy or cloudy, give Sainte-Chapelle a miss, as the play of coloured lights on the floor is well worth the wait for a sunnier day. As the chapelle is inside the Courts of Justice, there will thus be a security check.

pois.name: Eglise Saint-Julien-le-Pauvre
pois.description:
Saint-Julien-le-Pauvre, in full Église Saint-Julien-le-Pauvre (French for Church of Saint Julian the Poor), is a Melkite Greek Catholic parish church in Paris, France, and one of the city's oldest religious buildings. Begun in Romanesque style during the 12th century, most of its architecture is Primary Gothic. It is situated in the 5th arrondissement, on the Left Bank of the Seine River, about 500 meters away from the Musée de Cluny and in the proximity of the Maubert-Mutualité Paris Métro station. It shares a city block with the Square René Viviani.
Originally a Roman Catholic place of worship, Saint-Julien-le-Pauvre was built in stages from the 12th to the 19th centuries, and granted to the Eastern Catholic Melkite community in 1889.

pois.name: Cathédrale Saint-Louis
pois.description: Cathédrale Saint-Louis is a historic landmark that offers a glimpse into the region's rich cultural and spiritual heritage. This stunning cathedral, known for its striking architecture, features intricate designs and soaring vaults that create a sense of awe and tranquility. Visitors can admire the beautiful stained-glass windows, which filter in vibrant hues of light, and explore the serene atmosphere that makes it a perfect spot for reflection. The cathedral also hosts various cultural events and religious services throughout the year, making it a must-visit destination for both history enthusiasts and those seeking a peaceful retreat.

pois.name: Bercy Village
pois.description: For a taste of the French countryside, a visit to Bercy Village brings to life the spirit of market shopping inside Paris.

pois.name: Marché St-Quentin
pois.description: Market that offers a variety of goods from flowers and produce to antiques and candies.

pois.name: Rue Montorgueil pedestrian area
pois.description: Rue Montorgueil is like a scene from a movie. Closed to traffic, the street is a food-lovers delight, with cafes, bars, and all types of fresh produce for sale in the open air.

pois.name: Terroirs d'Avenir
pois.description: Slow food distribution on three different stores: a grocer, a fish monger and a butcher. They all source fresh, quality, mostly organic produce.

pois.name: Rue Cler
pois.description: Market street 10 minutes from the Eiffel Tower. The market is at its best on Tu–Sa, 08:30–13:00 or 15:00–19:30; Su, 08:30–12:00; closed on M.

pois.name: Marché aux Puces de St-Ouen
pois.description: Clignancourt Flea Market Widely-acclaimed as the largest flea market in all of Europe, in existence since 1885, this sprawling bazaar is made up of both permanent stalls and temporary stands (over 2,000 of them), arranged in winding, sometimes chaotic arcades, over 15 km of walkways, and over 10 differently-themed sub-markets. Everything from fine antiques through to collectible kitsch and bric-a-brac. Big on retro fashion also. Very popular with tourists, making it more difficult here to find a real bargain, but it is always worth looking. Convenient, competitive shipping is available at the market to send your precious finds back home all over the world. Be prepared to bargain!

pois.name: Marché du livre ancien et d'occasion
pois.description: Antique and second-hand books are sold.

pois.name: Village Suisse
pois.description: Quality antique dealers and galleries.

pois.name: Bois de Boulogne
pois.description:
Bois de Boulogne is a sprawling urban oasis located on the western edge of Paris' 16th arrondissement, near the suburb of Boulogne-Billancourt. Spanning an impressive 8.45 square kilometers, it is one of the largest parks in the city, offering a peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle of metropolitan life. For visitors looking to explore its vast grounds, the park provides ample opportunities for walking, picnicking, and enjoying outdoor activities like cycling and horseback riding. Its serene lakes and lush greenery make it a popular spot for both locals and travelers seeking relaxation.

In addition to its natural beauty, Bois de Boulogne is home to several cultural attractions, including the Jardin des Serres d'Auteuil, a stunning botanical garden with beautiful greenhouses. The park also hosts various events and activities throughout the year, making it a vibrant destination for all kinds of interests.

While the park is a tranquil retreat during the day, it transforms at night into a different kind of destination, attracting a diverse crowd. This duality makes Bois de Boulogne a fascinating and multifaceted place, reflecting the dynamic spirit of Paris itself.

pois.name: Avenue des Champs-Elysées
pois.description:
The Avenue des Champs-Élysées is an avenue in the 8th arrondissement of Paris, France, 1.9 kilometres long and 70 metres wide, running between the Place de la Concorde in the east and the Place Charles de Gaulle in the west, where the Arc de Triomphe is located. It is known for its theatres, cafés, and luxury shops; as the finish of the Tour de France cycling race; and for its annual Bastille Day military parade.

The name is French for the Elysian Fields, the place for dead heroes in Greek mythology. It has been described as the "most beautiful avenue in the whole world".

pois.name: Eiffel Tower
pois.description:
The Eiffel Tower is a wrought-iron lattice tower on the Champ de Mars in Paris, France. It is named after the engineer Gustave Eiffel, whose company designed and built the tower from 1887 to 1889.

Locally nicknamed "La dame de fer" , it was constructed as the centerpiece of the 1889 World's Fair, and to crown the centennial anniversary of the French Revolution. Although initially criticised by some of France's leading artists and intellectuals for its design, it has since become a global cultural icon of France and one of the most recognisable structures in the world. The tower received 5,889,000 visitors in 2022. The Eiffel Tower is the most visited monument with an entrance fee in the world: 6.91 million people ascended it in 2015. It was designated a monument historique in 1964, and was named part of a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1991.

The tower is 330 metres tall, about the same height as an 81-storey building, and the tallest structure in Paris. Its base is square, measuring 125 metres on each side. During its construction, the Eiffel Tower surpassed the Washington Monument to become the tallest human-made structure in the world, a title it held for 41 years until the Chrysler Building in New York City was finished in 1930. It was the first structure in the world to surpass both the 200-metre and 300-metre mark in height. Due to the addition of a broadcasting aerial at the top of the tower in 1957, it is now taller than the Chrysler Building by 5.2 metres . Excluding transmitters, the Eiffel Tower is the second tallest free-standing structure in France after the Millau Viaduct.

The tower has three levels for visitors, with restaurants on the first and second levels. The top level's upper platform is 276 m above the ground—the highest observation deck accessible to the public in the European Union. Tickets can be purchased to ascend by stairs or lift to the first and second levels. The climb from ground level to the first level is over 300 steps, as is the climb from the first level to the second, making the entire ascent a 600-step climb. Although there is a staircase to the top level, it is usually accessible only by lift. On this top, third level is a private apartment built for Gustave Eiffel's personal use. He decorated it with furniture by Jean Lachaise and invited friends such as Thomas Edison.

pois.name: Château de Versailles
pois.description:
Nestled in the heart of France, the Château de Versailles stands as a testament to the country's rich history and architectural brilliance. This iconic estate is a must-visit destination for anyone drawn to grandeur, art, and the elegance of a bygone era. As you approach the château, its imposing facade, adorned with intricate stone carvings and gilded details, sets the tone for an unforgettable experience.

Step inside, and you're transported into a world of opulence. The Hall of Mirrors, with its dazzling array of mirrors and crystal chandeliers, is a sight to behold. Each room is a masterpiece, showcasing exquisite furnishings and artworks that reflect the lavish lifestyle of French monarchy. The Royal Chapel, with its soaring vaulted ceiling, is another highlight, offering a glimpse into the spiritual life of the royal family.

The true magic of Versailles, however, lies in its expansive gardens. Stroll through the meticulously manicured lawns, where perfectly aligned trees and vibrant flowerbeds create a symphony of color and texture. The Orangery, with its citrus trees, and the Grand Canal, where you can enjoy a leisurely boat ride, are just a few of the many treasures waiting to be discovered. Don’t miss the stunning fountains, which come alive with choreographed water displays, especially during the summer months.

Beyond the main palace, the estate boasts charming additions like the Trianon palaces and the Hamlet, offering a more intimate glimpse into the private lives of the royals. These lesser-known areas are perfect for those seeking a peaceful retreat from the crowds.

Throughout the year, Versailles hosts various cultural events and seasonal activities, from classical music concerts to ice skating in the winter. Whether you're exploring the palace, wandering the gardens, or simply soaking in the atmosphere, every moment at Château de Versailles is a step back in time. Plan to spend a full day here to fully appreciate the depth of history, art, and natural beauty that this incredible attraction has to offer.
pois.address: 1 Rue Robert De Cotte, 78000 Versailles, France
pois.hours: Nov-Mar: Tu-Su 09:00-1730, Apr-Oct: Tu-Su 09:00-18:30; closed Jan 1, May 1 and Dec 25

pois.name: Sacré Coeur
pois.description:
Perched on a hill in the heart of Montmartre, the Basilique du Sacré Coeur is one of Paris's most iconic landmarks. This stunning white church, with its towering domes and intricate architecture, offers breathtaking views of the city. Built between 1875 and 1914, Sacré Coeur was constructed as a symbol of hope and reconciliation following the turmoil of the Franco-Prussian War and the Paris Commune. Its design, a mix of Romano-Byzantine styles, is both grand and graceful, making it a must-visit for architecture enthusiasts and history buffs alike.

Visitors can reach the top of the hill via a short but steep walk or by taking the Montmartre funicular, which runs regularly during the day. Once at the summit, the panoramic views of Paris from the dome and the square in front of the church are simply stunning, rivaling those from the Eiffel Tower. The square itself, 200 meters above sea level, is a popular spot to relax and take in the city's skyline.

While exploring the area, be mindful of a few local customs and safety tips. Photography inside the church is not allowed, so be respectful of the rules. Additionally, you may encounter street vendors or individuals approaching you near the lower steps. If you're uncomfortable, a firm but polite refusal is usually sufficient. Should you feel unsafe, don't hesitate to seek assistance from nearby authorities.

Sacré Coeur is more than just a beautiful building; it's a piece of Paris's history and a symbol of peace. Whether you're there to admire its architecture, enjoy the views, or simply soak in the atmosphere, it's an experience you won't want to miss.
pois.address: 4 Rue Du Cardinal Guibert, 75018 Paris, France

pois.name: Palais de Chaillot
pois.description: Great perspective on the Eiffel Tower and Left Bank from ''Place du Trocadéro'' in between the two buildings of the palais. Former location of the Palais du Trocadéro. It accommodates three museums, an aquarium, and the Theatre Nationale du Chaillot.

pois.name: Grande Arche de la Defense
pois.description:
The Grande Arche de la Defense is a striking modern landmark in Paris, known for its bold, cube-like design that reimagines the traditional concept of an arch. This monumental structure, located in the bustling La Defense district, is a testament to contemporary architecture and serves as a gateway to the city. While its design may appear more geometric than a conventional arch, it has become an iconic symbol of Paris's blend of history and innovation.

Visitors should note that the viewing platform at the top of the Grande Arche has experienced periodic closures over the years. After being closed following an elevator incident in 2010, it reopened to the public in May 2017. However, as of October 2023, the platform is once again closed. Travelers planning to visit are encouraged to check for updates on accessibility before heading to the site. Despite the viewing platform's current status, the Grande Arche remains a must-see attraction for its architectural significance and its role as a symbol of Paris's dynamic spirit.

pois.name: Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile
pois.description:
The Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile, often called simply the Arc de Triomphe, is one of the most famous monuments in Paris, France, standing at the western end of the Champs-Élysées at the centre of Place Charles de Gaulle, formerly named Place de l'Étoile—the étoile or "star" of the juncture formed by its twelve radiating avenues. The location of the arc and the plaza is shared between three arrondissements, 16th , 17th , and 8th . The Arc de Triomphe honours those who fought and died for France in the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars, with the names of all French victories and generals inscribed on its inner and outer surfaces. Beneath its vault lies the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier from World War I.

The central cohesive element of the Axe historique , the Arc de Triomphe was designed by Jean Chalgrin in 1806; its iconographic programme pits heroically nude French youths against bearded Germanic warriors in chain mail. It set the tone for public monuments with triumphant patriotic messages. Inspired by the Arch of Titus in Rome, Italy, the Arc de Triomphe has an overall height of 50 m , width of 45 m and depth of 22 m , while its large vault is 29.19 m high and 14.62 m wide. The smaller transverse vaults are 18.68 m high and 8.44 m wide.

Paris's Arc de Triomphe was the tallest triumphal arch until the completion of the Monumento a la Revolución in Mexico City in 1938, which is 67 m high. The Arch of Triumph in Pyongyang, completed in 1982, is modeled on the Arc de Triomphe and is slightly taller at 60 m . The Grande Arche in La Défense near Paris is 110 metres high, and, if considered to be a triumphal arch, is the world's tallest.
pois.address: Place de l'Étoile, Place Charles de Gaulle

pois.name: Panthéon
pois.description:
The Panthéon, originally envisioned by Louis XV as a grand neo-classical church dedicated to St. Geneviève, the patron saint of Paris, underwent a significant transformation after the French Revolution. It became a mausoleum honoring the great minds and heroes of the French Republic. The crypt holds the remains of esteemed figures such as Voltaire, Rousseau, Victor Hugo, and the Curies, among others, reflecting the nation's rich intellectual and cultural heritage.

One of the Panthéon's most striking features is its dome, which offers a breathtaking view of the city after climbing 206 steps. Inside, visitors can also find a fascinating reconstruction of Foucault's pendulum, adding a touch of scientific intrigue to the historical ambiance.

For those planning a visit, it's advisable to check the tour departure times at the information desk to make the most of your experience. The Panthéon seamlessly blends historical significance with architectural beauty, making it a compelling destination for travelers interested in exploring Paris's cultural and scientific treasures.
pois.hours: Daily, April-September 10:00-18:30, October-March: 10:00-18:00, Last admission 45 mins before closing

pois.name: Notre Dame Cathedral
pois.description:
Notre Dame Cathedral is one of the most iconic landmarks in the world, and a must-visit attraction for anyone traveling to Paris. This stunning early Gothic cathedral, also known as "Cathédrale de Notre Dame" or "Our Lady," showcases the evolution of Gothic architecture.
